Governmental deregulation of interest rates and the resultant competition for investors' funds is against the national interest. It is inflationary and penetrates every sphere of the economy. TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 1,545 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the introduction of tuition fees for post-graduate and second degree students will:

(i) severely limit access to such levels of study. The ability of a student to pay tuition fees will be the main criterion for entry to such courses. The restricted availability of Commonwealth post-graduate scholarships and the difficulty of finding part-time work in employment related areas further restricts the ability of post-graduate students to pay tuition fees.

(ii) result in higher attrition rates in post-graduate and second degree studies. Recent surveys have indicated that up to 50% of students would be unable to continue their studies if tuition fees at the level of $1,000 per year were introduced. Inability to continue study is both a personal tragedy and a waste of the community's resources.

(iii) limit Australia's capacity to cope with technological, economic and social change. Many degree students who will have to pay tuition fees undertake further study to upgrade their qualifications to cope with changes in their area of employment. Many are forced to undertake retraining in areas outside their current employment because of declining job opportunities in such areas due to economic change. Further study for many students will bring no financial benefit but simply allow them to extend their contribution in the course of their work. For example, thousands of teachers have undertaken further study to gain expertise in such areas as migrant education, remedial literacy and numeracy teaching, curriculum development and so on.

(iv) further restrict access to such study for women students. As a result of the abolition of tuition fees the proportion of women students in tertiary education has increased significantly. Mature age women students have benefited by the opportunity denied them when they left school.

(v) seriously undermine Australia's research effort. Approximately 22% of Australian research takes place in tertiary institutions. The bulk of Australia's basic research is undertaken in universities. The introduction of tuition fees threatens Australia's capacity to cope with major structural change in the economy.
Your petitioners therfore humbly pray that the Senate will reject the introduction of tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

(a) manufacturers normally allow 30 to 60 days credit facilities to their customers and, in many cases, payment is not received until 60-90 days have elapsed;

(b) to be able to pay the tax on the due date yet before payment for the goods has been received, the manufacturers, especially small business, are forced to borrow finance at the high current overdraft rates; and

(c) allowing more time to pay would be a small change in the legislation, which would cost no revenue to the Government but give a considerable relief to the business community, and cost savings which could be passed on to consumers, alleviating their burden also.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, three sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1981 No. 302, and made under the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Act 1976, be disallowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would like to draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the Gallery today of ex-Senator Laurie Neal. We extend to Mr Neal a very cordial and warm welcome back to this place.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to my question to him last week relating to the transfer to the States of all responsibility for soil conservation and the grave situation which this could create for Australian agriculture in the years to come. In light of the Minister's answer to me last week, did he write to the Minister for Agriculture of New South Wales on 29 June of this year? I ask Senator Carrick whether, in his letter to the Minister in New South Wales, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I do appreciate your disappointment at the termination of what may have developed into a productive area of Commonwealth States co-operation in developing a national approach to safeguarding the nation's soil resources for future generations.

Does this indicate that Senator Carrick regrets the fact that the Commonwealth, at the behest of the so-called razor gang, has withdrawn the small sum of $3m previously allocated for soil conservation work? Is it the Minister's view that there should be, as he put it in that letter, a national approach to safeguarding soil resources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember my answer to Senator Button last week. Indeed, yesterday I gave a more extensive answer on soil conservation. I pointed out that historically, and in terms of sovereignty, land and therefore the management of land and its soil, is a State matter. I said that what had happened was that the Commonwealth had made a relatively modest gesture towards it and that in no way could it be seen to be one that would supersede or even be predominant in terms of soil conservation. I said that it had been decided that the amount of money should be absorbed into the grants and, therefore, it would be available to the States for them to manage. By and large the State systems of the management of soil conservation have a considerable expertise.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not recall a letter dated 29 June. But I imagine that what Senator Button said could be true. I send only approximately 100 letters a day; so it is unlikely that I would recall one letter on 29 June. Indeed, if what Senator Button read is correct, I said that I understood the disappointment of the Minister in the State. I think they are his words. I did not express my own disappointment in the matter. I will look up the letter and refresh my mind on that. The Cabinet has made a decision in which I concur. The fact is that we will be developing in many ways as I said yesterday-particularly through water schemes and similar schemes and through the various ecological protections that come under other departments-matters which will overall preserve the topsoil and ensure the general conservation of the natural resources of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister now: Was the Cabinet decision in which he concurs made in April? I appreciate his difficulty about not remembering all the letters he wrote, but I ask the Minister whether he conceives it as being possible that in June of this year he might have described the Commonwealth's role in the provision at least of co-ordination for a national approach to soil resources as being a productive area of Commonwealth-State co-operation for future generations?

—Again, discussions on what amount to Budget matters take place between February and the end of July. Therefore, as to when finally individual decisions were made and put within the Budget I cannot answer at all. Nor would I answer in regard to a particular date that a Cabinet decision was made that was part of the Budget.
—I am talking about the razor gang decision; you know that. In April, the razor gang made a decision.

—If the interjection is to be noted, the so-called razor gang-the Review of Commonwealth Functions-decision was not a decision; it was a recommendation. It was necessary for each of its recommendations to be considered by Cabinet, to be adopted or otherwise. Of course the final adoption was part of the Budget which was expressed in this chamber in August.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to the subject of methanol as a gasolene extender in Australia and in particular the study carried out on the marketing and production aspects of methanol prepared by Davy McKee Pty Ltd for the Department of National Development and Energy, to which the Minister referred in his Press statement on 13 October 1981. The report examined three possible plant sites-one in Queensland and one in New South Wales, both using coal feedstock, and one in Victoria which would utilise natural gas. Is it not the case that the known gas reserves in eastern Australia would be insufficient to meet current demands as well as provide the feedstock for the methanol plant? Is the Minister aware that work done by the South Australian Department of Mines and Energy, summarised in a paper in June 1981, estimated that the cost of gas produced by a gasification plant located at the Wakefield coal deposit would be $3.50 to $4 per million British thermal units, which is less than the raw materials price for Victorian natural gas upon which the Davy McKee assessment of the Victorian project was made? Is the Minister aware that the estimated cost of coal recovery at Wakefield is $10 a tonne, a more than favourable figure when compared with the New South Wales and Queensland coal projects? Is the Minister also aware that in pilot studies the Wakefield coal has been found to be uniquely suited to gas production and that the Westinghouse company in the United States found it to be the most reactive coal that it has yet analysed? Can he say whether the New South Wales or Queensland coals have been tested in gasification plants? Is it not the case that, on location criteria specified in the report, the location at Wakefield is at least the equal of the proposed sites in Queensland and New South Wales? Finally, in selecting sites for further consideration, did the consultants consider the Wakefield site in South Australia and, if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My Department has, through the National Energy Advisory Committee, arranged for five research papers to be done on methanol. That which relates to production and marketing is the first, and it is available for discussion. The fact is that the report did address itself to Queensland and New South Wales coal and to Victorian gas. In general terms, at this moment it would be true that insufficient proving of natural gas in eastern Australia has been done to be sure that one could readily use it for some other purpose than that for which it is used now, such as extensive use in the production of methanol. For example, the tapping of methane from coal mines in the Appin area of New South Wales is regarded as being productive. There are signs, incidentally, that more gas fields are being located. One hopes that that will prove to be the case in the Gippsland and Otway basins. There are very significant signs that the west coast of Australia will emerge as noteworthy, perhaps even in world terms.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Hill described as encouraging the location of coal in South Australia, which was not known previously to have considerable coal resources. I understand that to be correct. I do not know the exact pricing of these matters. The report directed itself to the production of methanol from coal. It may well be that it could be done more cost effectively in South Australia. If we can find a large gas field, the production of methanol from gas is a very ready and much cheaper system. Also the liquid product can be carted much more readily than compressed natural gas. I am as eager as the honourable senator to see the development of the coal resources, the fossil fuel resources, in South Australia. I will direct the attention of my Department to his comparative figures as between the likely cost feasibility in South Australia and elsewhere and ask it whether it has a comment to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health give a general indication as to how many Australians are currently without medical or hospital insurance cover? Has the response from the disadvantaged sections of the community to obtaining the free medical cards been satisfactory? Finally, what steps are being taken by the Government to measure the effectiveness of our latest health scheme?

—I believe that approximately 30 per cent of people are uninsured. I would have to get the exact figure, but about 70 per cent of the people are insured. The issuing of health cards to the disadvantaged is a matter for the Department of Social Security. I suggest that this part of the question be directed to my colleague the Minister for Social Security. I am aware that the new health insurance arrangements are designed to bring to all Australians the benefits of security and of certain cover for their health costs.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, refers to the defence statement made last week by the Minister for Defence in relation to the acquisition of a replacement carrier for HMAS Melbourne. In view of the exhaustive analyses carried out by the Department of Defence in relation to the new tactical fighter program, will the Minister list those studies or reports prepared by the Department of Defence and its agencies which explored the question whether HMAS Melbourne should be replaced? Will the Minister table those reports?
—I will direct that question to the Minister for Defence and seek his response.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs been advised that there have been massive retrenchments in the mining industry in the Northern Territory over the past few weeks and that further retrenchments are anticipated? How many officers of the Commonwealth Employment Service are at present engaged in placing those people who have been retrenched? Will she undertake to put more officers in the field to ensure that those who will lose their jobs will be relocated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs the matter of the number of officers of the Commonwealth Employment Service who are directly working with those who have been retrenched in the situation mentioned by Senator Robertson. I will also ask him to check as to whether more officers are required effectively to give the assistance that may be within the reaches of the CES. As soon as I have some information on this matter, I will see that Senator Robertson is advised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations and, in his tenuous link, representing the Acting Attorney-General, is about a Mr Noel Latham who, I am sure Senator Chaney will recall, was the worker at Broken Hill who was denied the opportunity to work in Broken Hill because he refused to join the union which runs that city. I ask: Is the Minister aware that today in the Supreme Court of New South Wales His Honour, Mr Justice Nagle, in a very lengthy judgment awarded Noel Latham damages of $100,000 against 41 of the 75 Broken Hill unionists who were the defendants in the case. Apparently 30 of the unionists were let off, three died and one disappeared.

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister aware that Mr Latham has claimed this judgment as the most important social decision given by the New South Wales Supreme Court this century? Does the Commonwealth have laws similar to those under which this judgment was given? If not, will the Government takes steps to adopt such laws so that civil protection similar to this may be given to those in Australia who are denied the right to work by militant closed shop unions?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen reports of the judgment to which the honourable senator referred in his question. I agree with him that this area of legal activity is likely to be critically important to the question of civil liberties in this country; an area of civil liberties that is perhaps less attractive and of less concern to the Opposition than are some other areas. I am not in a position to give a detailed response to the question which has been asked, but I will ask Mr Viner to examine the points raised and to give an early reply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Does the Minister recall my question of 27 September 1979 in which I asked:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister aware-
It is most important and I am sure that the Minister will recall it. I continued:

That inadequate procedures to check oil production in Bass Strait could be costing the Federal Government millions of dollars in lost taxation revenue? I also ask whether he has seen the report of the Auditor-General for the year ended 30 June 1979 in which the Auditor-General castigated the Departments of National Development and Business and Consumer Affairs for:

. . . their failure to finalise satisfactory arrangements for the verification of production from the various fields in Bass Straight; and, consequently, of the amount payable as excise on naturally occurring petroleum liquids.
I then asked:
Is the Minister taking steps to require that departments ensure that the revenue is not defrauded or, at least, is not underpaid by the oil companies concerned . . .

Is it a fact now that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has reported that up to $100m has been lost to the revenues of the Federal and Victorian governments and that his Department 'must take a large share of the responsibility' for the failure to collect the correct excise? I now ask: What precise steps did the Minister take after my question of two years ago to ensure that his Department remedy its failure to devise satisfactory verification arrangements as required by the Auditor-General? Why did these steps, if any, fail? What responsibility does the Minister accept for this failure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may not surprise Senator Tate on two counts that I do not recall his question of 27 September 1979 because I would fancy that it was about a week or so before I became the Minister, but I may have been the Minister at that time. I have been asked whether I have seen the Auditor-General's report. I ask Senator Tate whether he has seen the latest Auditor-General's report, because so much of his question will be answered when I read from the Auditor-General's report for 1980-81, tabled on 24 September 1981, which states:

ANSWER.PARA: Procedures for measurement and allocation of production to the separate fields in the Bass Strait area and for the calculation of royalties and excise on this production are complex. Important questions of principle also had to be resolved before formal agreement could be reached with the licensees in relation to the basis for ascertainment of the value at the wellhead of the production on which the royalties are payable. Royalties which have been paid by the licensees since 1968-69 were calculated on an interim basis pending recalculation after formal agreement was reached.
He then goes on to say:
Although the action now taken or in progress is long overdue, the results when finalised should ensure that there is a satisfactory system of control over the substantial amounts of revenue involved.
The Auditor-General has said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Only because of the Public Accounts Committee.

—Because Senator Georges interjects, I point out that the Public Accounts Committee and its Chairman acknowledge that the report is dated, that it is about a year old in its findings and it does not take account of this Auditor-General's report. The Auditor-General's report, on which I am questioned, says that the procedures now in place will be satisfactory.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, secondly I must say that the report of the Public Accounts Committee does not say that $100m has been lost at all. The report says that there could be errors one way or another-that is, that there could be an overpayment or an underpayment by the companies concerned in any one year to the extent of $10m; but nobody knows. I am now asked what was done based on the Auditor-General's situation. The fact is that there is perhaps no more complex procedure in existence than that involved in attempting to solve this problem. No doubt Senator Tate has far more omniscience and omnipotence than those who put forward a solution. It is considered that there is only one expert in the world who could give advice better than the advice we have now and we are employing that expert. We will indeed engage Senator Tate if he fits that role. To those who want to understand the situation, let me say--

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you give some credit to the Public Accounts Committee and not only to yourself?
—If you had a resource rent tax instead of the clumsy, inefficient tax system you have--

—Of course the noise is made to try to prevent the answer being given. The material comes from wells in a variety of forms. It comes in the form of oil, gas, condensate, sand, water and other materials. It comes from a series of different wells and it all goes into one pipe to come through the Halibut rig.
—And what a mess.

—No doubt Senator Georges would therefore be able to say that he could determine with accuracy the stabilised value and quantity of the oil itself from each individual well. This has bedevilled all the experts for years.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked what has been done. As to the first point, I want to say that we have no reason to believe that the licensees are not operating within normal engineering tolerances. To ensure that this is the case, the Commonwealth and Victorian Governments have engaged an international consultant to ensure that the licensees' sampling procedures are accurate and consistent with good oil field practice, to review the licensees' inbuilt controls and to verify that the procedures and standards are correctly applied. In addition, the Governments have encouraged the licensees to apply for registration with the National Association of Testing Authorities in relation to hydrocarbon fluid quality measurement. Registration will involve regular review of procedures by independent engineers and technologists. The technical procedures are presently being reviewed by the international consultant and by NATA. In addition, the measurement procedures have been examined by the National Measurement Laboratory of the Division of Applied Physics of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation.

Having said that and having drawn attention to the fact that the Auditor-General has said in the report-which Senator Tate conveniently did not read-that the procedures are now satisfactory, I should say that in an enormously complex problem what we have done has been to get the best expert advice in the world. We cannot answer whether in fact we have been collecting more or less money than we might from the oil companies, but we are endeavouring to find out. The fact of the matter is that the Auditor-General approves of what we are doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is it a fact that the Chairman of the Committee, Mr Connolly, has indicated that the balance of probability is in the companies' rather than the Government's favour as far as the question of lost revenue is concerned? Further, why has it taken 12 years for the Government to engage the international consultant of repute in order to ensure that in fact the revenue is not defrauded or at the least underpaid by the consortium concerned?

—I read in the Press, and I think it is in the report, that it is suggested that on the balance of probabilities the companies have not paid as much as they might. I understand simply that the belief is that commercially they would be smart enough to take the necessary action. I point out that for the several years that I have been Minister the Commonwealth has been in association with the Victorian Government, the companies and experts to try to get an answer. Indeed, this was proceeding before the Auditor-General drew attention to the matter. I think Senator Tate fails to understand that the problem is one that is so complex, so the Auditor-General says, that in itself it does not lend itself to straightforward answers at all and the probability is that what has been happening is in line with the giving of the correct answer. But we have not regarded that as good enough and, without prodding from the Auditor-General, we set in train a series of scientific actions to get the money. Honourable senators can rely on the fact that the Commonwealth and I as Minister have a keen eye to extra money for the Commonwealth, if it can be obtained.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs advise whether there is any truth in the rumour that some officials from the Department of Foreign Affairs have been meeting South African officials for the purpose of organising a new flight program with South African Airways whereby that airline will be able to have only one flight into Australia per week and one flight into Mauritius where passengers wishing to fly to Australia will have to disembark and then transfer to a Qantas Airways Ltd flight for the continuation of their journey? If this is true, will the Minister advise when we can expect to see an end to the Government's present policy of not allowing Qantas to fly into South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As I am advised, officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs have not met South African officials on the question of a new flight program for South African Airways. However, I understand that Qantas officials are in the process of meeting officials of a number of African airlines, including South African Airlines, to discuss the future of services between Australia and the African continent. Until these discussions are completed it would not be appropriate to comment further on the question that has been raised by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. I repeat that Qantas officials are having these discussions at present.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs to statements made by Mr Owen Covick, of the National Institute of Labour Studies, in relation to the abolition of Commonwealth Employment Service unemployment statistics. Mr Covick said:

QUESTION.PARA: The CES series were always a valuable aid in the interpretation of the state of the labour market (especially the finer subdivisions thereof). Every economic data series has its deficiencies so it is never advisable to rely wholly on any single one.

I ask the Minister: Why was such advice ignored when the decision was made to abolish CES statistics? Is the Minister aware that CES unemployment statistics were the only data series which gave an indication of the state of the labour market in particular occupations? Is the Minister aware also that these statistics were used extensively by various research bodies, including the manpower forecasting area of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs? Is it a fact that officers of this Department have now resorted to the inefficient and time consuming process of counting newspaper job advertisements to overcome data deficiencies caused by the abolition of CES statistics? Will the Minister undertake to rectify this situation and reintroduce the CES series which, according to the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research, was a very valuable series for forecasting work opportunities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think the first question raised by Senator Foreman was why such advice as was quoted by him in the early part of his question was ignored. I am not aware whether this particular advice was in the hands of the Minister when he made the decision to discontinue the collection of CES statistics. Also, I am not aware whether the Department's officials at present are counting newspaper job advertisements to gain information. I would imagine that a number of sources of information is available to them. However, I think it is fair to say that, when the decision was taken to discontinue the Commonwealth Employment Service statistics, there were certain dissatisfactions with those statistics. The inaccuracies evident in them were, of course, of concern. It was a decision that was taken with many factors being weighed at the time. I will certainly refer the details of the question asked by Senator Foreman to the Minister to see whether there are any comments that he wishes to make on how the Department is overcoming any gaps that may be occurring in its collection of information and whether he has any views on the recommendation that was made in the question that has just been put before the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has the Minister seen more Press reports stating that the Government will try to clarify the legal issues relating to the medical use of pancreatic tissue of aborted human beings? The Minister will recollect that I asked him some weeks ago for similar information and that I also asked the Attorney-General. What I wanted to know then and what I would like to know now is whether these babies have to be alive in order that their pancreatic tissue may be of use to the researchers. If this is so, what then happens to the babies when their pancreatic tissue is removed? Are they then allowed to die through deliberate inattention or do they die when the tissue is removed? Will the Minister please let me have answers to these questions?

—I have not yet been advised by the Minister whom I represent as to the answer to the specific question raised by Senator Martyr, that is, whether the foetal tissue has to be alive-whatever that means-before it is removed.
—A-l-i-v-e, alive.

—Senator, today it is not quite so simple as what is alive and what is dead. I have not seen the extra Press reports to which the honourable senator referred. I understand that the Departments are trying to clarify a number of issues which were raised by Senator Martyr. The issue is complex. I understand that the collection of information is taking some time. I will refer the matter to the Minister and I will see whether I can expedite at least the answer to the principal question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: OVERSEAS STUDENTS: ADMISSION TO AUSTRALIAN SECONDARY SCHOOLS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs: Have the guidelines governing the admission of overseas students to Australian secondary schools been liberalised? Were overseas students previously only able to come to Australia for year 12 studies at secondary schools? I understand that some of our independent or private schools have received up to 50 applications for year 10, year 11 and year 12 places from children from Malaysia, Singapore and Hong Kong. What provisions will be made for supporting these young people who are accepted into Australian schools, given that the regional offices of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau are scheduled to be closed? Will the Government reconsider its decision to close the regional ADAB offices given that a considerable influx of youngsters is planned, many of whom will not speak fluent English and who will be isolated from their families at a crucial age? Do overseas secondary school children coming here to study have to pay fees to the Government? Does the Minister know how many applications have been received for visas for overseas secondary school children wishing to study in Australia? Lastly, have any additional funds been made available to Australian schools and tertiary institutions for the support of young overseas students?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have no information on the many detailed matters that have been raised by Senator Siddons. I suggest that his question be placed on notice so that it may have the attention of the Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and refers to the Freedom of Information Bill which was passed by the Senate in June 1981 and which has languished, with its second reading stage uncompleted, in the House of Representatives since August. Does the Government now propose to adjourn the House of Representatives without further effort to pass the Bill through that House during this session? Does the Government realise that, because of progress made in Canada, it is now most likely that Australia will no longer be the first nation operating under the Westminster system of government to pass freedom of information legislation?

—I am not aware of the precise scheduling of the legislation in the House of Representatives for the remainder of this session. Therefore, I cannot answer that part of the question. Nor am I aware of whether Australia would be the first or second nation under the Westminster system to pass such legislation. I will obtain the information that the honourable senator seeks and advise him accordingly.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CROATIANS: CLANDESTINE MILITARY TRAINING IN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, although certain parts of it fall within the province of the Attorney-General. It refers to a television program, 60 Minutes, shown last Sunday in which three women of Croatian background claimed that their husbands had undertaken clandestine military training in Australia and had taken part in an armed incursion into Yugoslavia in 1972. Their claims were supported by photographic evidence showing the men training in Australia and showing them with their wives in France and Germany, where they met other members of an armed resistance group which apparently crossed the border into Yugoslavia in 1972. The women claimed that they had never heard from their husbands again and assumed that they were dead; also, that they risked their own lives by appearing on television. They claimed that this sort of training was still taking place in Australia. Will the Minister make a statement on the matter giving the Senate any information concerning the 1972 incident and also stating whether this type of military activity is still taking place within Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer the question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to ascertain whether he wishes to make a statement arising from the 60 Minutes program referred to by Senator Sibraa or any of the matters recalled by the honourable senator in his question. If the Minister wishes to make a statement on the matter I will see that the Senate is advised accordingly.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EAST BLOCK POST OFFICE AND EXCHANGE

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications able to inform the Senate as to what have been the results of my representations to him on behalf of certain members of the Parliament, members of the Press and certainly citizens of Canberra that the East Block post office and exchange should not be closed or removed to Sydney? Can the Minister give an assurance that the excellent services we have enjoyed for so long from the East Block facility will continue to be available in the Australian Capital Territory?

—I intervene because East Block is of significance in terms of potential parliamentary accommodation and therefore Mr Sinclair, the Leader of the House in another place, and I have taken an interest in it. Although the matter has not been finalised, both Mr Sinclair and I hold the view that there is need for a post office and general facilities in East Block and that its presence would not in any way delimit the abundant accommodation once the rear part of it is changed. I hope that we will be able to announce fairly soon that post office facilities in that area will be retained. I will endeavour to expedite that decision.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: PAYMENT OF BENEFITS

TALK.START.PARA: —I hesitate to ask my question, which is addressed to the Minister for Social Security, because it might spoil his day. I believe that he has just turned 40 and I assure him that his next 10 years will be as difficult as his last 10 years. My question relates to the Auditor-General's report, which devotes some 10 pages to his Department. In particular, the Auditor-General refers to a continuing problem of the overpayment of benefits to the extent of $45m. What does the Minister, as the Minister responsible, intend to do to correct this continuing problem?

—A number of problems give rise to overpayments. The sorts of figures quoted tend to look very large and, of course, they are a matter of concern to the public and to the Government. I will merely try to put those figures into some sort of context by pointing out that the expenditure of my Department this year is about $35m short of $10 billion. Obviously, therefore, quite large amounts represent a very small proportion of the total payments made by the Department. Part of the problem which has been raised relates to work bans on the recovery of overpayments. Staff in a number of offices-not universally but in a number of offices-have imposed bans and those bans are getting attention from my Department at this stage. However, all the observations of the Auditor-General have been taken in hand by my Department. I will get a more detailed reply to the honourable senator on the particular point he has raised. I say to him that it is a very poor reward for a long and otherwise rewarding friendship that he should have raised the matter of the Auditor-General on this particular day.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. It follows the question asked by Senator Robert Ray regarding health insurance figures. Has the Minister noted the recent claim made by the Australian Council of Social Service that between one million and two million people will not have health insurance cover under the new health arrangements which came into force on 1 September? Is there any evidence to suggest that this figure is in any way accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that between one-fifth and one-quarter of the population are covered by pensioner health benefits, by health care cards, by membership of the defence forces, et cetera. That leaves only some 75 per cent to 80 per cent of people who need to obtain health insurance. The available statistics which we have are accurate only up to the end of September and the true figure will not emerge until the October figures become available. I remind honourable senators that the new scheme includes a two-month waiver period during which people have an option to insure and that period will not expire for a little while. Until that is completed, we will not know exactly how many people are insured. We know that there is a real incentive now for people to obtain health insurance. I think that the question asked earlier today by Senator Robert Ray alluded to that.

ANSWER.PARA: The figures which are available seem to indicate that over half of those who were uninsured before 1 September have now taken out insurance. In general terms, it seems that approximately 70 per cent of the population-we will be able to confirm that figure only within the next month or so-have some health insurance cover and another 25 per cent or so are covered. That figure may in fact be greater when the facts emerge, but it is very hard from the available figures to identify the veracity or the accuracy of the ACOSS assertions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is there provision under the Social Services Act for the collection and utilisation of pension cheques by persons other than the beneficiaries? If so, is it possible for such authority to be given to the proprietor of a lodging house who is not registered to provide any form of medical or custodial care? Would Department of social security records show possible abuses of such authorisation or would there need to be a specific complaint before any investigation were made?

—There are provisions in the Social Services Act which permit payments to be made to persons other than the beneficiaries. Those conditions are fairly limited but they cover a wide range of circumstances, ranging from some Aboriginal communities which appoint somebody to receive their cheques en masse to some individual pensioners who, for health reasons or other circumstances, require the assistance of some member of their family or some other person. I think it is possible for somebody who is not a relative of a pensioner to receive an appointment with the consent of a pensioner. I have come across some isolated cases of complaint and those complaints are always very carefully investigated. It is a basic principle of the social security legislation that the pensioner or beneficiary is primarily entitled to the receipt of benefit. Any pensioner or beneficiary requesting that, of course, gets it. Specific arrangements to the contrary are required to be made for the cheque to be made payable to any other person. I will examine the point raised by the honourable senator in more detail and see whether I need to give her a more detailed reply.

—I direct a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Approximately 278 tonnes of yellowcake now sit on the Darwin wharf. As the yellowcake has been declared black by the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia in Darwin, there is considerable speculation as to the future effects of this ban. Is it true that the non-delivery of yellowcake to overseas markets is endangering future contracts and demand and also the jobs of many workers in the uranium province? Also, can the Minister provide the Senate with an overall view of the industry at present and how the Government sees future marketing of uranium by Australia?

—I will deal with the third question first. The Government has now approved the development of four new uranium mines. Two are in the Northern Territory. In addition, approval can also be expected to be sought for Jabiluka and Koongarra in due course. These mines are providing and will provide considerable employment of people in the Northern Territory. They are becoming an increasingly important part of the economy of Darwin and of the region. The people of the Northern Territory and particularly the unions recognise the value of these projects and want them to continue.
—Like the wharfies.
—I understand that the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia has a view. I think its secretary holds a view in favour of this and encourages it.
—And the Seamen's Union.

—Because of the interjections, I will repeat what I said yesterday: Those who advocate that no uranium should flow from Australia to provide energy throughout the world for peacetime purposes are, in fact, flying in the face of the world advice that the world cannot overcome its energy crisis without the use of an increasing volume of nuclear power. So the resistance aims at destabilisation and at lowering living standards. The Government is determined to ensure the development of the uranium mining industry in the Northern Territory and throughout Australia and is proceeding in accordance with these policies. Nothing could demonstrate more starkly the importance of the industry in the Northern Territory than recent publicity given to the closure of the Tennant Creek copper smelter and, now, the scaling down of activities at the Gove alumina plant. The consequent employment effects should be evident to all. The Government is very disappointed by the actions of the militant minority of unionists who are attempting to stop the export of uranium and are putting at risk the jobs of their fellow unionists.
—What about pig iron? You were happy then.

—There is an interjection: 'What about pig iron?' The Western Australian State Labor Government made an application to the Federal government of the day for the export of pig iron. Let history be put in its true position. It was a Western Australian State Labor government. The Australian uranium industry has a major contribution to make as a supplier to nations around the world which are seeking long term, reliable energy supplies. As I said yesterday, there are now some 450 reactors operating or under construction throughout the world. Australian companies with development approval have commitments to supply in the order of 54,000 short tons of yellowcake over the next 15 years. Australia is a reliable supplier of resources. The Government is determined that its reputation be maintained. I repeat that the International Energy Agency, comprising 21 nations of the free world, has indicated that unless resort is made more and more to the use of uranium for the generation of energy the living standards of people throughout the world will decline and, in fact, there could be destabilisation in the developing world. Those who stand in the way of the use of uranium are in fact bringing about that imperilment. I also want to see those who are talking about pollution from uranium look towards the pollution that the alternative huge use of coal will cause to the ecosystem. Let us be balanced on this matter. This is a major question for the stability of the living standards of the people of the world, as well as for the ecosystem. Those who simply want to ban this use fail to realise what they are doing both to living standards and to the ecology.
—Mr President, I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.
—I am perfectly happy to do that. I table the document.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government or, if he is unable to answer, perhaps the Minister for Finance will be able to help. I refer to the disastrous bushfires at Zeehan on the west coast of Tasmania last summer. The Minister will recall that, on 6 February and again on 7 February this year, the Minister for the Capital Territory, acting on behalf of the Prime Minister and the Government, promised the people of Zeehan full Commonwealth compensation for the damage caused by the bushfires. Is it true that the Federal Government has still not reimbursed the Tasmanian Government for all the rebuilding costs? When does the Government intend making good Mr Hodgman's pledge of last February, and how much will be paid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have some information on this matter although I do not know whether I have an answer to the specific question whether all the payments have actually been made. Under the normal call relief measures, the Commonwealth is meeting on a dollar for dollar basis with Tasmania the cost of assistance for the relief of personal hardship. It is also providing assistance on a $3 Commonwealth to $1 State basis, subject to the financial conditions of the arrangements for State expenditures on the restoration of public assets and emergency protection and repair work done by State, local and semi-government authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth has also advised the State of special assistance measures for Zeehan bushfire relief and the Commonwealth will provide assistance for State expenditures on rehousing loans to owner-occupiers under the natural disaster relief arrangements and, as a separate matter, will contribute on a $3 for $1 basis towards the cost of reconstructing the Zeehan scout hall, a central point for community activities. Furthermore, expenditure on welfare housing by the State Housing Commission also will be eligible for funding on a matching basis under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

The cost to the Commonwealth of these various measures of assistance will not be known until the State submits a formal claim for its expenditures. If I understand from the question of Senator Coates that there has been some delay in the payment of the Commonwealth assistance, I will make inquiries to see that that is expedited. The State usually submits a formal claim for this and then the Commonwealth would, for its part, match on the basis that I have outlined the various items of expenditure. I will undertake to see through my Department that there is no delay that can be avoided as far as the Commonwealth is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government. According to the Computer Abuse Research Bureau at the Caulfield Institute of Technology, the government sector has slightly more than one-third of Australian computer installations but is responsible for about 50 per cent of the value of all computer abuse. According to the latest report of the Auditor-General, government computer networks are a potential major disaster area and are in need of stricter security measures. What does the Government intend to do about these problems?

—I am not aware whether the government sector has one-third of the computer installations, but I would imagine that it must have a very formidable amount. I know that attempts in the past to rationalise that situation have caused more headaches than they have resolved. I can understand that there is a security problem in this matter. I do not know the precautions that are taken. I will direct the question to the appropriate Minister and secure a reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. Is there a concerted Government program to undermine the activities of the Commonwealth Employment Service, as indicated by the abolition of the Professional Employment Office; the closure of CES temporary services, for example, Templine; the assistance from the CES in filling private agency jobs; the decision no longer to collect CES statistics; and the encroachment of the private sector on to areas that are normally CES responsibilities? If there is not such a concerted program, can the Minister provide an explanation of the Government's intention, having regard to the very serious concern being expressed by employees of this organisation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have noted the various points that were made, some of which certainly reflect the changes that have been made to the Commonwealth Employment Service. I think it would be wrong to suggest that the Government is trying to weaken the CES in any way. In fact, a lot of resources have been directed to the improvement and enlargement of the CES in an attempt to make it an up to date employment agency, one that is able to enter very freely into job placement, the matching of people with the jobs that are available, and in general giving the assistance for which the CES has always been noted. I will refer to the Minister any points in the question that require specific information. I state again that the efforts that have been made to improve and modernise the facilities and resources of the CES give a very strong impression that it is the Government's wish that it should be a strong and vibrant organisation that can direct assistance to those who seek its services.
—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Defence say whether the Government recognises the strategic importance of South Africa from a defence and minerals point of view?

—It is true that South Africa provides to the world a very considerable amount of minerals and therefore that must be taken notice of in any survey by any government. It is true that geographically South Africa is situated on a corner of a series of oceans which give it a strategic position. I take it that on both of those counts the Government takes note of both of those factors.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Did the Prime Minister consult him about the staff entitlements granted to the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine? Is it a fact that the Democrats were informed of their staff allocation in a letter from the Deputy Leader of the National Country Party? What did this matter have to do with the National Country Party? Does the Minister know why the Prime Minister appears to have by-passed him and the Liberal Minister for Administrative Services?

—I draw from recollection and I speak from the basis that staffing is not a responsibility of mine; it is the responsibility of the Minister for Administrative Services. Perhaps my colleague who represents that Minister may add to what I say. In general terms I would not be consulted. I recall that early on I was part of a discussion with regard to the Australian Democrats. Because they happened to be five in number, as was the membership of the Democratic Labor Party, my instinct was that they should be given the same facilities as were given to the DLP. I recall having had some conversation on that, but not necessarily at a direct official level-perhaps simply in conversation. It is not my recollection that I have had any discussion regarding the staffing of Senator Harradine. I would have taken the view that the staffing arrangements for all members of both chambers would come under the responsible Minister. I have no knowledge of the Leader of the House in another place having had any communications on the subject. Perhaps Senator Baume has information that I do not have.

—I do have some information regarding the staffing allocated to Senator Harradine, although it may not cover all the points raised by Senator Primmer. I am aware that Senator Harradine wrote to the Government in December 1980 seeking reclassification of the person holding his third position. He gave a number of reasons why this might be supported. The matter was considered by the Government and a decision on Senator Harradine's request was taken by the Government. In late February the Prime Minister, on behalf of the Government, wrote to Senator Harradine informing him of the Government's decision on this matter. I think that is the reason why the letter came from the Prime Minister. I understand that the Minister for Administrative Services followed that up with another letter at a later date giving details of the arrangements. I do not have any information relating to the Australian Democrats or their entitlements.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. I have watched with interest the activities of the baseline air pollution station since its inception at Cape Grim. Can the Minister say what the station has now achieved in its role as a monitor of air purity, or lack of it? Can the Minister give the Senate an assurance that the station's role will in no way be diminished by being contracted out, as required by the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that a global network of stations has been formed to monitor atmospheric conditions and that the station at Cape Grim is one of those stations. I understand that it will monitor a whole range of atmospheric pollution, both natural pollution and that introduced by man. The station has been managed by the Department of Science and Technology while the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has carried out some of the technical part of the monitoring. I am also advised that all the monitoring procedures, with the exception of one, have been put in place. I think that was for the monitoring of sulphur dioxide levels. It was still to be put in place.

ANSWER.PARA: Following the decision to which Senator Archer refers, a number of firms were invited to tender and express their interest in taking on this operation. Nine organisations have expressed interest and the input from those nine is now being examined in detail with a view to evaluating them within the Department of Administrative Services. No decision will be taken until that evaluation is complete. I believe Senator Archer can rest assured that the monitoring program for which Cape Grim is established will continue without any diminution of its effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, may I make a personal explanation? I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Can you give some indication of the area?
—It is with regard to a publication, the Journal of Advanced Education, and statements made therein this week.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most recent copy of the Journal of Advanced Education, dated 28 October 1981, came to my office today. On its front page is a photograph of myself and a very inappropriate headline, linked with that photograph, which I claim misrepresents me and, I believe, the Senate. The headline states: 'More attacks on colleges'. The article refers to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts inquiry into academic tenure. That headline implies to the readers employed in advanced education colleges around Australia, and to other people, that the current inquiry of the Senate Committee into academic tenure has some motivation springing from Government decisions that appear to be cutting back or in any sense attacking the colleges. I only want to say that all the members of the Senate Standing Committee endorsed the suggestion that the matter should come to this Senate for referral to us. It was the Senate that formally gave us that reference. In the prior discussion of the possible reference of this matter of academic tenure I had no consultations whatsoever with Government Ministers, nor is the inquiry in any way linked with Government decisions. I believe that when a headline such as this is published, it may mislead members of the public to believe that there is a prior motivation unworthy of the Senate in taking on such an inquiry. I only want to make the statement that it is a bona fide inquiry which will be carried out in the same manner as Senate inquiries. I add very briefly on the same subject that the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations-FAUSA-some weeks ago made a similar allegation in talking about the knives now being out for academic tenure. But I was able to speak with the Secretary of FAUSA and he acknowledged that he had no basis for making such statements and he has apologised for them. It is unfortunate that these, as it were, two industrial bodies representing staffs in colleges and staffs in universities have muddied the waters with this questioning of the motivations of a Senate committee.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Haines proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Federal Government to ensure the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women in Australia.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, notwithstanding anything contained in the sessional orders, Senator Martin be permitted to speak for 20 minutes on the matter of public importance if required.
The effect of this motion is to enable each of the three honourable senators listed to speak in the discussion to speak for 20 minutes.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot express my delight enough when my proposal for a discussion of a matter of importance is preceded by such a generous motion moved by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) in extending--
—Don't kid yourself. It was wrung out like blood from a stone.

—I accept the Minister's gesture in the spirit that I am sure it was intended and I am delighted that Senator Martin will have the same length of time to speak that Senator Ryan and I will have. This matter of sexual discrimination is particularly serious. Sexual discrimination is defined as discrimination on the grounds of sex alone-that is, that generally women are precluded from or have their access to such things as politics, education, employment and general community activity cut simply because of their sex. It is a problem which has been concerning women publicly, certainly since the suffragette movement in Britain at the turn of the century but for a lot longer than that, and it is a problem that we have not yet solved completely. Despite all the efforts of the women's movement in Australia over the last decade, despite the activities and lobbying of women's groups as widely diverse as the Women's Electoral Lobby and the National Council of Women and despite the fact that there is probably no intellectual or biological reason why women should be treated by society as second rate citizens in a country, allegedly anyway, as advanced and civilised as our own, the fact still remains that there is a vast amount of both overt and covert discrimination against women in the work force, in the home, in education, in business and in the community generally in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a situation in which we have one group of jobs which are acceptable for women. We have another group of jobs for men. We have one sort of life aims which are traditionally acceptable for women and another group of life aims that are acceptable for men. We have one set of educational norms that are generally taken up by women and another group that is taken up by men. We have one set of expectations for women and quite another set for men. That situation is intolerable on both counts since it precludes both men and women from engaging in all activities which make life worth living-activities that extend our personality and develop us as human beings. It is now some six years since we celebrated, if I might use that word, International Women's Year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of us did.

—Some of us did, said Senator Ryan. I agree that some of us did and some of us have been trying to celebrate it ever since. Certainly some of us have been trying to continue the activities that were begun in March six years ago. Yet it seems to me that we are no closer to achieving many of the things which that year was desigend to achieve than we were then. The reason I contend this is that the barriers to achieving equality for women are as much attitudinal ones as they are legal ones, particularly in a country like Australia. To illustrate this point-this rather subterranean restraint that exists on women-I would like to refer to the opening paragraph of a paper by Elizabeth Fennema on the problems facing girls and women in the area of education. She began her thesis with a somewhat whimsical comparison between the general attitude towards women in the United States of America and the specific attitude expressed towards a new one dollar coin when it was introduced in the United States. I think this is an appropriate analogy to draw in respect of this country as well. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: A few years ago, a new coin was put anto circulation in the U.S. The coin was worth one dollar and had on it a likeness of Susan B. Anthony, an early leader in the suffrage movement for women in the U.S. She was the first real woman to be featured on any U.S. currency. Before it was issued, the following comments appeared in a national newsletter.
Like women generally, the coin could be said to represent cheap labor. The Treasury regarded it as a less expensive substitute for the paper dollar which is less durable.
It is smaller than the traditional silver dollar.
It is less esteemed. . .
It is service-oriented. . .
Its employment is seen by banks and merchants as a problem. The coin was not generally accepted by the business and working world and is currently utilized infrequently.

Elizabeth Fennema went on to make the point that many of the remarks made about the coin are equally attributable to women and that in fact women, and their work outside the home in particular, are less esteemed, more service-orientated, their employment is seen as a problem, they are seldom found in the higher status and/or well paid jobs. She said that the reasons for this are many and varied, deeply rooted in the mores of each society and far beyond what can be addressed in her paper. They certainly go too far to deal with in the time I have in this discussion today. Nevertheless, the paper does make the point that women in Australian society and in society in America are still tainted with what amounts to a slave caste aura and that this is due almost entirely to discriminatory attitudes which are buried deep in the mores of our society. It is in fact all the more appalling that the present Government apparently refuses to acknowledge that fact, or if it does acknowledge it, is not doing anything in particular at the moment to rectify it.

We are half way through the decade for women. I wonder how much further into the decade we will have to go before the Federal Government is prepared to pass at this level, and not just leave it to the States, an equal opportunities Bill. Some States have that sort of legislation but of course it applies only in those States. I suggest that we will be waiting until Doomsday for the Western Australian and Queensland governments to introduce legislation granting women equal rights under State laws. Of course, Federal government laws affect women in only those jobs falling within Federal government jurisdiction but they will help if only in a fairly limited way.

I would like to make the point particularly in view of the Minister's extreme kindness at the beginning of this discussion that I am not saying that this Government has never in the past done anything to rectify discrimination against women or that it is being malicious in its slowness, in its tardiness in doing anything now. Last Wednesday I was prepared to congratulate the Government on recognising in its Domicile Act the situation relating to women in Australia, that the need for them to have independence of domicile was important and that the situation which existed prior to last Wednesday was quite out of kilter with modern social mores. I congratulated the Government then on its action in that regard and I congratulate it again now. But the major problem is not one that can simply be overcome by legal means.

The Government will have to face the fact that many of the problems associated with sex discrimination in Australia are attitudinal ones and that it will have to do something in that regard as well as closing legal loopholes. It could start, for instance, by ratifying the 1979 United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. It could, as a petition read out earlier today requested, take back from the States control over the funding and oversighting of women's shelters, rape crisis centres and so on. It could acknowledge that women have to be encouraged to undertake certain educational courses, particularly in view of the technological change which is occurring in this country, and certain career paths that they have not previously been encouraged to do because those paths have been seen traditionally as male areas of interest and ability.

The ratification of the United Nations Convention to which I referred would cause the Government to take all those other steps. In doing so it would be doing nothing more than bringing this country into line with a number of European countries which operate positive campaigns to see that women are given equal opportunities in the work force and in education. It may be of interest to honourable senators to know that Sweden, Belgium, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Austria and Norway all encourage the diversification of women in the paid work force. Not only have these countries undertaken legislative measures designed to help women break out of the low pay, low status, low satisfaction, low job security occupations, but also many of them have embarked on expensive, extensive and positive educational campaigns aimed at showing women just what their potential is and how they can best fulfil it in the labour force. It is extremely unfortunate, it seems to me, for this country as a whole and the 51 per cent of its population which is female that Australia is not prepared to make full use of the talents of women. Clearly the countries that I mentioned, whether they are signatories to the Convention or not and whether they have ratified it or not, are operating according to the spirit of that Convention and in some cases of course they are operating it to the letter.

The Convention is a long one. It contains some 30 articles which it sees as providing a solution to problems besetting half the world's population. It is an extremely comprehensive document. The preamble at the beginning of the convention states that it:

. . . reflects the depth of the exclusion and restriction practised against women solely on the basis of their sex, by calling for equal rights for women, regardless of their marital status in all fields-political, economic, social, cultural and civil.

It calls for national legislation to ban discrimination and recommends temporary special measures to speed equality in fact between men and women and action to modify social and cultural patterns that perpetuate discrimination. Other measures contained in the convention provide for equal rights for women in political and public life, equal access to education and the same choice of curricula. It calls for non-discrimination in employment and pay and guarantees of job security in the event of marriage and maternity, a fact which would no doubt be of some interest to the women in Broken Hill. It also stresses the social services needed, especially child care facilities, for combining family obligations with work responsibilities and participation in public life and, interestingly enough, it underlines the equal responsibilities it sees men having with women in the context of family life. It goes on in considerably more detail to cover a number of other things, including the particular problems facing women in rural areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no mention in there, is there, Senator, of equal rights for women who have to do women's work in the house like washing the napkins and all that, as well as going to work?
—Indeed there you are wrong.
—They have to work for a very low rate of pay.
—I am sorry, but the honourable senator is wrong, not that that is abnormal for him. But he is wrong.
—I know many women who work and don't get paid for it. They do that work for nothing.

—The argument put forward in this Convention is as much for status as it is for pay. I agree that it is high time that the status of women working in the home was recognised as being equal with anything outside. If their husbands do not choose to acknowledge it, that is something that I suggest the honourable senator takes up with the men concerned. Having indicated to the honourable senator what the basis of the convention is, it is apparent that in some areas Australia already complies with it. But in many ways it does not, and the most serious problem is the attitudinal one. This is the one which leads to and perpetuates--
—They don't get paid.

—If the honourable senator is really cut up about this problem, I suggest that he asks that his name be attached to the end of the speaking list and then he can make the only male contribution to the debate. Otherwise, I suggest he let me get on with what I am saying.
—Back benchers cannot get equal rights in this debate.
—We were excluded.

—The honourable senator was not excluded by me. The most serious of the barriers facing women is the one which leads to and perpetuates the problem of women who want to break free of the limited range of careers and job opportunities which have previously or up to now at least been available to women. I make that qualification because many of the traditionally female occupations will not be accessible to women in the next few years. The advances in technology in the Australian work force are hitting hardest at women and it is the majority of women who are clustered into that very small range of jobs, in clerical and assembly line work, the very ones, I contend, which are most susceptible to technological change. Before anybody in this chamber chooses to point out that technological change will create jobs, I point out that the jobs which are created will not be suitable for the women made redundant by the technological changes. In fact, they will not be particularly suitable to many women in the community as the majority of women are not educated to take up the sort of scientific work which is involved.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer honourable senators to page 34 of today's Australian newspaper which contains an advertisement which indicates quite clearly how firm a hold educational and occupational stereotypes have on employers and the community generally. It is an advertisement taking up something like one-third of the page. It is headed: 'Satellite communications and jobs for the boys'. On the right hand side it has a substantial photograph of a rather angelic looking boy of about seven years. I do not want to give the advertisers any free publicity so I will not mention their identity, but the advertisement states:
Young Australians have the right to learn the skills this new industry--
The communications industry-
Offers and to share in its growth.

Clearly the industry concerned considers that the only young Australians who really do have the right to learn and to be involved in this new and growing industry are males. This is the sort of thing which should be actively discouraged by the Federal Government as it serves only to cement outmoded social traditions concerning women.

A more serious question arises, however, for the women, those hardy souls, who do manage to break through the barrier of male-dominated employment areas. What happens to them when they do break through? All too frequently the women concerned are faced with what is to me a contemptible fact of life that in order to get on in and to get on with their job they have to put up with resentment and antagonism from their male colleagues. This has a number of effects. It occurs, of course, in different areas and to different women in different jobs in different ways. It can vary from being passed over for promotion, because it is assumed by management that the woman does not need the money as much as a male colleague, or some other equally irrelevant reason, to actual sexual harassment. The latter, of course, can again come in many forms, varying from the telling of off-colour jokes to in fact actually making sexual intercourse with the boss a condition of promotion or of keeping the job itself.

It is one of the hardest forms of discrimination for anyone to combat since it usually comes down to one person's word against another or to the fact that the woman concerned is made to feel dirty, guilty, somehow to blame for what has happened to her and certainly too embarrassed to tell anyone. It is exacerbated by the fact that some forms of harassment are still considered socially acceptable and passed off either as jokes or as compliments which a woman is too churlish to accept or to see. The women who complain are ridiculed and dismissed as having no sense of humour or as being radicals or lesbians, or, for that matter, all three. In the last minute of my speech as an example I bring to the Senate's attention a situation of sexual harassment which, ironically enough, occurred in the Defence Research Centre at Salisbury in South Australia. To save time in explaining the matter, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a letter that the woman concerned wrote to Dr Gail Radford.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has this action the approval of the woman concerned?
—Yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
19th January, 1981 Dr Gail Radford,
Assistant Commissioner,
Equal Opportunities Office,
Australian Public Service Board,
McLachlan Offices,
National Circuit,
BARTON,
Dear Gail,
SEXUAL HARASSMENT

I have been employed as a Public Servant since 8th March 1971 when I started work at The Weapons Research Establishment under the Department of Supply. With restructuring my place of employment is now The Defence Research Centre Salisbury under The Department of Defence. My Australian Government Staff number is 235 60094; my Third Division seniority date is 3rd October 1973.
I have set out below several complaints arising from an incident which occurred on 10th November 1980 at work. Would you please help/advise me?

On the afternoon of 10th November 1980 at work I was working in my office in building 21 labs in the capacity of Technical Officer 1 with the Data Reduction Section of Rocket Propulsion Group of Propulsion Division. I was returning a handkerchief to my bag hung on a hook behind the door of the office. Peter Drake a Technical Assistant from the same building rushed into my office and, without conversing, grabbed my left breast. I scolded him, thumped him and chastised with ''I will grab you'' while making a cupping motion towards his chest, where upon he raised both arms in the air and replied ''Please, please''.

Several times that afternoon he returned to my office and embarrassed me. For example he later handed me a wrapped article. On unwrapping I found underwear which Peter told me came from a London sex shop. When I passed him in the corridor later I held up a folder to my chest and Peter said, ''No, you only get it once a year''. The next morning Peter was still harassing me. At about 9.45 a.m. while walking to a computer centre I passed Peter Drake driving to a parking place. On noticing me he took both hands off the steering wheel and made a double cupping motion.

Peter Drake has frequently sexually harassed me. The first occasion I remember was his comment, ''Careful, they'll wobble'', probably back in 1971. The intensity and style of taunting has varied. On occasions he cupped a hand at me, or stood at my office door and told dirty jokes, or frequently inquired if I was wearing a bra, or handed me pornographic magazines or sexually orientated books, and twice asked me to stay weekends with him at Victor Harbor both of which I refused.

Eventually I told our supervisor Delwyn Carson, who thought that if I feigned lack of embarrassment the matter would resolve. It did not. I tried walking away from him, not talking to him for days and avoiding his office unless work made it necessary but he did not stop the harassment. I complained again to the supervisor who passed it off with the comment that he acts like that towards her also.

On 11th November, 1980 I handed a letter of complaint to the Principal Officer, Bill Bradfield outlining the problem. A copy of the letter is enclosed. He was unhelpful.
