Between 11th November 1980 and 1st December, 1980 Bill Bradfield's comments included: That is Peter Drake's ways; you have over-emphasized; you are too sensitive; that is how men greet women; he has not been offensive to me; he was only giving you a present when he flung his arms around you; what is wrong with a gift of underwear; it is only your word against his; you can be sued for libel; you have slandered Delwyn; you won't dare take this any further; if you take this further I will have you demoted.

Bill said that Peter remembered in 1978 being chastised by me on touching my bottom. This does not tally with Peter's statements that he did not know that he had offended me, and did not know what was offensive to me. Another ambiguity is apparent in a postcard sent by Peter in 1980, a copy of which is enclosed. The wording on the card make it very clear that Peter Drake knew exactly what reaction it would receive.

My Union (ADSTE) the welfare officer and personnel were then contacted and I was temporarily moved to building 75 with different Rocket Propulsion personnel. Bill Bradfield had stated that I could not continue my work in the nearby building so the Chief Superintendent, Jim Crompton was arranging my transfer elsewhere.

On 27th November 1980, Bill Bradfield arranged a lunchtime interview with me in a locked office, and among other things told me to resume working in building 21 on the following Monday, and asked for my decision before the afternoon was over on his request for my resignation.

A lesser example of non-co-operation involves Tom French of Personnel who told me that Peter Drake would be disciplined on all of the charges (including molesting which occurred without a third person present) or not at all. I enquired why he could not be disciplined on the proven sexual harassment, but the question was parried. I believe on 15th January 1981 Drake had not been disciplined.

On 13th December 1980 I discovered that all of my data sets stored on the IBM computer had been taken away from me. I had not been informed of this action. A computer Services person told me that Delwyn Carson had arranged it. It is possible that other persons were also involved to give the necessary authority. One reason given for the action was the security risk yet I had been cleared to do the work initially, the work was not considered at risk to warrant password protection, and also some data sets were plagiarized from universal IBM manuals and not at risk. Another reason given was that Delwyn was afraid that I would corrupt the data sets. If my data sets were needed by Rocket Propulsion Group copying could have been arranged through myself or Computer Services. Denying me access to my work impedes future work. It also prevents publication of two technical memoranda, the drafts of which I stored on computer, and thus decreases promotional prospects.

On 4th December, after acting as TO1 since 7th March 1978 the higher duties were taken away and I was reduced to my substantive level as a TO2. Earlier I studied an internal course in rocketry until the course was eliminated. Considering this I was informed that a decision was made in Canberra enabling me to stay as a TO1 permanently. Could you check the validity of this? Since then the possibility of losing higher duties was not mentioned to me prior to my written complaint. I acted as a TO1 for two years and eight months, received increments and am not aware of any inability to perform at that level. I am currently employed below my capabilities.

During November 1980 I learnt that I was inappropriately classified in the technical grades. The computing emphasis was more suited to a programming assistant grade. I learnt that Peter George, Principal Officer of Ionospheric Studies Group required a PA3 and, although he thought I was the best applicant, I was not permitted to take up the job. PA3 is on a par with TO1. I was told to report on 4th December 1980 as a Technical Assistant 2 (a reduction of $45.85 gross per fortnight) with Aerodynamics Group.
I am told that Delwyn Carson as well as Peter Drake are considering sueing me with libel.

The stress has affected my health. I have suffered from recurring diarrohea and headaches and my hair has started to fall out. I took sick leave between 4th December and 14th December 1980 and then used my recreation leave which started on 24th December to give myself time to recuperate. Despite the respite from work I am still suffering the effects of stress and continuing to bald.

I believe that the coincidence of events surrounding the recent change in the nature and status of my work has been a direct result of my action in submitting a written complaint about the sexual harassment I have been subjected to by a fellow staff member. Not only has my health been affected by the pressure placed on me by my superior officers but I now feel unable to return to my previous position even if it were to become available. I understand that the Public Service Board is able to act in cases involving sexual harassment, and I seek your assistance in redressing the wrong which I believe has been perpetrated against me.
Yours sincerely,

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The letter details a rather sorry tale of harassment of the woman concerned by a male colleague which culminated in her being demoted, having had her protestations ignored by her superiors, and then having to stand back and watch the harasser accept promotion into her position.
—Order! I am afraid that the honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the matter of public importance introduced this afternoon by Senator Haines. I am very pleased that she has introduced this subject for discussion because, as she said, it is a most serious subject indeed. I think that the signing of international conventions by Australian governments is a matter of great importance to the Parliament. The failure of this particular Government to take any substantial action following its signing, in Copenhagen in 1980, of the United Nations Convention outlawing all forms of discrimination against women is something to be deplored.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset I endorse some of the remarks made by Senator Haines to the effect that we are not saying that the Federal Government actively discriminates against women or even, indeed, actively opposes any progress in this area. But that is not enough. The Fraser Government has signed an international Convention but it has failed to ratify that Convention even though it has now been ratified by other countries. It has failed to take any steps in its own country to ensure that the provision of that Convention, which it was very happy to sign in Copenhagen last year and about which it made a great fuss in the media, are being implemented in this country.

I remind honourable senators that, as of 3 September 1981, the United Nations Convention for the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women came into force after having been ratified by the requisite 20 countries. I say that it is a matter of great shame that Australia was not one of those countries that ratified the Convention. The first process in bringing the international Convention into force is the signing of that Convention. The Australian Government did that. The second step which brings about the implementation of the Convention and brings it into force in international forums is the ratification of the Convention. Of course, the Australian Government has failed to do that. I think the reason it has failed to do that is the reason the Fraser Government fails to do so many things in the area of human rights and progressive legislation. That is the reluctance, or in some cases the hostility of certain conservative State governments within this country, to act accordingly.

If the Australian Government is to ratify the United Nations Convention, it must ensure and guarantee in international forums that all laws within Australia are in accord with that Convention. Of course, that means that laws in the States of Western Australia, Queensland, as well as all the other States, must be in accord with that Convention. The States of Tasmania, South Australia and New South Wales provide no particular difficulty. In the case of New South Wales and South Australia, anti-discrimination legislation and equal opportunity machinery have been in effect for some years. Tasmania is on the verge of such action. In the Northern Territory, a private members Bill was introduced by the former Opposition Leader in the Northern Territory, John Isaacs, to provide for this. But, of course, in the States of Western Australia and Queensland there is absolutely no intention to legislate to outlaw discrimination against women as required by the international Convention.

Not only is the obstacle provided by those States obstructing progress in their own States but also it is obstructing Federal progress. If the Federal Government were to be prepared to enact Federal anti-discrimination legislation, I believe, and many constitutional experts believe, that that legislation would apply in those States where no such legislation existed. The Federal Government would have overriding power and Federal legislation would provide some protection to women in the States of Western Australia and Queensland. But, of course, the Federal Government, as ever, full of good intentions and full of fine words is reluctant to stand up to these reactionary anti-progress States and is reluctant to force the issue. I believe that that is why we do not have anti-discrimination legislation throughout this country. I believe that is why the Australian Government has failed so shamefully to ratify the international Convention.

Another matter arose from the Copenhagen conference and the signing of that Convention. That concerns the matter of a national plan of action to achieve equality for Australian women over a 10-year period. Honourable senators will recall that again, very unfortunately I believe, the Australian Government failed to vote for the world plan of action at Copenhagen because of political matters which really had nothing to do with the status of women.

TALK.START.PARA: —But who raised the political matters? Not the Australian Government. The Soviet Union raised them.

—Senator Martin will have the opportunity to place her view on what happened. In my view and in the view of the Australian Labor Party, there was no true or ultimate impediment to the Australian Government's voting in favour of the world plan of action.
—They corrupted the motion by what they added.
—I do not defend any attempt to bring irrelevant political matters into that debate.
—We agree.

—We did not wish them to be brought in. They were brought in against our wishes and the wishes of the Government. I do not believe that there was an ultimate obstacle to showing some sort of support for the world plan of action. Indeed, I was pleased to see that the Australian Government did to some extent retreat from its Copenhagen position when the matter came before the Third Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.
—What did it do?
—Senator Martin was there. I hope that we will have the benefit of her very detailed experience when she speaks.
—You made the allegation of retreat.
—I understand that the Australian Government did not press outright opposition in the Third Committee but abstained.
—It abstained.

—That is my understanding. I am very pleased that Senator Martin, who was there at the time, agrees with me. The Australian Government nonetheless offered to have an Australian plan of action which would be its commitment to equality for Australian women over the next 10 years. Where is that plan of action? Why have we not seen it? Many months have passed since that Copenhagen conference and since that commitment was made. I believe that the plan of action is with the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson), who is the responsible Minister. We are still waiting for any squeak out of that Minister as to his intention with regard to this plan. Given the snail's pace activity which is characteristic of that Minister, I think we will be waiting for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator Haines that the matter of social change, of changing people's prejudices and expectations about the proper role of men and women in Australia is a long and difficult process. Indeed, some of the interjections that Senator Haines had to endure demonstrate just how slow social change can be. I agree as she said that attitudinal change is required.

I make the point now in some detail that, although matters of attitudinal change are fundamental and important to all of us who believe in these forms of equality, there are serious practical economic consequences of inequality. We are not just engaged in an academic debate about equality. We are not just engaged in a sociological debate about attitudinal change. Why I, on behalf of the Federal Labor Party, choose to support this matter raised by Senator Haines is that there are very dire economic consequences to this country because of inequality. There are women living in poverty and there are families supported by women living in poverty because of discrimination. That is of fundamental concern to the Labor Party. That is the main reason for my enthusiasm in supporting Senator Haines today.

I think it is really a matter of hypocrisy that the Government on the one hand is prepared to sign this international Convention eliminating all forms of discrimination against women and, on the other hand, through its policies, relentlessly pursues a decline in the economic circumstances of Australian women. The Fraser Government mouths the rhetoric of equality for women while promoting economic and administrative policies which contribute to the growth of inequality.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does that sort of thing about everything.

—Indeed, as Senator Walsh says, women are not singled out for this treatment. However, they are the subject of our debate this afternoon. For example, the number of women who have been forced into permanent economic dependency on the state through the Fraser Government's economic policies is alarmingly high and growing. The Fraser Government consistently has attacked the living standards of low income earners, the majority of whom are women. Almost two thirds of those who now rely on social security benefits for the major portion of their income are women.

SPEECH.PARA: The single most important factor in determining income levels and therefore living standards for any Australian is access to employment. Not only has the job market declined in line with the Fraser Government's policies but also women's access to the job market has declined. Women's unemployment, particularly female youth unemployment, has grown under the Fraser Government. I do not want to burden the Senate with too many statistics. I simply say that the current measured rate of female youth unemployment is 18.3 per cent and that the current measured rate of adult female unemployment is 7.1 per cent. Of course, that is only the measured rate. Some economists, such as Margaret Power of Sydney University, have suggested that if we measured the hidden unemployed-that is, those women and girls who are not registered as unemployed-we could double those rates. I believe that my colleague Senator Sibraa, who spends a lot of his time in rural areas of New South Wales, where the problem is even worse, would endorse that extrapolation by Margaret Power.

When we pass to the area of migrant women we find much higher rates of unemployment for both young and adult migrant women. When we pass to the area of Aboriginal women, as my colleague Senator Coleman would endorse, the situation is infinitely worse.

Why has there been such a growing rate of women's unemployment? First, and this is a very fundamental problem, there is the inadequacy and unavailability of child care. Senator Chaney, the Minister for Social Security, recently proposed that a universal means test be imposed so as to restrict the application of the child care subsidy to the very needy. On the face of it, that might sound like a sensible use of restricted resources but I reject that policy completely. I believe that it will have the effect of making quality publicly funded child care more expensive and therefore less accessible to the majority of women who, although in need of child care assistance, are in receipt of low incomes but not on pensions and therefore unable to qualify for the extremely needy category that Senator Chaney is apparently considering.

Another problem is the Government's decision to abolish a large number of jobs in the public sector which, of course, represents a high area of women's employment. The last Budget contained cuts to Public Service staff ceilings to the extent of a further 3 per cent. This will result in the destruction of about 9,000 jobs in the public sector. Many of those will be women's jobs. An example was brought up in the Senate last night-that of the cleaners who are to be sacked from the Public Service. Of course, many of them are women-women who, I might point out, because of the kinds of factors to which Senator Haines has referred, have not had the opportunity of gaining the skills and experience that will enable them to compete for other jobs in this very restricted job market.

There has also been a destruction of jobs in traditional areas of women's employment, such as clerical, service and sales areas, through technological change and structural change in the economy brought about by the resources boom. Of course, there will be some new jobs in areas associated with high technology and resource development, but traditionally very few women have been able to obtain employment in those areas. I suggest that the Government has failed completely to respond to this problem. Whereas, training programs that are specifically designed to qualify women for work in the resources areas are needed, the Government's training measures will exclude women further.

For example, since 1975 Government spending on employment and training has fallen in real terms by 44 per cent. The majority of training programs that the Government has funded have not been based on the fundamental manpower principle of channelling people away from areas where there is unemployment and into areas where there is a demand for labour. Rather those programs have simply been employer subsidy kinds of schemes. Their aim has not been the retraining of women displaced through technological change.

Recently I pointed out to the Senate that more than $1m was being spent by the Department of Defence to bring from Britain engineers, technical officers and other skilled personnel, while in Australia young women could not get jobs. Of some thousands of engineers, draughtspeople, naval architects, technical officers and trainees employed by the Department of Defence, less than a dozen are women-less than 12 of all the thousands of jobs in the Department of Defence are occupied by women.

The Defence Force also implements employment policies which discriminate against women. Women are still not accepted as officer cadets at the Royal Military College, Duntroon, and on current plans will not be accepted at Casey University when it opens either. This is a case-I refer specifically to the Department of Defence-not only of a Government failing to ensure the elimination of discrimination against women but also of one of its departments upholding blatantly discriminatory policies.

Much of the increase in Government expenditure on training in the last Budget is directed towards the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training Scheme. Since 90 per cent of apprentices are males, women will get minimal benefit from this expenditure. The increased Budget allocation for skills in short supply will also go mostly to males, because the areas of need are not traditional areas of female employment. There are no legislative mechanisms, indeed no Government policies, to ensure that women get equal access to these schemes.

When we turn to the area of education, which is so vital if we are to ensure equal opportunity for women, we find equally discriminatory polices advanced by the Government. In association with the lack of job training opportunities, the Government is putting obstacles in the way of women who seek access to tertiary education. Part of the Government's Budget package was the imposition of fees for second and higher degrees. Women who have spent some years out of the work force raising children are much more likely to need to upgrade or update their qualifications, or to take a second or higher degree to prepare for the job market. They are much less likely than are men to find themselves in any of the fees exempt categories outlined by the Minister and I believe, certainly many vice-chancellors and staff associations believe, that the ultimate effect will be to force out those mature age women students who will simply not be able to pay fees.

If other areas, such as health or taxation, are looked at, the picture of discrimination against women, which is perpetuated and promoted by the Fraser Government's policies, is repeated. The key to breaking the cycle of disadvantage lies in ensurang that women have adequate income levels. A comparison of male and female income levels provides clear evidence of the extent to which discrimination still exists and of the Government's failure to redress it.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions Working Women's Centre has just compiled a review of equal pay based on figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. This shows that more women work part time than do men, that women perform less overtime than men and are paid less for it on average, and that women are less likely to get over-award payments or bonuses. As of March 1979, women made up only 8 per cent of the full time managerial and executive employees, although women make up 37 per cent of the work force. Moreover, the review shows that the majority of women workers are concentrated in a small range of jobs-clerical and secretarial work, teachers, nurses, waitresses, cleaners, factory workers, shop assistants and telephone operators. As honourable senators know, these jobs are mostly low paid, have a high labour turnover and present few opportunities for advancement. Moreover, even within the female dominated areas of employment, men are paid more than women.

The Budget figures on the taxable incomes of males and females for 1980-81 show that while 90 per cent of men earn less than $30,000 per annum, about 90 per cent of women earn less than $15,000 per annum. Some 55 per cent of women who pay tax have incomes of less than $10,000, compared with 27 per cent of men, and a quarter of all women who pay tax have incomes of less than $7,000 per annum. This is the case despite the fact that in 1973 the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission awarded an equal pay decision.

Therefore it is not just a matter-and here again I must agree with Senator Haines-of simply getting the awards and the legislation right. Other steps must be taken-positive training steps, positive encouragement and equal opportunity policies-if this area of discrimination is to be effectively redressed. Consistently, the Government has failed to implement policies which would challenge this basic economic inequality. In fact, the Government's policies have reinforced and promoted inequality.

If the Government wishes seriously to pursue the elimination of discrimination it must adopt policies and enact legislation, such as Federal anti-discrimination legislation, which will attack institutionalised discrimination in Australia. The Government ought to do a number of things if it is serious in its signing of that international Convention. They are, as I said, the enactment of Federal anti-discrimination legislation to provide equal opportunity throughout the whole area of Commonwealth public employment; the insistence that State governments enact parallel legislation or, otherwise, respond to Federal legislation; the public endorsement of a plan of action for Australia; and, finally, the allocation of appropriate funds to ensure that the matter of equal opportunity and the elimination of discrimination does not remain merely a matter of rhetoric in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two interesting speeches have been made this afternoon. We have heard from women senators the attitude of the Australian Democrats, I take it, and the attitude of the Australian Labor Party towards the subject of discrimination against women. I should say at this stage that the objectives of those two parties and the Government parties are not vastly different. Senator Ryan's speech pointed out the difference in how we would achieve those things. We can debate the value of modus operandi; however, we have to go a little further than that. There has to be some taking to task, certainly, of Senator Ryan for her mis-statements during her speech in relation to Government actions and attitudes towards a range of issues. Notably, she raised the subject of our ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.

SPEECH.PARA: At the beginning I say that, in a sense, it is impossible to debate the subject sensibly in this chamber as it is worded by Senator Haines. To say that 'the failure of the Federal Government to ensure the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women in Australia' is a matter of public importance seems to indicate that there was some sort of target date and that it should all have been done by now. It is the objective of the Convention on that subject to eliminate all forms of discrimination. But I think the fact that the Convention was signed only last year would indicate to honourable senators that it would not be expected to be done just 12 months later. It is a very large Convention with many articles. Obviously, it will take some time to be put into effect. that is not to apologise if it could be alleged subsequently that the Government was tardy, but in fact the Government is acting. The fact that it has not all happened in 12 months-indeed, it cannot happen in 12 months-does not mean that the Government has failed in its pursuit of the elimination of discrimination against women.

There are four aspects to a debate on our Government's policy and what we have done to do away with discrimination against women. Quite a long story can be told about the things that have been achieved by the Fraser Government, none of which Senator Ryan gave the Government credit for. There are the things that are not yet done, but which are under way and on which statements have been made in this chamber by Ministers, notably by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and also by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) who represents the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson). All of those statements of intention and processes which are under way have been ignored by Opposition speakers in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again.

—Yes, once again. Some things cannot be done by a Commonwealth government but need to be left to State governments to do, if they are to be done at all. In due course I intend to take up Senator Ryan's allegation that because we proceed in a certain way action will not take place. I suggest to her that if we proceeded in her way not only would we not guarantee action, but also we would certainly guarantee reaction and that would not be in the interests of women in Australia. There are certain things which cannot be done by any government but which must be done by society itself and, notably, by women themselves. Both Senator Haines and Senator Ryan touched on those items and I will cover some of the points which they raised and which I think must be put on behalf of the Government in defence of a very strong and, I believe, unwarranted attack on the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Haines started her speech by saying that discrimination exists. I accept that Senator Haines was correct. Discrimination does exist. The other side of the coin is that the Government is working on the subject of discrimination and wants to do away with it. I accept that there are long-standing sources of discrimination; I will not accept that there has been no movement, that we have failed to meet those areas of discrimination and how they disadvantage women in our work force. In the last decade, and as notably under the Fraser Government as under any previous government, extraordinary progress has been made for women in Australia. Also, a decade ago nobody could have foreseen the amount of progress which has been made by 1981. I suggest that that is a result not only of government action, but also of social changes in attitudes of society towards women and its expectations of women, and in attitudes of women, towards women and their expectations of themselves.

I must chide Senator Haines for bringing into the debate, when she was quoting from an article, a tone which I think helps women not at all. She presented a quote in relation to the Susan B. Anthony United States dollar. It is that sort of snitchy, cynical comment that was made in that article which the honourable senator read that does not help women at all. I am not interested in debating the merits--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was an article in a public newspaper.

—I am not interested either in turning the debate into a hen's party. I am not interested in debating the merits of the United States currency but, to put the Susan B. Anthony dollar into its context, it ought to be pointed out that in the entire history of the United States, apart from the obverse side of every coin which depicts one of the great initial national leaders of the United States of America, only three America citizens have ever been honoured to have their faces on a United States coin. Those coins are the Eisenhower dollar which followed World War II, the Kennedy half dollar which followed the assassination of President John Kennedy and the Susan B. Anthony dollar. It does not help to suggest, as that article does, that it is some sort of symbol which enshrines discrimination against women and their poor status in society because Susan B. Anthony struggled against her own poor status and the poor status of women in society. We ought to be reasonable in our judgment. It is a great honour to women that that women's leader in the United States is one of the three citizens of that country ever to be so featured and featured because she was a feminist. I am sure that many honourable senators, particularly Opposition senators, are frustrated at times because governments do not do exactly as they would like them to do. That is not surprising. Sometimes government and opposition agree and sometimes they do not. But if the Government always did what all honourable senators wanted, we would all be in the same political party. There would be one party in Australia. In fact, there are differences of attitude.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Haines raised the subject of an equal opportunities Bill and said that the Government had been tardy. The Government has announced and is acting upon a sex discrimination ordinance in the Australian Capital Territory, which is its initial area of jurisdiction. The objective of that ordinance, as stated by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment is 'to proscribe discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status in areas such as employment, education, land, housing and accommodation, and goods, services and facilities, including credit, insurance and superannuation'. That objective would have to please the most ardent feminist. The ordinance will provide for the confidential conciliation of all complaints. A time limit is to be placed on conciliation and, if conciliation fails, a complainant will be able to institute proceedings in a civil court.

It is anticipated that the draft ordinance will be available to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly by the end of this year. Senator Haines may have liked it to go to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly at the beginning of this year. Time does not permit me to outline and my intimate knowledge of the event, because I am not the Minister, would not permit me to guess why it did not go before the House of Assembly earlier this year. But it is being drafted. It is being worked on. The objectives are stated. Action will take place. The fact that it has not happened yet does not mean that the Government has failed-not at all. It means that the Government is moving to cover an area which it has recognised must be covered. I note that Senator Haines said that the Government must face the fact that many of the problems encountered by women are attitudinally based. I think we have all accepted that in the debate. We have also accepted in the course of the debate that there are the two aspects of attitude-the aspect of society's attitude towards women and the aspect of women's attitude towards themselves.

I think it ought to be mentioned somewhere in this debate how far women, in terms of achievement and in terms of attitudinal achievement both in society and on their own part, have come in this place. Prior to the 1974 election there were two women members in the Senate and no women members in the House of Representatives. This year there are 10 women in the Senate out of a total of 64 and three women in the House of Representatives. For the first time ever there is more than one woman member in the House of Representatives. Nobody would have forseen that in 1974 or 1971. That is a measure of attitudinal change.

No longer do political parties give women the unwinnable seats to contest. They are getting the safe seats on some occasions in both the Commonwealth and the State arena. They are getting increasingly the marginal seat because it is recognised by political parties that social attitudes have changed so far that, given a good woman candidate, there is a better chance in many cases of winning a marginal seat. Even 10 years ago it was common for the political attitude on this subject to be expressed as: 'You cannot endorse a woman because women will not vote for women; they are election losers'. The proof of the pudding is in the eating in this case. The fact is that political parties frequently choose to head their Senate tickets with women and they choose to endorse an increasing number of women in seats that are either safe or winnable. That is a recent change.

The fact that women have come forward in greater numbers and have become more assertive about their potential as candidates is also a change. Every woman senator in this chamber would have to agree with me that the greatest barrier to having more women in public life is that good women still inhibit themselves attitudinally even with the proof before them of remarkable success in comparative terms. We have all had the experience of having discussions with women who we think would be very good in public life but who still have an attitude that it is not appropriate for them to put themselves forward. This is changing. More are coming forward, but it cannot be changed by government.

Attitudinal change is a matter of process. It is a process that has accelerated and will go on. I will agree that there are some areas where government can influence attitude and that is in the way it goes about its own business. I would like to come to that matter subsequently. Before my time expires, I want to say a few words on the subject of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. This was raised as being noteworthy by both Senator Ryan and Senator Haines. I regret to tell those two very worthy and very able honourable senators that their comments are, in my opinion, precipitate and not reasonable. Because nothing has happened yet in terms of what they demand does not mean that a process is not under way to bring about the objective they seek, perhaps not in the way they seek it-

TALK.START.PARA: —When?

—Just wait a minute. The honourable senator has been waiting a long time for my speech. Several times during her speech she invited me to speak. I am coming to that. Senator Ryan properly pointed out that there are two ways to implement an international convention. The first one is to become a signatory and the second step is ratification. The process of ratification is under way in Australia. It is not to the shame of the Fraser Government that ratification has not yet taken place-not at all. It is to its credit that it is proceeding in a sensible way which will ensure far more the implementation in real terms of the objective of that Convention than by going about it with a sledge hammer.

SPEECH.PARA: I also have to point out to both Senator Haines and Senator Ryan that the fact that a government ratifies does not necessarily mean that one woman in that country is any better off. Senator Ryan invited me to say a few words about the Copenhagen Conference and I will put them in this context. The fact that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has ratified the Convention does not necessarily mean that one woman in the Soviet Union will be any better off in comparative terms and in terms of discrimination. It is impossible for us to examine in the same way that we can be examined and our governments can be held up to public examination, what is happening in certain countries and to apply any objective yardstick.

There was an interesting incident revolving around a word that led to our not voting for the plan of action in Copenhagen. It should be put on the record that Mrs Beaurepaire, national chairman of the National Women's Advisory Council, in making a statement just before the final vote, said that the Australian Government supported the plan of action and had supported it up to the point where it was so politicised that it was impossible to add our name to it. I say to Senator Ryan that it does Australian women and advocates of women's rights no credit at all to suggest that the Australian Government should have denied its policy towards Israel and the Middle East for the sake of voting yes on that document. The insertion of the word 'zionism', which had nothing to do with the subject of the conference, made it impossible for the Australian Government to vote straight out for that plan of action. But the Government made it clear-as the Press did not-at that conference that it supported the plan of action and would seek to implement it.

I dare say at this stage and make a forecast that it will be implemented in far more worthwhile terms in Australia than it will be in a number of the countries that have already given their nominal ratification to the Convention. When, in the committee stage of that Convention, the word 'zionism' was sought to be inserted Australia sought to insert the word 'sexism'. Senator Ryan might be interested to hear that the Soviet delegates did not know what that word meant. There is no word or phrase in the Russian language that translates to sexism. When it was explained in Russian to the delegate the delegate had to admit that he had never heard of the concept. So much for the women's movement in the Soviet Union! The Soviet Union opposed the insertion of the word 'sexism'.

TALK.START.PARA: —No one is supporting Russia's position.

—I am saying to the honourable senator that because the Soviet Union has ratified the convention it does not mean that women in that country will be any better off; the indications are otherwise. When we ratify, it will mean something and the meaningful process is under way. Any government can slap its signature on something and ratify it if it knows in the back of its mind that it will never be reasonably held up to have to act on it. The ratification process is under way. In Australia we operate under a Federal system of government. That is a fact of political structure. There are certain things that the Commonwealth Government can do and certain things that it cannot do. There are certain things that must be done by State governments. One can argue that under the foreign affairs power the Commonwealth Government could legislate on just about anything-never mind the other provisions of the Constitution-because this Convention was signed in a foreign affairs context. One could certainly argue that.

SPEECH.PARA: But to ram down the throat of State governments issues they have not had the opportunity to debate as to how they might participate if they want to participate will not endear the issues to anyone. Conferences of Attorneys-General, who are the Ministers responsible for human rights in Australia, have been under way and are proceeding. Progress has been made. Certainly, in my opinion, it will be better that the six State governments and the Territory Government at the end of the process are at a point of agreement about what should be done about the elimination of discrimination against women than that we beat them over the head with something they have not yet fully debated. The process is under way. Some agreement has been reached. The process will go on. There have been precedents for that in other areas.

That is the process that the Fraser Government follows and it is a process that leads to results. To suggest, as was done towards the end of Senator Ryan's speech, that the Fraser Government has pursued policies which are anti-women, is nonsense. The record is clear. In a number of areas specifically designed towards women-in boards and other activities within the Public Service and in other areas such as crisis accommodation for families in distress, which has a very particular application to women-the Government has acted in a very positive way and has shown that its attitudes are alive and well and that it intends to extend them. I think this has been a worthwhile debate if only to educate a few of our colleagues in some of the issues that we consider to be important. In accordance with the agreement reached between the Government and the Opposition, I move:
That the business of the day be called on.

BROADCASTING STATIONS LICENCE FEES BILL 1981

This Bill and the Television Stations Licence Fees Bill 1981, which I will introduce soon, propose to amend the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Act and the Television Stations Licence Fees Act 1964 to vary the basis on which commercial broadcasting and television stations are charged for their use of a limited public resource. Honourable Senators will be aware that those Acts impose fees in the nature of a royalty charge, thus following the practice common to all Governments of ensuring that the public gains some benefit from the commercial utilisation of public resources.
The present Acts provide for a lump sum payment on the original grant of a licence and for a lump sum and a percentage of the gross earnings of the station in respect of each year after the grant.

The Bills propose an increased fee of $500 on the grant of a licence and tying the annual fee simply to a revised percentage of gross earnings. That percentage varies in relation to increases in gross earnings, subject to specified upper limits.

Honourable Senators will be aware that Bills to give effect to these measures, which were announced in the Budget, have previously been considered in the other Place. The present Bills differ from the earlier ones only in imposing an upper limit on the proposed percentage of a station's gross earnings. These limits are:
(a) 5 per cent of gross earnings in the case of broadcasting stations; and
(b) 7.5 per cent of gross earnings in the case of television stations.

The Government has reconsidered these measures and their long-term effects on licencees. It is believed that the principles of the measures should continue, but it is appropriate that a maximum level be set so that the measures will not result in excessive and inequitable continuing increases in the amounts of fees required to be paid.

Licence fees are calculated on the basis of gross earnings of stations. Honourable Senators will be aware that the effects of inflation will inevitably lead to an increase in gross earnings of stations without necessarily a corresponding increase in disposable income. To impose an open ended obligation would steadily increase stations real expenses. Those expenses will have to be recovered from advertising revenues which will increase the costs to advertisers using medium and larger sized stations.

The Government feels that it is equitable to fix upper limits on the percentages applicable. This allows stations to budget with reasonable assurance and requires that the Government take a positive decision to increase the rate of this taxation, thereby giving the Parliament the opportunity to debate the matter on its merits.

The overall level of licence fees and their impact on stations will however be kept under review. The Government has decided to re-examine the whole question by 1984 to ensure that the levels of licence fees remain appropriate.

The variations will not substantially alter the position of stations in the short term. Stations with gross earnings of less than $2 1/2m will still pay lower fees than under the current provisions and estimated revenue from this source in 1981-82 remains at an estimated $31.5m.
This will benefit approximately 120 of 130 commercial broadcasting stations and 20 of 50 commercial television stations.

The Government hopes that this will enable stations benefiting by these changes to improve programming and services to the public. It does not believe that these aspects will suffer in the bigger stations. Advertising revenue is the life blood of commercial broadcasting and television. It is directly related to the audience share of a particular station and obviously this relates to the programming appeal of the station to the general public. No station can, therefore, afford to lower its programming standards.
The details of the proposed rates are clearly shown in the Bills. The changes will take effect on 1 September 1981.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The purpose of this Bill is to authorise the payment to Queensland of $58.5m in 1981-82 as special grants in respect of 1979-80 and 1980-81.

The payment of this amount is in accordance with the recommendations of the Commonwealth Grants Commission contained in its Forty-eighth Report 1981 on special assistance for States, which was tabled on 23 September 1981.

Successive Commonwealth Governments, from time to time, on the recommendations of the Commonwealth Grants Commission following applications by States, have provided special financial assistance to the less populous States to compensate them for such factors as lower capacity to raise revenue and higher costs of providing government services of a standard comparable to those provided by the financially stronger states.
Since self-government, the Northern Territory has also had access to the Commonwealth grants commission on the same basis as a claimant state.

The grants commission has recommended a special grant of $3.3 million for the Northern Territory in 1981-82. However, by virtue of phase-in provisions included in the memorandum of understanding in respect of financial arrangements agreed between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory governments, the territory will receive an additional assistance grant of $20 million in 1981-82 in lieu of the special grant. Provision for the additional assistance grant to the Northern Territory is made in Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1981-82.
When special grants were first paid they constituted the only regular form of general revenue assistance to the less populous states for this purpose.

However, for many years now, the main way in which special compensatory assistance has been provided to these states has been through the payment of higher per capita amounts of other general revenue funds. This situation is reflected today in the fact that tax sharing grants paid to Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania are higher, in per capita terms, than similar grants paid to New South Wales and Victoria. Special grants are made available to supplement a state's tax sharing grants.

The overall distribution of general revenue assistance to the states is currently undergoing a fundamental re-assessment. The grants commission is itself closely involved in this exercise. Arising from consideration by the Commonwealth and the States of its report on State tax sharing entitlements 1981, the commission has been asked to review its report and in so doing to take into account a number of matters including those that will be raised by the Commonwealth and the States. As an interim arrangement in 1981-82, the Commonwealth has provided additional general revenue grants to New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland in recognition of the likelihood that, following the further review, relativities could be adjusted in favour of these States.

Clearly the role of special grants in the future will need to be determined in the context of the re-assessment of the distribution of general revenue funds. The interim funding arrangement for 1981-82 has therefore been adopted on the basis that there will be no applications by any State for special grants in respect of this financial year. As I mentioned earlier, the special grants which are the subject of this Bill are in respect of the years 1979-80 and 1980-81.
Queensland has been the only claimant State in recent years. It has applied for and received special assistance in each year since 1971-72.

The practice of the Grants Commission, in arriving at its recommendations in relation to state claims for special assistance, has been to make an assessment of the 'Financial needs' of a claimant state. In making such assessments, the Commission compares in detail the finances of the claimant state with those of the 'standard' states-the Commission has regarded New South Wales and Victoria as 'standard' states for special grants purposes since 1959-60.

Normally, special grants recommended by the commission have consisted of two parts. One part is based on a preliminary assessment of the financial need of the claimant state usually in the financial year concerned, and is an advance payment subject to adjustment usually two years later when the commission has compared in detail the finances of the claimant state and standard states for that year. The other part of the special grant represents the final adjustment to the advance payment made earlier and is known as the completion payment. This adjustment might be positive or negative and therefore might result in the final grant in respect of the year being higher or lower than the advance payment for that year.

The payment to Queensland in 1981-82 of $58.5 million provided for by this Bill consists of a completion payment of $33.5 million in respect of 1979-80 and an advance payment of $25 million in respect of 1980-81.

The completion payment in respect of 1979-80, when added to the $11 million advance grant paid to Queensland in that year, brings the final grant in respect of 1979-80 to $44.5 million, that is, $21.8 million above the corresponding figure for 1978-79.

The advance payment in respect of 1980-81 normally would have been provided during that financial year. However, Queensland requested an advance grant only towards the end of that financial year, after the commission's methodology for its review of tax sharing relativities and the processes surrounding the review became known. A completion payment in respect of 1980-81 will be assessed by the commission in 1982-83.

The commission's recommendations in relation to the special grants arrangements have been adopted by the parliament since the commission's inception and the Government considers that they should be accepted on this occasion.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: —I had discussion earlier this day with the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button). I understand that there is agreement that all of the education Bills be debated cognately but that separate questions will be put on each Bill at the second reading stage because there may be some attempt at attachment or amendment. I confirm that there will be a cognate debate on the five Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating five Bills concerning the appropriation of funds for schools and universities in the tertiary education sector throughout Australia. Although the Bills cover a number of different matters, they are, as Senator Carrick pointed out, being debated cognately. Many speakers will choose to discuss different Bills and different aspects of those Bills. On behalf of the Opposition, I will give a brief description of the Bills and then speak in some detail on the three Bills concerning tertiary assistance-the Australian National University Amendment (No. 2) Bill, the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981 provides funds for the next triennium to universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education institutions around Australia. It embodies the decision by the Government to attempt to impose tertiary tuition fees on students studying for second or higher degrees. It embodies the razor gang decision to effect amalgamations between certain tertiary institutions. I give notice to the Senate that, at the end of my second reading speech, I will move an amendment to that Bill. I request the Clerk to circulate that amendment at this stage.

The Australian National University Amendment (No. 2) Bill and the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill are primarily consequential Bills resulting from the Government's decision to impose tertiary tuition fees. These Bills are designed to amend the relevant Act so that the governing bodies of these two institutions may impose fees in accordance with the determination made by the Minister for Education (Mr Fife). The Federal Australian Labor Party is totally opposed to the decision by the Government to impose tertiary fees on students in tertiary institutions who are undertaking second and higher degrees so we will be opposing generally, and specifically, all such measures.

Being debated cognately with the Bills that I have described are two other Bills concerned with schools-the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill and the Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Amendment Bill. The States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill is legislation which provides for the implementation of the program of Commonwealth support for government and non-government schools throughout Australia. The Opposition will, therefore, not be opposing this Bill. However, we will be moving an amendment to the second reading of the Bill, drawing attention to the serious shortcomings of the Government's policy with regard to schools. The Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Amendment Bill extends the provision of a Commonwealth loans guarantee not only to existing schools but also to new schools. The Opposition objects to the proposal to extend the loans guarantee scheme to new schools and will therefore oppose clause 3 of this Bill. My colleagues will be canvassing more fully the issues raised in this Bill.

The Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Amendment Bill is a reasonable statute which gives the Government power to guarantee loans for extensions to non-government schools; that is, existing schools. The Act was legislated for to facilitate the loan raising capacity of non-government schools. The Bill proposes two changes. Firstly, it seeks to expand the guarantee to include interest payments outstanding as well as the principle. The Australian Labor Party has no objection to that. Secondly, it proposes that the guarantee be available to new or proposed schools. Our opposition to this matter will be expressed when we oppose clause 3 of the Bill. The measure would, in our view, encourage the type of school which is currently causing so much dissent and alarm within the community-for example, schools which are not attached to mainstream churches or backed by established community or parents' groups and which often seek to follow eccentric curricula or educational practices. The experience in the United States of America of schools conducted in the fundamentalist tradition provides an example of the reason why so many parents and teachers are alarmed by the development of these schools. I believe that many Australian parents would question whether schools which promote such teaching are in the best interests of children or are deserving of public support. Such schools, I must point out, are not usually subjected to the judgment of their educational standards by State regulations. Registration procedures in most States go no further than dealing with public health and safety matters. Yet, when such schools are registered, they are automatically entitled to recurrent subsidies from the Schools Commission.

With regard to the major points I want to make at this stage of the debate, we, as I said, are opposed outright to those Bills before us which seek to impose fees on students in tertiary institutions. I must point out that the fees will be imposed not only on students undertaking higher degrees but also on a large body of undergraduate students; that is, those students who are taking a second undergraduate degree. Honourable senators may be aware that in some universities this body of students is a significant proportion of student numbers. In the university with which I am most familiar, the Australian National University, in excess of 20 per cent of the undergraduate students in the School of Asian Studies are in fact second degree students.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Asian studies is exempt in its amalgamation with arts, economics or law.

—Senator Teague has made a suggestion which is news to me. I would request that the appropriate Minister make that statement of Government policy very clearly throughout this debate. I am referring to students who are undertaking a second undergraduate degree. It would be news to hear from the Minister that this body of students is indeed exempt.

SPEECH.PARA: In the view of the Australian Labor Party, and indeed I think in the view of many people throughout the educational community in Australia, the imposition of fees will result in a reduction of access to education. This is our primary concern. I cannot stress the point too strongly that what we are concerned about with Federal education policy, with the Federal funding of education throughout Australia, is the increased access by Australian citizens to education-to schools education and to higher education. We do not believe, as some latter day elitists are now claiming, that the increasing access by students from low socio-economic families means a decline in standards. We are also committed in the Australian Labor Party to the maintenance of the highest standards within all educational institutions. But in our view, all students who have the ability and the motivation are entitled to education of the highest standard. We believe that the imposition of fees directly obstructs the realisation of that objective.

We believe that we are already getting to a situation in which, because of the Government's mean minded handling of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme, only the sons and daughters of the affluent are able to undertake tertiary education. This is an appalling situation for a country such as Australia. It is particularly appalling in that it is a setting back of the clock; it is a reversal of the trend of increasing access to education which I am very happy to acknowledge was started by Prime Minister Chifley and extended enormously during the Administration of Robert Gordon Menzies. The restriction of the access of Australian citizens to higher education on socio-economic grounds alone is an appalling situation. It is a situation which we will oppose in every possible way.

Senator Teague seems to doubt that the situation I am describing does in fact prevail. I would draw his attention to a recent survey carried out by the Australian Union of Students at Sydney's four major tertiary campuses which found that if faced with tuition fees of $1,000 per annum, which is the maximum fee payable under this legislation, 55 per cent of students would defer or not enrol. A breakdown of student responses to the AUS survey according to family income found that, while 4 per cent of those in the $25,000 and upper income bracket would not enrol if a fee of $300 were levied, over 16 per cent of those with incomes under $10,000 would not enrol if such a fee were levied. Women students would be disadvantaged to a greater degree than men. The AUS survey found that if the $300 per annum fee were levied 32 per cent of males would defer or discontinue compared with 45 per cent of females. This, of course, reflects the lower income levels of women in our community.

The Opposition is also opposing as strongly as it can this measure to impose fees because it believes that it is in fact the thin edge of the wedge. We believe that it is the intention of the Government to impose fees for all tertiary students. As much as the Government may care to deny it, its record speaks for itself. There was a time when it said it would not impose any fees on students in tertiary institutions. First of all it imposed fees on overseas students; now fees are to be imposed on second and higher degree students. If the Government gets this measure through unchallenged by the Senate it would be only a matter of time before fees are imposed for all tertiary tuition. The abolition of tertiary tuition fees and the introduction of a means tested living allowance created a vast expansion in the access to education, particularly for mature age students and for women. As I said, the Fraser Government has attempted to erode such access. It has allowed the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme to diminish to the point where it can no longer be accurately described as a living allowance. Now we are to have the reintroduction of fees.

I think it is proper to ask what the money collected through the reintroduction of fees will be used for. The Government does not intend to require those who can afford it to pay and then use the revenue gained to assist lower and middle income people to undertake tertiary education. It does not intend to use this money to increase the dwindling level of tertiary education assistance. This legislation simply takes money out of education and redirects it elsewhere. The problem of inadequate funding for tertiary institutions has been exacerbated by large increases in academic salaries. Following a 4 per cent interim increase in academic salaries announced earlier this year Justice Ludeke has only recently awarded a further 6 per cent increase in academic salaries. This means that universities and tertiary institutions are going to be faced with a 10 per cent increase in their wages bill at a time of severe budgetary restrictions. Their budgetary problems are going to be almost overwhelming. Unless the Government allocates more funds to tertiary institutions to cover this recently announced increase, I believe that many tertiary institutions will find that their financial position is impossible. I look forward to some comment on this matter by the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) during this debate.

It is very strongly the view of the Australian Labor Party that at a time of rapid technological and economic change the Government should be encouraging people to acquire new skills and to upgrade their qualifications. Currently both government and private industry spend vast amounts of money importing experts and people with specialised skills to fill jobs for which too few Australians are qualified. The cost of importing skills and expertise will only grow as access to education and training decreases. It simply does not make any sense that at a time when we are crying out for advanced skills in a whole range of high technology areas, in a whole range of areas such as the so-called resources boom, we are importing this talent and expertise and denying Australian citizens the opportunity to acquire the appropriate expertise.

I might say at this stage of the debate that it simply does not make sense either that we provide a financial incentive for young people to drop out of university and go on the dole. That is precisely what is happening in an undocumented but I believe, through my experience as a local senator in the Australian Capital Territory, very great number of cases. If students are struggling and finding it impossible to live on the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and if they are now going to be faced with fees for higher degrees, then in many cases they will drop out. As we know, rates of youth unemployment being what they are, many young people will end up on the dole. Where is the sense of paying young people to be unemployed and yet denying them sufficient support to continue to develop their education and expertise to a level where they will be of great benefit not only to themselves in their economic circumstances but also to the whole community and economy. It makes no sense at all.

I remind the Senate that compared with other nations the Australian Government ranks education as a low priority. A comparison between Australia and other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries of full time enrolment rates by age groups shows that in the 15 year-old to 19 year-old age group Australia has 46.1 per cent enrolled; Germany has 51.3 per cent; Canada has 66.4 per cent and Japan, to whom we look as an economic partner in so many instances, has 76.3 per cent enrolled. When we go to the higher age group-the 20 year-old to 24 year-old age group-the ones who will perhaps be most affected by the imposition of fees, we find that Australia has only 5.5 per cent enrolments, Germany has 11.1 per cent, Canada has 14.5 per cent, and Japan has 14.5 per cent enrolment. Again this sort of comparison ought to convince the Senate of the senselessness of the measures currently being legislated for by the Government.

How are we to compete internationally or improve our trading situation? How are we to upgrade the whole range of skills and expertise within the economy if we deny our young people and our adults the opportunity to enrol in full time tertiary education? I think the comparison with countries like Japan and West Germany particularly are most instructive. There is no benefit in the community having vast numbers of people unemployed. There is no benefit in the community having vast numbers of people unskilled and undereducated, as is the case in Australia. It has become a very popular fad in some of the editorials of the newspapers in this country to say that we are overeducated and that we have spent too much money on education. I do not know what standard of comparison they are using when they make these sorts of judgments, but no realistic standard of comparison which I can discover, suggests that we are anything other than a severely undereducated community.

Although I am stressing the importance of education in training for the economy, I would stress even more greatly the importance to a health, progressive democracy of having a highly educated citizenry. People are not able to operate properly and freely in a democracy if they are undereducated, unable to grasp the way institutions work and, I suggest, if they are unable to decide for themselves the objectivity of the news and information that is available to them through the highly monopolised news outlets that we have in this country. To be a truly free person one needs to be competent and to be able to understand and to assert that understanding. One needs to be able to judge governments and indeed, I might add, to be able to judge oppositions. None of those attributes so essential in a democracy can be achieved while we are keeping people at such low levels of education and as such low levels of access to information, ideas and expertise.

I strongly believe that the current high levels of unemployment, particularly youth unemployment, will be exacerbated under the fees proposal which will discourage people from seeking higher educational qualifications. The fees proposal ignores the ability to pay. For example, those post-graduate students already in receipt of Commonwealth awards will also be exempt from fees. Those who get nothing will now have to pay fees. There is no question of ability to pay being a criterion for the requirement to pay. It also ignores the vital contribution of post-graduate students to Australia's research effort. Under Fraser Government stringencies there are now far fewer tutorships and demonstrator positions available at universities and colleges of advanced education to enable post-graduate students to support themselves. Again, what is the fall back position? It is either affluent families or nothing-dropping out.

The revenue collected by the imposition of fees would be small. I think this is an important point to make. I believe this is not an economic measure, like so many alleged economic measures introduced by the Fraser Government, but it is an ideological measure. We are not really seeking to bring vast revenues either into the Consolidated Revenue Fund or into revenues for campuses by the imposition of these fees. The Government is simply seeking to exclude a certain number of students from access to higher education.

Appropriation Bill (No. 1) from the recent Budget intends to appropriate something like $1.865 billion for colleges, universities and technical and further education institutions throughout Australia. The Government estimates that in the next calendar year it will get no more than $8m as a result of the imposition of fees. I think that is an extraordinarily optimistic estimate. The figure will probably be closer to $4m. We must subtract from this $4m figure the relatively high cost of collecting the fees. For example, the Griffith University in Queensland has estimated that the difference between the administration cost involved and the amount of fees collected will be no greater than $10,000. The Griffith University has therefore refused to collect fees.

The other issue raised directly by this legislation is the amalgamation of tertiary institutions. Like the decision in relation to tertiary tuition fees, the decision that 30 colleges of advanced education should cease to exist, was made by the Lynch Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions, popularly and notoriously known as the razor gang. This decision seems to have little economic justification. It seems that the razor gang believed that if there were fewer colleges, savings would be made in recurrent expenditure. I suggest that such savings are likely to be minimal. Even the Tertiary Education Commission has said that significant economies are unlikely in the short to medium term. The question of what is good or what is best for education in this country just does not seem to have entered the decision.

This Government seems to be ideologically opposed to educational and cultural activities and to be totally committed to reversing all of the initiatives introduced by the Whitlam Government. I simply point out at this stage that there is one thing that the Fraser Government cannot do. It cannot reverse the expectations of quality and access that were raised during the period of the Whitlam Government. It can dismantle programs, slash funding and impose staff ceilings, but this society had its whole vision of what an equal and fair society ought to be like, greatly enhanced, greatly increased and illuminated during the period of the Whitlam Government, and that, I suggest, cannot be totally reversed by this Government.

In 1973 43 teachers colleges achieved CAE status. This clearly had an impact on the entire tertiary sector. The emergence of a surplus of teachers in the mid-1970s and the subsequent reduced intake in teacher education courses provided justifiable grounds for some re-organisation in the tertiary sector. The Opposition does not oppose such re-organisation. However, we do believe that the current amalgamation proposal is unsatisfactory. The unsatisfactory aspects of this proposal include the likely reduction of overall educational opportunities, a decrease in the diversity of courses and in the recognition of different educational approaches by different institutions, the likely damage to morale at tertiary institutions leading to a decline in educational standards and the problem of redundancy of college staff which will result from amalgamation. I should point out here that the Minister for Education is on record as saying that he is not in the least bit concerned about the problem of redundancy and it is clearly a problem for the States and the institutions themselves. If tertiary institutions are forced into these unsatisfactory kinds of amalgamations the consequences for tertiary education in Australia will be serious and permanent.

There are a number of points to be made about the other Bills which are being debated cognately, but as I said in my opening remarks, these will be addressed by colleagues of mine and, I presume, other speakers in the debate. At this stage I want to stress that we are adopting this attitude to this packet of Bills because of our basic belief that access to education in Australia should be increased, that education of the highest possible standard should be available to all with the motivation and the ability to undertake it and that the current series of Bills are designed to attack both access and standards. If we exclude people, if we reduce access to tertiary education to those who can afford to pay for it, we will be excluding people of talent, we will be excluding people who could otherwise make an important contribution to this society. By reducing access we will also lower standards. I do not think there are many people in a position of competence to speak on this matter in campuses throughout Australia who would disagree with me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would academic stand- ards be lower?

—It is my belief and the belief of all people in my party that ability and talent do not reside in one particular class of people. It is my belief that native ability and motivation reside in all socio-economic classes in our society. There have been innumerable examples of this having been the case. There have been innumerable examples in our own series of education policies in this country where the giving to people from socio-economically deprived backgrounds the opportunity and access has resulted in outstanding performances by children and adults who without that special opportunity provided by sympathetic government policies would not have been able to develop their abilities. So in our view talent, ability, academic talent, research talent and so on exist in an almost random way throughout society. Therefore, policies which exclude people simply on a socio-economic basis are policies which will exclude talented people and potentially creative and constructive people. I suppose that is the nub of our concern about these restrictive policies. On behalf of the Opposition, in respect of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill, I move as an amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that-

(1) the University/College of Advanced Education amalgamations proposed in Newcastle, Armidale, Wollongong and Townsville should not proceed until arrangements satisfactory to both parties to the amalgamation have emerged;

(2) those Colleges of Advanced Education in New South Wales and Victoria for which no satisfactory amalgamation proposal exists should be funded until proposals satisfactory to the staff and students of the colleges involved are determined, and
(3) the Government should provide guarantees backed by special financial support to ensure that where amalgamations occur the-
(A) existing range of educational opportunities are maintained,
(B) employment security of staff is safeguarded, and
(C) academic integrity of the institutions is protected'.

In respect of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill 1981, which is being debated cognately with the other education Bills, on behalf of the Opposition, as an amendment to the second reading motion, I intend to move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that-

(1) the Commonwealth Government is ignoring its primary obligation to the government school sector as stated in section 13 of the Schools Commission Act especially in its neglect of Schools Commission advice that the continuing shortfall in capital funds for government schools is unacceptably high;

(2) the advancement of one sector of Australia's schools should not be at the disadvantage of the other sector whether public or private as this will revive tensions within the community which disappeared with the introduction of the 'needs' policy by the Labor Government in 1973, and

(3) the excessive and unplanned proliferation of new private schools beyond the demand for new places at a time of contraction of the school age population is wasteful of resources and will destabilise existing schools creating 'public resentment' as expressed by the Victorian Minister for Education'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is involved in a second reading debate on five education Bills-the State Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill, the Australian National University Amendment (No. 2) Bill, the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill and the Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Amendment Bill-which are being debated together. These Bills cover many issues and it is not my intention to range over the whole of the field or all of the provisions covered in the Bills. Having listened to the speech made by Senator Ryan I think it is time to get back to a few basic points-a few essentials in this education debate. Surely the starting point is that the education vote is finite. It is not an infinite vote. There is not an unlimited amount of money. What this Government has tried to do is to assess priorities and I will have a little more to say about that in a moment or two. Anyone who listened to the speech from Labor Party representatives would think that really no money is going into education at all. The figures belie that thought because the education vote has risen quite dramatically in the last 10 years.
—So it should.

—Yes, it should, and it has; that is my point. It is not a hypothetical case that this will happen in the future. Apart from the vote for social security and welfare the education vote has risen more than the vote for any other sector in the Federal Budget.
