For example, 10 years ago in 1971-72, the vote was $349m. This year, 1981-82, the vote is $3,255m which is roughly a tenfold lift. If we have a look at the position of the universities which is a particular point of concern we will see that 10 years ago in 1971-72 the vote for the universities was $126m. This year the vote is $967m. It roughly parallels the great increase in the educational vote. That vote has more than kept pace with inflation.

SPEECH.PARA: I would prefer that we did not charge fees for tertiary students but I can see the need to assess the priorities that we have had in this field. Much is made about free education but I would remind the chamber that there is no such thing as free education. Education is paid for through tax and that means that everyone who earns any income at all and anyone who buys anything in the community that in any way attracts an indirect tax contributes to those who are educated. I think the idea of free education is as nonsensical as the idea of free medicine. That is a point that I am sorry my comrades over the road-those senators who sit opposite-simply cannot understand.

That leads me to the business of priorities. It is up to the Government to assess priorities as it sees them for the benefit of the whole Australian community. We are fortunate in having a Liberal-National Country Party Government that can operate for the benefit of all the people in the country, not just sections that support those parties.

The priorities in education that the Government has to look at include first of all how much money is to go to education as opposed to other areas in the community such as the development of this country, welfare payments and the rest, and secondly the proportion of the education vote that goes to tertiary education. The Government has decided that those students who already have one university degree will contribute-only contribute; not pay for the whole cost but make a partial contribution-towards the cost of their second degree. I believe there is a very justifiable argument for that action.

I have presumed that the Government did look at alternatives to this, such as a percentage reduction in the grants that go to education. The Government decided this was the fairest and best way to go about it. The argument for charging fees for second degree students is pretty clear. These students are well established in their academic careers. They know where they are going. They have career motivation and, having started and been supported by all wage earners and taxpayers in Australia, they are now asked to make some small contribution to the funding of the final part of their educational course. The fee that is to be charged is $1,000 a year. I would not know what the true cost is to provide a year's tuition for a student.

TALK.START.PARA: —Six thousand dollars.

—I thank Senator Teague. I am casting my mind back seven or eight years to the position in the United States where term fees for graduate students were, I think, about $4,000 to $6,000. The proposition that has been put by the Labor Party turns on three premises. The first one is that students simply cannot work while they are doing higher degrees. The second one, so eloquently put by Senator Ryan with much passion, is that we are going back to the dark days of the 1950s, that it will be only the rich and elite who will be educated if fees for these students are not paid for by government and that students will drop out and go on the dole. Does Senator Ryan really believe that people make the sacrifice and effort to go through all the rigours of secondary education, through a pass degree, to then become a voluntary recruit for the dole? Really! I would ask why that student ever started the course if he were to do that. The third proposition is that Australia's research capacity will collapse-not diminish-if fees are introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to deal with the first of these propositions, and that is that students cannot be allowed to work while they are undertaking higher education. As I said before, I should like them to be able to get their education without paying fees. But I cannot accept the proposition that a student cannot work between the period of his pass degree and his higher degree and put some money in the bank to put himself through his course. I cannot accept that he cannot intermit in some degrees, although it is undesirable to take a year off half-way through the course to earn some money. I cannot accept that a student cannot work part time at weekends and in the recesses, which, by and large, are quite extensive-probably 35 to 40 per cent of the year-to earn some money to put himself through his course. It may not be desirable in the best of all possible worlds, but it is possible to make the effort. I reject utterly the concept of education that is going around that we have to bribe students, that we have to cross their palms with silver to encourage them to take a higher degree or any form of education. I find that idea utterly abhorrent.

Certainly the proposition I am advocating does mean that some effort in education is required. But I believe that students are prepared to make that effort. The basic requirements for a successful higher degree student or indeed any sort of student are, firstly, motivation, the will to succeed, the will to acquire that knowledge, and, secondly, the ability to be able to cope with the academic course. I have an unbounded belief in the virtues of human nature. I believe that people will make the effort and that they have the ideals to acquire a higher education. We are talking about students, and students have a thirst for knowledge. That is what scholarship is all about. Scholarship is not a matter of legislating and putting people through universities and giving them degrees pro rata after they have served a period. It is a matter of having able people who want that knowledge and who want to get on.

At a lesser plane than the idealism of the desire for knowledge, we have the matter of career advancement. A large number of students who enrol for higher degrees do so so that their career will benefit. They know that they will be promoted and they know that a higher range of opportunities and appointments will be presented for them if they have a higher level of education. I believe that that is the motivation that will move students to cope with the difficulties of earning in order to provide some income for themselves while they are students.

I turn now to Government priorities and raise two small points. As a senator for Queensland, I have to make a decision whether I support a government that moves to pay a student to do a second degree which will enable him to advance his career or whether I want to see that money directed towards roads or communications. Probably no State in Australia has worse roads than Queensland. I refer to the northern highway and to other main roads where one has to dice with semi-trailers to beat them over priority narrow bridges. I mention also the flooding of highways. People are being killed all the time on our roads and that is a real penalty for society, far more so than a student working for a few hours at the weekend to put himself through university.

Let us take the subject of telephones and television. Most of the people in Queensland live outside the capital city. They have maybe one or no television channel. They do not have the four channels or the countless number of radio stations that the people in Sydney and Melbourne have. Telephones are a very big issue in the country area. Every household in the cities of Melbourne or Sydney which wants a telephone connection can have it. If there is no telephone in the house there is the corner store with a telephone available or the public telephone box out on the footpath. As Senator Robertson would acknowledge there are not too many public telephone boxes 60 miles from Ilfracombe.

TALK.START.PARA: —There aren't too many paid for by the education voter. Get to the point.

—I am interested in hearing some of the comments that are coming through from honourable senators. I should like to put forward my own credentials. I have taught graduate students in three different countries. I have spent over 16 years teaching in universities.
—Where did you get your training?

—I have seen systems which range from the free educational system in the United Kingdom through to the very high free structure in the United States. In the high free structure, which is at the opposite end of the spectrum, there is no shortage of enrolments for the courses at all.
—Who paid for your training? Come on, answer me.
—If the honourable senator wants to know something about my own case, I will tell him. I was not going to but I will. I put myself through my post-graduate education--
—Because you were allowed to earn money.

—I had been practising for years. I put myself through. I do not assume any virtue from this at all. It was the only way that was open to me. Seven years after I had graduated, with specialist qualifications and a higher degree, I was happy to take a job at #12 a week in a hospital and pay #7 a week rent. I had a wife and one child. I did that, and I would have paid for that privilege because of the opportunity and experience it gave me in my career. I am no different from anyone else in my generation.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that the generation coming on today should do what my father had to do or what I did. The only point I am making is that it is possible to approach this problem in different ways. My ambition in politics is to make life easier for people, to make it more satisfying so that they can do more things. I certainly do not want to inflict on another generation any of the difficulties that I had to go through. But we must never lose sight of the point that human nature can cope if it has the motivation.

The point that Senator Ryan made about the rich being the only people who are educated really is a load of nonsense. There is no social segment which has the right to be educated under the system of government in this country. By and large I think it is true that those people who have an excess of money simply do not have the motivation to do the hard work that an academic career involves. The basic requirement, as I said before, is motivation, and that motivation of course is more a matter of family values that the child has been brought up with, and how much emphasis has been put on education. That, and not the economic structure of the family is the sole determinant, really.

While we are talking about the 1950s, it might not be a bad idea to look at what was going on then. Since the 1950s free education at a tertiary level for a pass degree has been introduced. More importantly, in the graduate level that we are talking about, almost every form of training is now available in Australia. Thirty years ago in the 1950s, indeed 20 years ago in the 1960s, if anyone wanted to do a higher degree it was probably desirable for them to go overseas. In many cases it was mandatory for him to go overseas to acquire that qualification. That meant that students had to pay their fares to the other side of the world, either North America or Britain; they had to support themselves in a foreign country without any support from their family while they were there, and they probably had to pay fees. All of that has gone. One of the achievements of the Government in recent years is that we have now a full spread of graduate accommodation available within Australia. That is a point that does not get the recognition it deserves.

The final point made by the Australian Labor Party is that research will collapse. That is a very loose statement. That point has only a very thin grain of truth in it, and the truth that it has relates to the fact that if manpower is not coming on our capacity to perform research will certainly diminish. But we must take the broader view and look at the whole of the Australian research record. Australia has a very poor record in the field of research and development. As the report of the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment which was tabled last year showed, the effort we make does not compare at all with effort made by similar countries. Probably that is a consequence of the high tariff protection policies that have been followed by all Australian governments over the last few generations. There has not been the pressure on industry to compete. What we need to support an increased research effort in this country is action by the Government to reduce the level of tariffs, to provide taxation incentives for industry, so that more research and development is done in-house in Australia and also an increase in the research grants, particularly in the scientific disciplines, to bodies such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the universities. In general I think there is an obligation on the Government to look at the whole field of post-graduate education in the light of these changes. If it finds that there are some unforeseen consequences, there is probably a need to look at the level of post-graduate scholarships and awards available to the Australian academic community to see that they are adequate in number and in conditions.

The second matter that I will deal with in relation to this parcel of Bills relating to tertiary education institutes concerns the matter of compulsory unionism for students maintained in all Australian universities. To allow the tentacles of unionism to spread into a field where really it has no business at all is really intolerable. Quite simply, what is happening is that, unless a student joins a student union, the university administration does not allow the student to enrol for his course or, if he is allowed to enrol, he is not allowed to enrol for examinations. If those two steps are allowed, the administration will not allow the examination papers to be marked or will block the student on the awarding of the degree. I find that absolutely unsupportable. This Parliament has moved in relation to the only university over whose affairs we can exercise any guidance at all, the Australian National University, to eliminate that practice.

It should be a matter for State governments of all political persuasions to move in because the power rests with them to see that this pernicious habit of compulsory unionism in student unions is stamped out. Joining a union should be a matter of choice. A student should have the choice whether he joins a union. That should be where the matter ends. Under this principle of compulsory unionism, a great deal of political agitation is being stirred up. It is not doing the student body any good at all because the fundamental premise for any learning is that there is peace in the land and on the campus. It is not possible to teach students when they are out throwing bricks through windows and rioting in the streets. It is not possible to imagine a worse situation for scholarship to flourish in.

Last Saturday morning in Brisbane, I opened the Weekend Australian and looked at the career positions in the 'Positions Vacant' column. There was an advertisement for the University of Queensland Union. I will read what that advertisement says. It is titled: 'University of Queensland Union Calls applications for the newly-created position of Part-Time Students' Organiser'. Under the heading 'Duties', the advertisement stated:
1. To organize and politicize the Unions' part-time members.
Then the advertisement lists three more duties and the qualifications expected. I repeat that the first duty is:
To organize and politicize the unions' part time members.

What are we about in this country? Is this the thousand Year Reich or the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics? We do not need the student body to be politicised by force. It students want to be interested in politics, that is fine; I was, as a student, 20-odd years ago. But to compel people to be politicised as is required of the part time student organiser advertised for here-presumably if there is a part time student organiser, we have a full time student organiser as well-I find utterly intolerable. That is not the sort of society I want to live in.

What is going on with this compulsory unionism? I will tell honourable senators. There is a compulsory union contribution for political purposes. University union fees are not $5 or $10 but run in excess of $120 for most universities. That is quite a large sum of money. Quite a large fraction of that is diverted for political causes which are quite antipathetical to the students scholarship. The only argument to support the running of a union on a university campus is to provide facilities for students, for cafeterias and for recreational facilities. I believe that even those facilities should be self-supporting. I find it hard to believe that, on the larger university campuses, where there is a student and staff body in excess of 10,000, it is not possible to make a pie stall pay. Most unions now have licences and run bars. I cannot see why the whole thing cannot be run as a normal commercial operation without the taxpayer having to put a subsidy in not to provide food or drink for students but to pay for the mismanagement in the operation of those facilities.

I am very concerned at the way university administrators, vice-chancellors, senates and the various boards of management, support without fail compulsory unionism in the universities of Australia. They are the very first people to talk about academic freedom. I am prepared to defend academic freedom anywhere. But it is not academic freedom to compel a student to be a member of a union. A more basic human freedom is involved-the freedom of choice whether a person wants to belong to a body. That should be recognised. While we support compulsory unions on the campuses, we are leading to a closed shop mentality which extends throughout the whole of the Australian community.

One element that is putting this country at risk is the level of industrial relations that we have. We do not need to inculcate bad relationships in universities. I do not believe that this country can survive for more than four or five years unless we modify quite dramatically our industrial relations. The first thing that will happen is that we will lose our mineral exports. We already have a very undesirable reputation as an unreliable supplier. The large bulk exports that the mineral industry trades in simply cannot be accepted by the users in other countries when there is such a degree of unreliability whether they will get their coal, iron ore or alumina. The second thing that is happening is that we are being priced out through the increasing cost of production of these minerals despite the very great natural advantages of cheap extraction that we have. Those aspects are purely matters of union relationships.

There is no permanency in the development of minerals. There is no way we can lock minerals up and come back to them in 50 years time hoping to derive money from their extraction. The solution to these problems is purely political. It is not a matter for the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or the trade unions but it is a matter for the government of the day. I am sorry to say that, on this side of the Parliament, all we seem to be involved in is a semantic or legal argument as to what some agreements mean. Of course, on the other side of the chamber, it is just a sell-out to what ever the most demanding union wants at the time. It is a very complex problem. There are many causes of it but essentially it is a political matter. The first thing the Government should do is to do something about the income tax laws because the tax on wage earners is far too high. That is one of the arguments for indirect taxation which the Australian Labor Party is not so keen on.

The matter of overtime is a very real problem in the work force. Penalty rates do not work and the cash in the hand practice and the tax evasion that results from this action are a very real issue in the community. Put quite simply, people are not prepared to work at the weekends and out of hours at the approved penalty rates, whatever the union rates might be, but they will work as long as required provided they are paid on a cash-in-hand basis on which earnings they pay no tax. I think there is an obligation on the Government to recognise these customs in the community and to cope with them. Obviously it cannot prevent them happening.

The second consequence of high taxation on tax earners concerns the matter of strikes. A lot of disputes result because people feel that they do not have enough money. People do not have enough money because they pay so much tax. They go on strike for a while and get quite a large wage rise but, when tax is taken out, the net gain is very small. The other aspect concerns the high level of income tax which allows strikes to be prolonged until such time as that income tax, paid through the year, has been amortised because the workers are really losing nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Much as I hate to interrupt a speaker, I ask whether Senator MacGibbon might come back to the Bill so we might know what he is talking about? What he is saying is interesting but does not appear to relate to the Bills that we are debating.
—Senator MacGibbon, I ask that you direct your comments to the matters in the Bills at hand.

—I was. I was relating my remarks to the business of compulsory unionism of students in Australian tertiary institutes. If Senator Robertson has the patience to listen and the concentration, he will find that I will relate my remarks back to the subject of compulsory unionism.
—You are saying that they are teaching industrial unrest; that is the point.

—The point I made was that it was most undesirable to compel students to be members of a union. I think that quite secretly Senator Button agrees with me. The second point in the whole matter of union relationships concerns the conditions that the Federal and State governments apply to their own employees. Simply stated, the terms and conditions under which public servants are employed exceed the terms that private industry can offer its employees. That has a destabilising influence on society. The whole matter of compulsory unionism--

—I rise to a point of order. I have just entered the chamber and have been listening to Senator MacGibbon. I am in a position to consider his comments clearly and without reference to what he has said previously. I am completely unaware of the Bills to which he is supposed to be speaking. Certainly, they are not the four Bills that are before the Senate at present.
—Five Bills.

—Not one of the five Bills deals with the subject of compulsory unionism for students at universities. The honourable senator has misused the forms of the Senate to range widely over a variety of subjects-actually because he has run out of material.
—He is defying the Chair, which is most unfortunate.

—Of course. He has merely extended his remarks to embrace another area because he has nothing further to say on the subject matter before the Senate. I suggest that he be brought back to the five Bills that are before us.
—Senator Georges, your point is made.

—It is really an impertinence for someone to walk into this chamber after I have been speaking for 26 minutes and tell me what I have been talking about. To continue, compulsory unionism cannot be supported in the Australian community. This Government has done everything it can to ensure that the monopoly position of capital cannot be used to exploit society. It has done nothing to control the monopoly of labour through unionism. The way in which the union movement has moved into the campuses of Australia with its compulsory unionism is quite against the interests of the students and of the Australian community. It prevents students from getting on with the job and acquiring the knowledge that we are all talking about. That is the reason for their being there, but the intrusion of which I speak is producing a destabilising effect on the Australian community. I have much pleasure in supporting the Government on these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating five Bills which deal with grants to the States, to the Australian National University and to the Canberra College of Advanced Education for educational purposes. They represent quite an important package of education Bills and, contrary to the suggestions of my colleagues, I have been quite encouraged by Senator MacGibbon's speech, because I have a strong suspicion that at last he is coming to grips with the issues of the 1960s. For him, that is indeed encouraging. However, at this stage I do not propose to dwell on the various points that he made.

SPEECH.PARA: These are important Bills. In a sense they are important in their absurdity because in no way do they address themselves, as one hopes Bills of this kind might, to questions relating to the educational issues which face this country. Basically, the debate in the Senate on the measures will be about the question of fees and, to a lesser extent, the amalgamation of colleges of advanced education. I begin by quoting from an editorial in the Australian of April of this year which dealt with the question of the reintroduction of fees for second degrees. The editorial stated:
What Australia needs and has a right to expect is a clear educational policy, not hiccups of reaction or isolated ad hoc decisions.

In regard to the question of fees, we are confronted with very much an isolated ad hoc decision. According to the Government's estimates when dealing with the economic aspects of fee collection, fees to be collected in 1982 would total approximately $8m, or less than half of one per cent of total Commonwealth expenditure on universities and colleges. Therefore, we are not dealing with a big issue in economic terms but rather one of the issues that this Government has always been concerned about in an ad hoc way, in seeking to indulge in somewhat disciplinarian gestures towards certain sections of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —The CYSS program was only $11m.

—I am not talking about the CYSS program; I am referring to university fees. When one contrasts the $8m estimate of revenue from the $1,000 fee to be imposed on individuals with the effect that it will have on many individuals-because that sum represents a substantial proportion of the income of people of student age-one sees the absurdity of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the $8m figure is an official estimate. On 21 October the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick), in answering a question, assured the Senate that in 1982 only 4,000 students would be affected. According to my mathematics, that would bring in an income of some $4m rather than an income of $8m, as projected by the Government. So much for the estimates made by a goverment which is blown up with rhetoric about its efficiency in relation to these matters.

My second point, before dealing with the educational consequences of the reintroduction of fees, relates to the Government's credibility on this issue. That is very important to the Senate as a so-called House of review. Let me say quite clearly that if the Government proceeds by way of legislation with the proposal that it put to the people of Australia, prior to the elections last year, to establish a motor racing circuit in Canberra, the Opposition will support the proposal because that is something that the Government said, before the last elections, it would do. However idiotic the proposal may seem to us, the Government is entitled to do it because it went to the people of Australia and told them that it would.

On the other hand, let us consider what the Government said about university fees. I am sorry to have to go back to 1977, but the statements made about the fees issue by Senator Carrick, as Minister for Education then and subsequently were quite explicit. It was made quite clear that a Fraser government would not be about introducing fees. Senator Carrick stated in November 1977:

Cyclically, each year, a series of rumours circulates about a number of aspects of education. Like all rumours, and certainly those that have been circulated about the Fraser Government, they are utterly wrong. Rumours are running in certain quarters that the Government intends to re-impose fees for foreign students. There is no truth in that at all.
Look at what happened in 1979. The Minister continued:
It is true that Australia is even more attractive than ever to foreign students . . .
He then went on to deal with that issue. Referring to Senator Lajovic, who had asked the question, the Minister added:

The honourable senator referred also, I believe, to the suggestion that fees were to be reimposed in other areas. There has never been, and will not be, an intention to reimpose fees in relation to the primary or co-ordinated degree areas. Nor do we intend to reimpose fees in regard to second degrees. In short, any rumours circulating regarding fees are in error.

There could be no more explicit statement than that. I suppose that it could be said that it is an old statement, but it is one of intention on the part of this Government. By contrast, look at what the present Minister for Education (Mr Fife) had to say on 8 October 1980 when he was flushed out on the fees issue. The Minister had to be flushed out because he did not understand the issue, but when flushed out he had this to say:
I have given an assurance publicly, and I repeat that assurance, that no proposals are being considered by the Government for the possible reintroduction of tertiary fees.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true. Senator Carrick's statement of several years ago was also true.

—We can have an argument with Senator Teague about credibility at any time from now on because he is advocating as a matter of political philosophy something that his masters have adopted as a matter of political practice for some years-that one can say anything prior to an election and do something quite contrary after the election.
—No, I am not advocating that.
—Senator Teague knows what it is about. He should not try to pretend with me.
—I am not advocating that.

—He is quite aware of what it is about. He can work it out for himself and perhaps make a devious contribution to the debate which explains what this Government has been doing. Quite frankly, had this Government adopted an honest approach to the electorate and had it had the guts-it requires political guts-to go to the people of Australia before the last election and state its position on fees we would have been in a very difficult situation indeed in opposing this legislation. But the Government did not do that and that is why the fees issue is causing so much concern now, as are other issues which this Government failed to raise prior to the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look briefly at the merits of the fees issue. What we are talking about in terms of fees for second degrees and what we are talking about, in a different sense, in terms of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill are questions concerning access to education. In relation to second degrees we are talking about access or the right of access to further study. I found all Senator MacGibbon's views on this issue quaint, if I might say so. Most members of this Senate have been through the tortuous experience of having to do a bit of work as students. I did not mind that; I hope that Senator MacGibbon did not mind it either. I do not have any views which would encourage the sorts of soft options which Senator MacGibbon seems to think are being offered young people today compared with what was offered his sturdy generation, which produced senators and the like. At all levels in this debate we are talking about questions of access. The fundamental question about access to tertiary education in Australia, as I think all the experts agree now, lies in the schools area. At a later stage I want to say something about the level of funding for schools and the response of this Government to the increased drop-out rate amongst secondary students and the declining access from secondary schools to tertiary education. But let us deal with the matter of access to post-graduate study of one kind or another.

The effects of the abolition of fees by the last Labor Government has been a matter of legitimate debate. It has been said, I think with some veracity, that the results which the abolition of fees was expected to achieve in terms of increasing access to education were not achieved. It is very doubtful whether one can generalise or speak with certainty about that issue. Certainly, two or three years ago a survey indicated that one-third of college of advanced education students would not be able to continue their courses, in their view, if fees were imposed. But one of the interesting and exciting aspects of the abolition of fees has been the increase in the number of highly motivated mature-age students who have been attending universities and colleges of advanced education, not only for primary degrees but also for post-graduate and second degrees. I would have thought that they were the sorts of students that Senator MacGibbon had in mind in his vision of the perfect student under Malcolm Fraser's Government-highly motivated students wanting to pursue further studies and all that sort of thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't prove that they are denied entry and the attainment of a degree through financial limitations. That's the issue you are skating away from. That's the issue you won't tackle.
—Why do I have to prove that?
—To make your argument respectable.

—I suggest that Senator MacGibbon should just look at the figures on the number of mature age students attending universities and colleges of advanced education consequent upon the abolition of fees. Of course, the other issue is that of the access of women to education, particularly in respect of the pursuit of education courses as such. As I said earlier, the real question of primary access is at the school level. That is where increased drop-out rates are occurring under this Government. This Government has a capacity to look about 2 hours ahead rather than to the long term future, which we have to look to when considering educational issues. What we are faced with is a real crisis in educational institutions in Australia-a crisis in institutions generally, I think, but certainly a crisis in educational institutions in terms of directions, sense of purpose and sense of ongoing capacity for access to further education.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.
(Quorum formed).

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting we were discussing a package of education Bills and, basically, the effects of the introduction of fees for second degrees. I was trying to illustrate the veracity of a point made by the Australian in its editorial of 23 April. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: What Australia needs and has a right to expect is a clear education policy, not hiccups of reaction or isolated ad hoc decisions.

The imposition of fees is a hiccup from the Government which will provide revenue equivalent to one half of one per cent of the Commonwealth's expenditure on education at the tertiary level. At the same time it will impose substantial burdens on individuals. Quite frankly, this Government's education policies confirm the observation made in the Australian editorial in that there is no indication of any educational philosophy in these Bills. There is no clue as to where the Government thinks it is going in education policy. Over the last five or six years we have seen a government which has pigeon-holed reports in relation to education matters. There is a whole list of reports which, of course, we have been asked to wait for almost in a state of desperation. The report of the Williams Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment was to solve all the problems of secondary and post-secondary education. We waited two and a half years for it and, of course, it is virtually a pigeon-holed report.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was your speech last year and the year before.

—Senator Teague compliments me because he says that that was my speech last year. I say to Senator Teague that it will be my speech next year too because I have absolute faith that this Government will have no education policy next year as it had no education policy last year. I will go on saying that. It is an educational achievement of the highest order to have persuaded him of the veracity of that comment.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter I was raising before the suspension of the sitting for dinner was the credibility of the Government on the fees issue. I pointed out that Senator Carrick in 1977, as Minister for Education in this place, and on a number of occasions thereafter, had made it quite clear that there would be no introduction of fees. That was confirmed quite explicitly last year before the appointment of the present Minister for Education, Mr Fife. That is, of course, why we take the position about fees which we do in the Senate. It is another example of this Government saying one thing before an election and doing something completely different afterwards.

If ever the notion of mandate, which has been discussed in the Senate over a few years, did not exist in respect of a government, it does not exist in respect of the Fraser Government. It made it quite clear that it would not proceed with fees and it has gone back on that undertaking. That is a matter of political concern to the Senate and is closely related to the attitude adopted by the Opposition. I said that the imposition of fees affects individuals. It affects the question of access to education. This Government has done very little. I challenge anybody to tell me what the Government has done. In fact, I challenge honourable senators opposite like Senator Teague, who will be speaking later, to tell me what measures the Government has taken in the last six years in education policy which have resulted in an increase of access to education at the tertiary or post-secondary level.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our whole TAFE program.

—I appreciate that, but we are talking about the university and college level. The technical and further education program, of course, has been expanding for a number of years now. I would not have thought that that has happened as a result of any effort by this Government other than the shift in the balance of resources to the TAFE sector. It is a matter of bipartisan concern, I think, that that should happen. When I talk about access I talk not only about the capacity to obtain or enter tertiary or post-secondary education at the college or university level but also about the ability to remain in post-secondary education.

SPEECH.PARA: We have debated in this place-Senator Teague will no doubt remind me of it and I will keep reminding him-the level of post-graduate awards and the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance. Both the eligibility for the allowances and the actual allowances themselves have fallen under this Government. So much for its concern about continuing access to education! One group that I believed had been granted access to education as a result of the abolition of fees was mature age students. It is mature aged students who want to pursue second degrees who will be most affected by the imposition of these fees if this legislation is allowed to go through this Parliament.

I want to refer to one or two effects of this imposition. There are many sorts of characteristic mess-ups in the way the regulations which have been sent around tertiary institutions have been drafted. For example, from looking at those regulations is seems to be a correct view that people who have completed a three-year diploma on, for example, education will not be exempt from fees if they seek to upgrade their course to a degree course unless the degree is in precisely the same field as the one in which they took the diploma. That is not a decision about access to education. That is a projection of the view that you sharpen your mind by narrowing it. It has nothing to do with educational access, breadth of education or the capacity to obtain a broader education.

I believe there are quite a few examples of those matters. I want to look at some other examples. Some of the effects are indicated by the response from universities to the proposed legislation. Griffith University estimates that it will bring in $10,000 in fees. The University says that it will not collect the fees because it is not worth its while. That is an absurd result in terms of that University. There has been the response from the university vice-chancellors who are not people who exactly bounce on radical pogo-sticks every day of the week and project their views about social change in an innovative manner, but they are very concerned about this issue.

The other matter, of course, is the impact on research. Senator MacGibbon made some comments about research. I share his views about its importance in the national scene. He said that Australia has a poor record of research. That is not really true. Australia has a poor record of research in private enterprise. It does not have a bad record of research in terms of government initiative, government-sponsored research, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and so on. If the honourable senator examines the figures as distinct from the rhetoric, he will find that is true. He touched on it himself when he suggested that it was as a result of tariff policy that we had such a poor record. Tariff policy has not affected government research; it has affected private enterprise research in Australia. I share the view that more should be done about Australia's research effort. The important point about it is that 40 per cent of university research, which is an important aspect of Australian research on a number of issues, is carried out by graduate students. I think that is a figure which should be borne in mind.

The Williams report made the comment that the highest proportions of graduate students in Australia pursuing second degrees were in the disciplines of agriculture, engineering, education and the natural sciences. Day after day, we see comments from the mining industry and elsewhere about a chronic shortage of professional engineers in Australia. That is true. Even if one takes the view that the purpose of education is to serve the mills of industry in this country-I do not take that view-it is not succeeding because we are not producing enough engineers or agricultural scientists, for example, and we are not producing enough highly qualified people in the natural sciences or in disciplines such as the soil sciences, geology and areas like that which are of considerable importance but which again are areas in which there is a shortage of highly skilled people. Yet it is on these areas which carry the highest proportions of second degree students that the imposition of fees will bear most heavily.

I want to say a brief word about college amalgamations and why I support the amendment moved by my colleague, Senator Ryan. I emphasise the Opposition's objection to college amalgamations by quoting the Minister for Education in Victoria, who described the college amalgamation proposals emanating from the Review of Commonwealth Functions as:
. . . unilateral, blunt, insensitive and ill considered, disclosing no appreciation whatever of the problems involved for staff, students and institutions.

He went on to object to particular amalgamations such as those involving the State College of Victoria, at Hawthorn, the Institute of Early Childhood Development, which plays a special role in the education life of Victoria, and the Institute of Catholic Education. I appreciate that since then some of those problems have come nearer to being dealt with in a more effective way.

We on the Government side-I am sorry, I am ahead of myself; I should say on the Opposition side-do not retreat from saying that there were too many colleges of advanced education created in that phoney boom of the late 1960s and early 1970s. We do not retreat from that at all. What we say is that amalgamations, such as the one at Townsville between the Townsville College of Advanced Education and the James Cook University, to which the Queensland Government has properly objected, are being carried out at the point of a gun. They are told: 'Do this or we will cut off the money'. That is not a way to achieve results in this area. Well, it may be a way to achieve results but it will not do much for the morale and efficiency of academic communities. It is a bandit approach to government. This is the main objection we have to it.

The effects on morale on the college campuses and so on, with very little assurance about job security and things of that kind, have been quite shattering for any senator or member of parliament who has bothered to go to those colleges in Victoria or Queensland, as I have done. The Government is damaging a resource. The skilled resources of colleges of advanced education and universities are being damaged. That resource is very important to the future economic life of this country and to the wellbeing of the population, not just this year but 10, 20 or 30 years ahead. If the resources and structures are run down, as this Government has allowed them to be with its ad hoc, ill-considered policies, as the Victorian Minister described them, it is immensely costly to build them up again. That is something which I do not think is adequately considered in the policies of this Government.

The absurdity about the amalgamations decision is simply that it was taken by a bunch of educational hillbillies, by Ministers a couple of whom are graziers, a couple of whom were lawyers and a few people like that. It was not a decision made on educational grounds which related to any educational priorities. That is the whole problem with this Government. The Government is not looking forward in terms of making decisions for the future about educational priorities; it is concerned with one-off stunts like the so-called razor gang. As long as it carries on with this one-off stunting, we will not have good government and we will not have a secure and a steady future for the education system in this country. These were not decisions made in the light of educational priorities and the Government parties education committee had nothing to do with them. The members of that committee found out about the decisions, as we did, after they had been made. That is not good government, because they were not consulted about these issues and they should have been. They are here on big salaries, representing people, and they should have been consulted.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true but the TEC came up with the original list. The 30 colleges were named by the TEC.

—No. We will take that matter up at the committee stage. The honourable senator is talking about 30 quite different colleges which were named by the Tertiary Education Commission in its report and the razor gang, in its ineptness, I suspect picked up the wrong list. We can discuss that at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I want to say something about the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill. I have very limited time but I just want to say this: The situation in Australian schools is at a crisis point. It is at a crisis point because of the same sort of decision-making by this Government which has been apparent in relation to post-secondary education. Anybody who is concerned about the future of this country must be concerned about the current crisis in schools with kids turning off institutions, just turning away from them, because those institutions are not supplying the needs which a society like this should be supplying. Very big educational questions are involved in that issue. But how does the Government tackle it? It has been tackling it by running down the government schools sector and giving a bit extra to non-government schools because, I understand that is where the elite of Australian society is supposed to be taught. This has been done in defiance of the advice of the Schools Commission and I think in defiance of the views of most serious educational bodies.

The Schools Commission has had a continually difficult task in coping with the needs of government and non-government schools equally. In 1977, it objected to the transfer of funds from the government to the non-government sector. In 1979-81, it returned to the subject in its report for that triennium. I refer to the results obtained by the Schools Commission which are pointed up in the more recent report of the Schools Commission. The figures show a shift in Commonwealth funds from the government to the non-government sector, general recurrent funds for government schools having fallen by 4.1 per cent and general recurrent funds for private schools having increased by 53.7 per cent. The same sorts of changes-I do not have time to give the order of those changes now-are taking place in relation to capital funds. The Government is developing an imbalance between the two sectors of education which, as a result of earlier Schools Commission activities, had begun to work together in a way which was in the interests of a cohesive society in this country. This Government is not concerned about those sorts of things. It should be and, if it continues not to be concerned about them, it should no longer remain in government. We will be seeing that that is the case at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are speaking tonight about five different Bills which deal with the educational expenditure of the Commonwealth in the next year. Though I intend to speak primarily on the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill, I want to say a few words about the other Bills that are in this package. I am concerned and must be concerned as a Government senator who has in the last few months received hundreds of letters not only from students but also from teachers and organisations that have expressed concern with aspects to education expenditure. I believe that there is concern about that in the community. There are, of course, opposite views. There are people who take the view that those who are educated are in a privileged situation and are obtaining more than they should in a community in which moneys are short and needs are great. On the other hand, I believe that there is a very considerable need for people in this country to become highly educated and highly trained. If Australia, as part of the Asian area, is to become a country which is able to offer expertise and skills and to provide the type of product that is attractive to countries in our region, we have to attack more and more the problem of educating the people of this community. I think that this is one of the most urgent needs facing this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that the Menzies Government made a great attack on the problems of tertiary education. It can be said that during that time there was a great deal of improvement and progress in the tertiary field, that the initiatives which that Government and subsequent Liberal governments provided were such that we achieved a great deal in improving the standard of education in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a long while ago.

—The honourable senator is quite right; it is a long time ago. It is important now to continue that initiative. I am somewhat concerned that, because of other demands upon us, we are not successfully meeting some of the needs. I realise that during this debate objections will be taken to the Bills and some attempt will be made to amend them. I believe that it will not be possible for the Senate to amend the Bills.
—Why not?

—Just listen for a moment. I remind the Senate that, under section 53 of the Constitution, the Senate may not amend proposed laws imposing taxation or proposed laws appropriating revenue of moneys for the ordinary annual services of the government. There is no doubt that the legislation before us concerning education is one of those provisions. The Senate also may not, under the Constitution, amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people. Likewise, if we were to amend these Bills by taking from the Government certain revenues which it wishes to receive and certain payments of fees which are required, there would be undoubtedly an increase in the burden on the people. For these reasons and for the-
—You would need a better argument than that.

—I do not need a better argument than that. I also point out that I will not oppose the money Bills or the Budget of this Government. I will criticise them. I will make some remarks in this speech which suggest that I think the Government is being unwise in pursuing the present policy in certain directions. At the same time I will not endeavour, as a senator, to superimpose my views on the views the Government has taken in the Budget and in monetary Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that in a number of areas there is need for a review of the policies which the Government has taken. I have read the arguments that have been presented to me by many people about the position of government schools and the payments that are made to private schools. We cannot ignore the fact that there is a rising feeling in this community of prejudice on the part of the Government in favour of private schools. I have been recently to Chadstone High School in Victoria, which has been trying for some years to obtain an assembly hall. Although that school's request was near the top of the list, it has now disappeared from the list at least for the time being. Many of these schools have told me about the situation at what they call the 'wealthy' schools. I think that Melbourne Grammar School has provision for six gardeners but I have been told that money coming from the Commonwealth is being used for a ski lodge. When one hears that sort of argument one realises that there is danger of some moneys being expended unwisely, in view of the limited funds of the Government. As one who supports payments to private schools and feels that they have a just claim on Commonwealth funds, I believe that we have to be careful about ensuring that funds do not go to schools that are in no real need of funds.

Likewise, there is a considerable amount of distress in the community about some of the proposals in the area of amalgamations which the education program in this legislation covers. Some of the amalgamations seem to be absurd. There seems to be no common interest in some of the proposed amalgamations of colleges or colleges and universities. In fact, it will be very awkward for them to amalgamate. I believe that in the first place there should be a reconsideration of some of the proposals for amalgamation. In the second place it should be realised that if there is an amalgamation the amalgamating organisations will incur additional costs, not less costs, in the first year or two following the amalgamation. It is important that people should be able to undertake a course with some confidence and with some expectation that they should be able to complete their course.

Tonight I wish to speak mainly about the reintroduction of tuition fees for secondary and higher degrees, which is covered by one of the Bills before us. I feel that the criticisms which have been made by many people who have written to me should be considered very carefully by the Government. I realise that if fees of $1,000 a year were proposed I would not have had a tertiary education, I would not have been a lawyer and probably I would not be here today.

TALK.START.PARA: —A mixed blessing.

—The honourable senator says that that is perhaps a mixed blessing. He may find some comfort in that. Some people who will be affected by the imposition of fees may not in fact receive the education to match the talents which they have-I do not claim talents for myself-and which ought to be used for the benefit of this community but may be lost to it. I remind the Senate that before the last election the Minister for Education, the Honourable Wal Fife, speaking on behalf of the Government, made a commitment in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: I have given an assurance publicy, and I repeat that assurance, that no proposals are being considered by the Government for the possible reintroduction of tertiary fees.
I do not say that what has been done is in direct conflict with that undertaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been quite a good deal of rationalisation. You are good at that sort of thing. You can rationalise anything.
—Would the honourable senator try to be fair for a moment and just take--
—I have tried to be fair but you are a humbug.
—The honourable senator may hold that view. I take no objection to what he has said.
—If you can speak against it and vote for it you must be a humbug.
—I want to say that I regard that as not being an honourable situation.
—I am sure it is not. But have you thought about it? How do you shave in the morning?

—I am thinking about it. If the honourable senator would only shut up for a minute and listen he would probably realise that actually I am agreeing with him. But it is very difficult to agree with him when he is talking all the time. Probably there were no undertakings, arrangements or considerations at that time. But to change it now is not consistent with what I think is the proper interpretation of what the Minister said. Obviously since then there has been a change of policy and a determination to reintroduce fees. I regret that very much because it seems to me not to be consistent with the general policy which the Government was then expounding.
—It is not consistent with what he said, that is for sure.

—I am glad that we have reached agreement at long last. We have a situation in which the reintroduction of tuition fees will mean that students will have to pay $1,000 a year. It is true, as the Minister pointed out, that this is something like 20 per cent of the cost of tuition. It is a very substantial burden on people who, at that time in their lives, are expected to contribute to fees. As we know, no provision has yet been worked out for any loan arrangements whereby they could be expected to pay. The Canberra College of Advanced Education Students Association has estimated that 60 per cent of its students will be forced to discontinue or to defer their studies if these fees are introduced. I have received the same type of representation from many other groups. It would appear that the groups in the community which will be most affected by the introduction of the fees will be women, part time students, mature age students and students from low income families.

SPEECH.PARA: I know from many personal experiences and from friends of the difficulty students have found in recent years-partly because of the unemployment in the community and partly because of the lack of desire by employers to take on students for a short period-in obtaining part time or vacation work for a period. I believe that this situation adds to the difficulty which the imposition of fees will create. Students should be able to earn for a period during the year. I have seen sons of judges who cannot find work during vacation periods. It is amazing the number of people in this community who have now realised the difficulty which this imposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be a right, not a privilege.

—The honourable senator may say that it is a right. It is not a very important question, but it is very desirable that there should be an opportunity for students in the community to obtain work. If fees are imposed then it will become doubly difficult for them during this period. I also believe that the introduction of post-graduate and second degree fees will seriously affect the number of post-graduate students who will come forward in following years. This will discourage many of our most talented students from realising their potential and therefore from obtaining advance in research or professional training. I do not think we need so much the extra few thousand B.As or LL.Bs. We do need the people with specialised training. If one makes a comparison with other countries, one finds that Australia does not stand very well in relation to the numbers. I have here the 1975 figures of full time enrolment rates by aged groups for Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries and I do not think they have changed greatly since that time. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short table covering these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
