TALK.START.PARA: —There are very interesting figures in this table. For example, if one takes the 15-year-old to 19-year-old age group, Australia has 46.1 per cent engaged in education, Japan has 76.3 per cent and the United States of America has 72 per cent. It is very obvious where the strength of education is. In the 22-year-old to 24-year-old age group it is perhaps even more striking, because Australia has 5.5 per cent engaged in full time education, Japan has 14.5 per cent and the United States has 21.6 per cent. So one has a situation that the countries which seem to be drawing ahead economically are the countries in which people are continuing with their education for a considerable period.
—Well, why do you not oppose the legislation?

—I have already explained that. I have made my protest on this matter to the Minister for Education, to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and I am making it now here in the Parliament. I hope that something will still be done about it.
—Not to the same effect.
—I am doing what I can.
—As long as you vote the right way, it doesn't matter what you say.
—I have a right in this Parliament which unfortunately no member of the Australian Labor Party has. No member of the Labor Party will criticise its policy.
—We normally vote the way we speak though, which is different from you. You speak one way and vote the other.
—The honourable senator says that.
—Well, I am a fairly keen observer of your actions.
—Of course, I know that very often the honourable senator has objections to what the Labor Party decides, but the honourable senator never says it.
—But we are not hypocritical about it. We do not pretend otherwise.
—We can and we do criticise and inform our Ministers of our views.
—You still vote the same way. At least I am not hypocritical.

—How we vote is not of the greatest importance compared with that. What is important are the views which we express. Honourable Senators know and I know that the decision will be made in the House of Representatives by the Government.
—Well, why are we wasting our time? We might as well all go home.
—We are not wasting our time. I happen to believe that the Senate is worth while as an institution. It is worth while for us to represent and express our views as I have done, privately and publicly.
—Not if you do not do so publicly.

—I will not waste too much time with the honourable senator because he is in a straitjacket and I am sorry for him. I am rather more concerned to express the argument which hundreds of other people have expresses to me rather than to engage in chit chat across the chamber with the honourable senator. Australia's research effort is something that I think is terribly important and it is something that has lagged behind some Western countries. Our research could be seriously impaired by this lack of post-graduate students. The best post-graduate students I know of do something like 40 per cent of their basic research in various universities. It is important that they sould continue to do that. Tonight Senator MacGibbon said that it was very undesirable for students to take a year off work, earn money and then go back and recommence these things. I think that is correct. It is important that young brains should continue to do post-graduate work. One of the problems is that if they do not do that then the community at large will suffer. Individual students will otherwise have to use their education for financial reward. They do this and they obtain some personal satisfaction, but it is a fact that the individual already pays for higher education through hard work, financial privation and income which is forgone.

SPEECH.PARA: The future employers of students use the student's education to the benefit of the corporations or public bodies concerned and society at large benefits from a better educated population and a diversity of interests and skills within the community. So it is, as we find in the argument, that the 'user should pay', as occasionally he does and the user which gains very much from the benefit of post-graduate work is often the financial corporation. The user which gets the person of great interest is not paying in this case. The fee here is being paid by the student. One of the other problems with the introduction of fees is that certain categories of post-graduate students will be discriminated against, for example, particularly those who do not have post-graduate awards and thus have to support themselves. Another case is the part time student. As we know, full-time staff will be exempt from these fees, but part time students must pay, although in some cases their salaries were decreased by a decision of the Academic Salaries Tribunal earlier this year. Some information on this subject was given by Professor Low, the Vice-Chancellor of the Australian National University. In a letter which he wrote, and which is recorded in the House of Representatives Hansard of 22 October 1981 at page 2387, he said:
The particular issues over tuition fees about which I have pressed my concern, but unsuccessfully, are:

(a) In view of the exemptions from tuition fees which have been agreed to, tuition fees for research students will fall upon those least able to pay for these, the relatively small minority who whilst accepted as suitable by the university are not the recipients of any exempted awards. This, I have to say, is a matter of considerable concern to us, particularly since there has been a reduction in the numbers of Commonwealth Postgraduate Awards since 1977 of 16 per cent.

I suggest that it is important that at this time there ought to be an increase in post-graduate awards. If fees like this are going to be imposed on students then at the same time the number of awards should be increased so that students of great ability will gain the benefit.

I turn to another question. What will be the income gain from the imposition of fees? They will yield a minimal revenue. The Federation of Australian University Staff Associations, known as FAUSA, has estimated that revenue in 1982 will be about $3m before deducting administrative costs. The Government has said that it believes in the ultimate about $20m a year will be netted from fees in, I think, the third year of the scheme. But FAUSA has claimed that unless fees double, or higher degree students double in number, such a figure seems to be rather optimistic. The problem therefore, is that we will gain very little from the imposition of fees and at the same time we will probably cause very considerable hardship for a number of people.
I mentioned that this is not a case in which we can expect the user pays principle to produce very much benefit for Australia. In a recent publication FAUSA said:

Who are the users of specialist education at advanced levels? Certainly, the individual student will use his/her education for financial reward and/or personal satisfaction. But the individual already pays for higher education through hard work, financial deprivation and income foregone. The future employers of students use their education to the benefit of the corporations or public bodies concerned, and society at large benefits from a better-educated population and a diversity of interests and skills within the community.

It seems therefore that the proposed imposition of fees will not mean that the actual user will pay. It also has been argued that one of the problems is that there is some discrimination in this proposal to impose fees. It is said that there is discrimination against universities compared with the colleges of advanced education. In another publication FAUSA said:

Almost 13 per cent of students at universities are engaged in study for Masters or Ph.D. degrees. Less than 1.5 per cent of students in Colleges are studying at this level. Colleges (excluding Central Institutes of Technology) have a high level of students enrolled in postgraduate diplomas-almost 37 per cent compared with less than 4 per cent in universities. But these diploma students have been exempted from the fees.

Therefore, it is suggested that there is some unfairness and some discrimination in the way in which these fees will be imposed on students. We know that many of the Australian universities, including the University of Adelaide, Sydney University and the Griffith University, are unwilling to collect fees. If the fee proposal takes effect, the Government will face the embarrassing prospect of open defiance on the part of some of the more august institutions in this country. About 20 per cent of Australia's research is performed in universities, the major areas being social sciences, agriculture, drug and medical research, veterinary science, engineering, radio astronomy and the earth sciences. Altogether post-graduate students do approximately 40 per cent of the basic research in universities.

I believe there is a problem because we have in this country a need for much greater post-graduate work. We must, to ensure Australia's future, make certain that we have more people doing post-graduate work. Recently I wrote to the Prime Minister following the receipt of correspondence which I know was sent to him by representatives of the universities. I also had discussions with the Vice-Chancellor of the La Trobe University who pointed out to me that one of the problems was the lack of consultation about the proposed imposition of fees, that in fact if more money was desired to be obtained by universities there ought to have been better consultation to find the best proposal to be introduced to obtain those funds. He pointed out to me that the university had not been consulted as to what were the greatest priorities for a reduction in expenditure. He said that if the university had been consulted the imposition of fees on post-graduate students would certainly not be one of the high priorities. I therefore suggested that the universities be given the opportunity to suggest the alternate areas where expenditure might be saved before the decision was implemented. Unfortunately, the decision has been implemented.

Unfortunately, as has been pointed out by people who have written to me-namely, Professor David Allan from Monash University and Mary Hiscock from the University of Melbourne whose courses will probably cease in 1982-students will continue in the courses they are in but people will not be able to come into the courses. The courses related to international economic finance and matters which could be of great value to the economic community in this country. I believe it is unfortunate that this decision has been taken. In fact, this is one decision that ought to be reconsidered at this time because it means that the chances of Australia becoming the Sweden of the south, of becoming a country with a people of considerable training who will be able to assist here and in Asia in developing our trade may partially be lost.

I believe the Government has a limited amount of funds. In regard to education it has had to cut back in various areas. There are some restrictions. There are reductions in the number of teachers in other areas which have called for some changes. But I do believe that changes in some of the areas have been unwise. I hope that whatever happens following the carriage of this legislation the Government will not stop looking clearly at this subject in the hope that there may be changes in the future and an important increase in post-graduate awards in future.

I support the legislation for the reasons I have given. I do not believe it is a case for this Senate to change the Budget or money Bills of this Government. But I believe the Government should pay close attention to the criticisms which have been made in this chamber and I hope it will do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill and the other education Bills we are discussing in a cognate debate tonight range over a number of important items in relation to tertiary and secondary education in Australia. These Bills are of the utmost importance and import. Therefore, I think it is necessary to take a wider view than many speakers have so far taken in this debate. I want to raise the general issue of funding of education in the economic life of this country. Unfortunately, the public discussion of the economy that generally takes place in the media and elsewhere tends, probably of some necessity, to look at the next quarter, the next year or, at the most, the next two to three years until the next election. Implicit in that type of debate is that the economy today is basically the same as the economy of yesterday. However, over the years, almost imperceptibly, our economy has changed in its fundamentals.

SPEECH.PARA: If I may elaborate on that issue, in 1947, 54.7 per cent of the working population in Australia was involved in the production of goods. In 1981 this had fallen to 36 per cent. Employment in the service sector-I define the service sector in the economic sense, and it is fairly broad-had increased by a staggering approximately 300 per cent. Likewise in the 30 years in that period since the War to the 1978-79 financial year, which is the bench-mark for which I could obtain figures, it is interesting to note the following facts: The service sector had risen to be the dominant contributor to the national wealth with 37.9 per cent of the gross national product compared with 4.5 per cent from mining, 7.3 per cent from primary industry and 19.4 per cent from manufacturing industry.

I think it is about time that we started to reorient our thinking in this country to find the basis of our economy. The point of raising these particular issues is that tonight we are dealing with education and educational funding. This leads directly to the notion of human capital. The definition of human capital is normally taken to be the skills, dexterity and knowledge of the population. I intend to use that type of definition. My party contends very strongly that the competence of management and skills in the work force, particularly those engaged in the service sector, determines the ability of enterprises to obtain and utilise our essential resources. In other words, our capital enterprise, our materials and our technology are only as good as our skilled manpower.

The concept of human capital, of course, is not new. Unfortunately, as we have already seen in this place in the last couple of weeks, it tends to be perverted in debate. I think probably the person who has done most in structuring this economic theory is Edward Denison. In his words and documents which have been produced in relation to the American economy I think we find a fundamental linkage with educational expenditure. It is his contention that two-thirds of the growth in the American economy is directly attributable to educational expenditure. Let me repeat that contention: Two-thirds of the growth in the American economy is directly attributable to educational expenditure. I believe that his calculations could be easily extrapolated to the Australian economy without too much dent in those percentages.

This is not to deny that physical capital plays a dominant role in a country's economics. What I am saying, however, is that the growth in economies such as the Australian, American, Japanese and West German is based very strongly on the growth of the new technological and biotechnological enterprises. In other words, it is in the expansion of knowledge, skills, imagination, ideas and insights of our population that we find the economic answer to the problems which confront us.

Unfortunately, for the past three decades we have found that while federal governments have been quite willing to contribute directly to the growth of a variety of industries in this country, such as car manufacturing, boat building, primary industry and mining industries of one kind or another, very little attention has been paid to the economic viability of investment in education. It is not fortuitous that the major growth industry in America, the computer industry, or the growing industry in biotechnology, are all based on universities. In other words, by putting money into our higher education we can reap extraordinary economic benefits.

We have been expending money on education in this country. Indeed, in the years following 1972 and the advent of the Australian Labor Party Government we saw a rapid increase in those expenditures. I believe that unfortunately for that particular Government the educational sector of which I was a part failed to recognise that type of shift. While some of us may have recognised it, I felt that we did too little to promote what was a useful and a thoroughly respectable economic trend in Labor Party expenditure, at least in the early 1972-73 period. Unfortunately, in the last Hayden Budget there was a destruction of the triennium funding which has bedevilled this country ever since. But I do not think that that should necessarily take away from the innovative approach to educational funding which was taken at that time. I believe it is a pity that that type of trend, once it was started, was stopped so prematurely.

The points, then, seem to me to be relatively clear. If we are to have in this country a technological society and if we are to follow the inbuilt logic of the economic changes which have occurred from 1947 to 1981, then instead of looking for some pie in the sky of reindustrialisation or whatever it is that we are on about in this country when we are trying to cut educational funding, what we ought to be about, quite deliberately, is moving larger and larger proportions of our gross national product into education. We know that we can get a much better spin-off if we put money into education than if we put money into almost any other area that one can think of. That was not the case in the past. It was not the case in industrialisation. It is the case now because we are in a different ball game.

I have discovered since coming to this place that it has great feelings for the past but, unfortunately, its view of the future seems to be almost myopic. When we go past requesting pencil and paper from members of some of our departments which supply honourable senators with the wherewithal their eyes glass over. They are very heavy on pens and rubbers and paper, but when we start talking about some type of computerisation to enable the type of work that we have to do to be done, we get grunts. What is needed is at least some far sighted people to start looking at where we are in the economic race and where we are going. Without any view of the future and without any view of our economy we are doomed to become a second rate country. The types of things that our Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has been talking about and promoting in terms of North-South dialogue are so much hot air because if we do not have the wherewithal we certainly cannot provide it for anybody else. Therefore, we believe that it is of vital importance that the particular sector of the tertiary institutions that can most readily and most directly assist in the growth of those particular industries should be not only exempt from imposts by government but also should be funded deliberately in this Budget.

In the speech that I made in this place a week or so ago I was able to point to department after department that had had funds slashed, that had had major research projects of enormous economic value slashed for the want of a measly $20,000, $30,000 or $40,000. I was able to document what I was saying. The information has not been denied by anybody. I have in writing from heads of the departments concerned information to the effect that some post-graduates will not be re-enrolling or coming back into the system because of these cuts in funding. Departments of Japanese studies at the Queensland University and the Australian National University are to be destroyed. Of all departments, Japanese studies is the one that we should be looking at and promoting. But that entire post-graduate sector will be chopped off. The heads of the departments have said that; I have not said it. The heads of departments have said it in writing. They were willing to go that far. In other words, we will not even bother to learn the lanaguage of one of the leading export-import countries in relation to the Australian economy. We will not even bother to train our people so that they can understand the operations of that country. We will destroy those valuable departments, and they are arts departments. Arts does have an economic value, and so do all the other types of departments that we have in our universities. Those departments do have economic value for this country. It is only those with a very narrow view who see those types of departments and others as not contributing to the growth and the life of this country and to what we can offer the world.

Senator Siddons has proposed a private members Bill through which we hope at some stage to be able to debate ideas such as participatory democracy in our workforce, incentive rewards, flexible scheduling and other types of opportunities to enable our industry base to operate. These types of things are talked about freely. Indeed, even the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) has suggested on one or two occasions that he is in favour of such innovative approaches to industry. That idea at least has got off the ground even if it is still only in the talking stage.

When we come to trying to put the argument that educational expenditure is not a cost but is a direct investment, as is any other investment in any other area of the economy, we are met with glazed eyes. When we get to this proposal in these Bills, what do we find? We find that we are seeking to penalise a group of people who, in fact, have been selected for and who have reached the top of our expensive and very essential educational process. These are the very people on whom this economy depends for its future development.

I put aside completely-I will not even bother to debate- the proposition that those people ought to contribute little bits and pieces to their education. To me, that seems to be such a small-minded, mean and piddling-if it is not unparliamentary to use that word-reason for imposing fees as not to warrant debate. For goodness sake, we are not talking here about 3,000 people or whether we will add an extra $1,000 to their fees. We are not talking about that at all! We are talking about the economic health of this country. We are not saying that this little user should pay or that that little user should pay. How about growing up and getting down to some fundamental debates on education and getting away from this utter rubbish.

We are talking about very real issues in this country. We are talking about funding our research effort. What is wrong with putting some money into the education of these people who will make money. I ask a free enterprise government: 'What is wrong with making money?' Yes, those people are going to do that, and work hard in doing it. The labourer is worthy of his hire. Is the Government saying that that doctor, that solicitor or that technologist should not be paid those wages? Presumably it is not saying that. Those people are worthy of their hire and they should be paid because they are contributing and should be rewarded for making an input. Those people put in far more than they take out. If education did not work that way, we would not fund schools. If it did not work that way, we would not put one penny into universities. The community gets more out of than it puts into education. It is an absurd economic proposition to say anything different.

We have not had one real argument put forward tonight in this Senate to justify these despicable suggestions. I am running out of adjectives to describe how mean the arguments have been in relation to this matter. They have not been far-sighted. The Government has not been looking at economic growth. It has not looked at the matter in a global sense. It has not been trying to assess what we really need to assess in this country. I say: 'Yes, let us fund these people'. What is wrong with that? They will put in and put in handsomely and we will all get the benefit from that. If we do not support those people, those people will not remain in this country.

Several weeks ago, when I made my last speech on education, I made the self-same points. They have not been denied by any honourable senator on the Government side. I said that we are losing people at an enormous rate from this country. Why? If we can get top quality people, people who rise above the herd-I put it in that very colloquial form which Liberal senators may appreciate in the elitist view of education-doing the types of things the Government talks about, that is all right. There does not seem to me to be anything wrong in people actually displaying some talent, developing that talent and moving further and further with that talent. Indeed, if that is the case, it seems to me that only one conclusion can be drawn: If we do not provide the base in this country for those people to do productive far-reaching research, they will leave.

Last time I spoke, I documented one case in the biotechnology area. One such person in the University of Queensland is accepted as the world's leading authority on the subject of oxygen growth in the biomicrobe industry. As I suggested before, that forms the base of 6 per cent of Japan's gross national product at this time and is growing faster than the computer industry. We have the world authority here in Australia. He has put it in writing to me that at this stage he has turned down all offers. But he has acknowledged that the world needs him so he does not feel he can go on much longer researching here. If honourable members wish to read his letter I am quite happy to provide it. It is his cry from the heart which says that we have this talent in this country which we have developed here. That talent should be taken further.

The fact that, given the rate of inflation, we have merely kept pace with funding for tertiary institutions with the funds that we put in last year is not a mode for congratulation but is a mode for wonderment, for scratching our heads and for asking: 'What on earth are we about?' All right, we can talk about putting money into a variety of industries and providing superphosphate bounties. Those matters and the provision of funds for other important areas are talked about at great length. But the tertiary industry and the provision of skilled manpower are neglected. They are neglected badly. I return to the fee issue, not because it is the major issue in these Bills, but because it is symptomatic of the approach taken to educational funding at the tertiary level in this society. What do we know about the vast bulk of those people who will end up paying? The rather nice aspect here is that, while the Government's purpose was to impose fees on students studying for second and higher degrees, now the Government is congratulating itself on the fact that only 3,500 people will pay fees. One wonders why it bothered with the exercise in the first place if it is now going to give us a vast number of exceptions.

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be 20,000 in three years.

—Oh, is that a matter for congratulations? I am sorry. The honourable senator has suggested that penalising 20,000 higher degree students is a matter for congratulations. I am sure that Senator Teague with his own educational background would not deny that we are desperately in need of highly trained personnel in this country. We need to retain and update the knowledge of the people who already have qualifications. Of course, an enormous number of platitudes is mouthed about this subject from time to time. But I will quote one of these nice platitudes mouthed by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) on 2 October when opening the Technology Park in Adelaide. That was time for a speech. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: My concern is that while Australia has an impressive record of scientific and technological invention-
Let us pat people on the back-

we have not performed nearly as well in the commercial exploitation of this talent. All too often promising inventions and ideas have been abandoned or lost overseas for want of experienced entrepreneurs and institional support . . . The tertiary institutions with their research facilities and intellectual force represent a resource for innovation which few industries can match.

I agree wholeheartedly. All that the Australian Democrats are asking is that we put money where those platitudes are. The money has to be forthcoming and in large amounts. Without such a movement this country will not progress in the industries that are leading the world.

I return to the point I made at the beginning-that I am talking not about the base of the economy but about the growth of the economy. That is why this matter is so current. That is where the action is taking place. If we want our economy to stand still, to stagnate, we will not spend money on education. We will slowly slide backwards. If we want real growth in this country we have to foster the real growth industries and pay for it. We have to pay those who give them support. It is as simple, clear and direct as that. If we look overseas we see precisely what has happened. Funds flow through to university research institutes. That is done more and more frequently because that is where the support comes from.

People, upon looking at the comparative costs for students in Australia and other countries, will say that our students are not badly off. I agree that they are not, in terms of fees, compared to students in many of the countries that I have been talking about, but I do not see that as an excuse for Australia to go backwards. What is not acknowledged is that the vast bulk of people who support the research base in the United States and Japan do not operate on a fee basis. They operate as people who, in our terminology, are tutors and who, in the American technology, are instructors. In other words, they carry both their teaching load and their research. They work in the academic community. In our universities, the people that we are cutting off everywhere are our tutors. In other words, we are getting rid of the new blood. I take Senator Teague's point, raised this afternoon in the course of making a personal explanation, that the whole problem of our universities being able to attract new blood in a steady state situation is one which must exercise everybody's concern. But there is a way out. It is to look at our universities as representing a direct investment in our country's economic future, to stop looking at education as though it were a cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or a privilege.

—Or even a privilege. I have tonight stayed away from the whole range of arguments which deal with individuals and their entitlements within the community because I wish to make one point only in what I have been saying. I refer to the economic advantages to this country not merely of failing to impose fees but even of paying people to undertake higher degrees. I would like to give such people a nice wage because, after all, in some fields, such as engineering, at the moment it is very difficult to keep people because one has to live on or below that poverty line that we call our Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme or post-graduate awards. It is expected to be good for the soul. It may be good for the soul but it is rotten for the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Time and time again we thought there was growing up within this community a consensus in relation to our tertiary institutions and funding. Indeed, Liberal Party Ministers reiterated that theme from time to time during the last year. Senator Carrick, in many of the speeches that he made while Minister for Education, repeated that point. We were moving towards a consensus that we ought to be looking at our universities and higher education institutions as a source of skilled manpower; that we ought to be supporting them and considering them from that point of view. The statement of the Minister for Science and Technology which I quoted earlier reiterated that kind of view. Unfortunately, we now find that growing consensus blown apart. We are back to the knockdown bloody battle in regard to education in this country. Once again we are engaged in a brawl concerning where we are supposed to be going in our tertiary institutions when every party in this chamber and in the other place ought to be working together to support wholeheartedly our university students at the second and higher degree levels so that in 10, 15 or 20 years this country will have a skilled, intelligent and innovative work force that is in the forefront of technological development and will carry forward with it this country. We will be living off what it does. Again I ask the Government to reconsider this proposal because it constitutes economic madness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating five education Bills. It is significant that they cover the whole range of primary, secondary and tertiary education. The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill is perhaps the one that has been debated most so far. It provides grants for tertiary education in the States and in the Northern Territory. Two other Bills also deal with tertiary education. The Australian National University Amendment (No. 2) Bill provides, amongst other things, for fees to be charged at that university. Similarly, the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill provides for fees to be charged at that college. The States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill provides for payments to the States and to the Northern Territory in the primary and secondary education fields. Finally, the Non-Government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Amendment Bill does exactly what its title suggests.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to dwell on three of the Bills in particular. I refer to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill, the Bill which relates to the Australian National University and that which relates to the Canberra College of Advanced Education. The reason I intend to dwell upon them is that they will produce a revolutionary change in tertiary education in Australia, namely, the reintroduction of tuition fees at universities and colleges of advanced education. I am not surprised that the Government proposes to introduce tuition fees at this level because in recent times it has done its utmost to undo all of the progressive initiatives of the Labor Government in the field of education. It was only a matter of time before the Government made this assault on students; indeed on those students who, as has been pointed out, should be educated well so that Australia can provide for its future. The assault has been made in this area. During the debates tonight it will be recalled easily that it was a Labor Government that in 1974 abolished tuition fees at universities and colleges of advanced education.

I remember that in my time as an undergraduate student we had a very narrow view of what we should be doing about fees at universities and colleges of advanced education. In those days most of the arguments centred upon universities because colleges of advanced education were not all that numerous. The argument advanced then by students, especially part time students-students who were trying to update their skills or to gain extra skills in order, perhaps, to obtain a better position-was that perhaps they could make sure that the fees they were paying were deductible for taxation purposes. That was a great argument in those times.

It took a far-reaching government and perhaps one particular person in that government to say: 'No, that is not the answer. The answer is to abolish fees at that level'. I remember that argument being put forward before the 1972 general election, perhaps in the late 1960s and early 1970s. We said that when we came to power we would abolish those fees. A lot of people believed that it could not be done. They said that the cost would be too high. But the fees were abolished in 1974 and we must remember that when we debate these Bills tonight. That was a great leap forward in the tertiary education field.

I will return to the fees issue later. That was not the only progressive part of the policy which the Labor Government implemented in 1974. In 1974 the Government assumed full Federal responsibility for the funding of tertiary education. A lot of honourable senators would not remember that prior to 1974 Federal funding for that level of education was not high. However, in 1974 the Federal Government assumed full responsibility for that funding. As I have already mentioned, as well as that there was the abolition of tuition fees. Included in that package of policies implemented in 1974 was the introduction of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme to provide students with finance to enable them to undertake a university or college of advanced education course.

All three of those measures are under attack. It is significant that they are all under attack this year. I will refresh the memories of honourable senators on the Review of Commonwealth Functions, which presented its report earlier this year. It is significant that that report was brought forward after the 1980 general election but before the composition of the Senate changed. It was certainly brought forward then so that a lot of the recommendations made in that report could be implemented at that stage. When we look at the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions or, as it is normally called, the razor gang-I actually heard a Minister use that term today; its use is becoming very widespread-we see that one of the matters listed is that student loans are to be introduced. I remind honourable senators that the report states this:
A loan scheme, administered by tertiary institutions, to be introduced from the beginning of 1982 as a supplement to TEAS.

It is important that we look at that in relation to the Bills we have before us tonight. I remember well, back in 1977, asking the then Minister for Education a question in relation to student loans. Amongst other things, I said this:

In view of the increasing concern at suggestions that the Butcher report will result in student loans replacing rather than supplementing tertiary education assistance scheme assistance . . . will the Minister ensure that additional time is allowed for further submissions . . . to be presented for consideration?
Senator Carrick, as the Minister for Education, among other things in his answer stated:
I make it clear and I repeat that this inquiry is an inquiry into student loans as a supplement to-as an addition to-and not a replacement of student allowances. It is utterly clear that that is so.

When it was mentioned back in 1977 that student loans were to be supplements to TEAS allowances, I took 'supplement' to be defined as something additional to, something that was to be added to the TEAS allowance. Indeed, the Minister said in his reply that it would be in addition to the TEAS allowance. But what has happened with the Review of Commonwealth Functions? It states this:
Changes to TEAS rates to be considered in the light of this additional form of assistance.

It seems to me that the loans scheme is definitely to be used to keep the level of the TEAS allowance down. Back in 1977 Senator Carrick, as Minister for Education, in relation to student loans also stated:
. . . the Government . . . would regard student loans, if adopted, as being not a replacement for but a supplement to allowances.

We could have a nice little debate on semantics about what is a supplement and whether the loans will be in addition to the allowance. But back in 1977, when we were talking about student loans, it was definitely stated that the loans would be in addition to the TEAS allowance which was to be provided. The implication of what is happening now is that the TEAS allowance will be affected. In fact, the TEAS allowance is being affected at present, as we were shown during the recent Estimates committees' hearings. But I mention something else about TEAS. One of the things mentioned in the Review of Commonwealth Functions report which sticks in my mind as something which is to be changed is this:
De facto relations no longer to be an acceptable qualification for independent status.

At the moment certain people, if they are in a de facto relationship and if they have been in that relationship for some time and can show that it is a permanent relationship, qualify as married people and gain independent status. But now a whole lot of moralising old fuddy-duddies, who put together this report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, are saying: 'You cannot be in a de facto relationship and get the TEAS allowance any more. Get married or lose out on your TEAS allowance'. It is interesting to note that the number of recipients of the maximum TEAS allowance is decreasing. A deliberate attempt appears to be being made to make the means test so stringent that TEAS payments will be depressed. Perhaps I can outline what I mean. During the Estimates committee hearings we were told that this year, 1981, 50,000 students are expected to receive the full TEAS allowance. Next year it is estimated that 48,000 will receive the full allowance. There has been a decrease in every category, in the at home, away from home and independent categories. It is quite understandable that if the means test level is not increased the number of people receiving the full allowance will decrease.

The Review of Commonwealth Functions report mentions the rationalisation of colleges of advanced education. That is something which has been mentioned in relation to these Bills tonight. It seems to me that 'rationalisation' is quite an in word. If someone wants to cut back on something or to renege on an undertaking, what does he do? He rationalises. What we are doing in rationalising the colleges of advanced education is cutting back. Perhaps we are not reneging on an undertaking because no undertaking was given. But we certainly are cutting back.

I shall outline one aspect of the razor gang's rationalisation which particularly affects the State I represent. This aspect of the razor gang's rationalisation has effectively robbed north Queensland of an educational institution. I refer to the Townsville College of Advanced Education. In contrast with some other States, there is rapid expansion in Queensland. In north Queensland there is an area with tremendous potential for significant short term and long term expansion. What has been done in Townsville in relation to education? There has been an attempt to force Townsville's College of Advanced Education to amalgamate with the James Cook University. An honourable senator suggested in the debate tonight, it is either a type of shotgun approach or a blackmail approach-I forget the exact words. What will happen is that the Townsville CAE will disappear. It will be merged into James Cook University. Instead of having three tertiary institutions in North Queensland-James Cook University, Townsville CAE and the TAFE college at Townsville-we will have two institutions. Certain people at James Cook University welcome this.

James Cook University is a high cost university with a very high proportion of higher degree students. The 1980 figures show that 17.3 per cent of the students at James Cook are pursuing higher degrees. This is the highest percentage for any university in Australia. It contrasts with 12.6 per cent of students pursuing higher degrees at all other Australian universities. There is nothing wrong with this. James Cook University is a specialist university. Because it has such a high proportion of higher degree students, it is regarded as a high cost university. If the college of advanced education students come into the James Cook University, the cost per student will be lowered and this may be a good thing on paper for the James Cook University. It will not stand out as much as it does as a high cost university. Of course, the people in the colleges of advanced education are not happy about this situation; neither are the people of north Queensland because they have been robbed of a significant institution. From the conversations I have had with people in Townsville, I can see that it is a matter that the electors of Herbert will remember and register their views about at the next election. This Government can kiss Herbert goodbye as one of the electorates it holds. Herbert will be lost not only because of this move against the Townsville College of Advanced Education but also because of a number of other things. This move will play a significant part of the loss of Herbert. The amendment which was moved by one of my colleagues mentioned, in part this matter. It states:

The University College of Advanced Education amalgamations proposed in Newcastle, Armidale, Wollongong and Townsville should not proceed until arrangements satisfactory to both parties to the amalgamation have emerged.

We know that the amalgamation will probably go ahead in Townsville because if it does not the CAE will not receive any Commonwealth funding. The State Government will believe that it will not be able to fund it; so the amalgamation will probably go ahead. That part of the amendment which my colleague moved is quite significant.

I would like to return to the tertiary tuition fees issue. The Opposition opposes this as it would mark a significant reversal of one of the many initiatives of the Labor Government in the field of education. We oppose it on educational grounds. We also oppose it because the Government does not have a mandate for this proposal and it is a direct abrogation of an undertaking of the Minister for Education (Mr Fife). In the Liberal Party policy speech issued last year, no mention was made of the introduction of tertiary tuition fees. It was not even mentioned in the speech that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) issued or in the papers associated with that speech. I think two supplementary groups of papers were associated with it. There was not any mention of the matter.

The obvious implication was that fees would not be introduced. If one were going to introduce fees, one would have mentioned it. As fees were not mentioned, one implied that they were not going to be introduced. The matter of fees has been raised in this place a number of times since this Government came to power. In 1977 Senator Lajovic asked a question of the then Minister for Education, Senator Carrick. Senator Lajovic asked:

Can the Minister for Education, in view of certain recent speculation, inform the Senate whether the Government has any intention of introducing fees for foreign students attending Australian universities, or for students undertaking second degrees?
Senator Carrick in his reply, amongst other things, said:
Rumours are running in certain quarters that the Government intends to reimpose fees for foreign students. There is no truth in that at all.
We all know what happened. In 1980 foreign students in Australia were paying fees. He also said:
. . . we are not contemplating what has apparently been rumoured.
He went on to say:
There has never been, and will not be, an intention to reimpose fees in relation to the primary or co-ordinated degree areas. Nor do we intend to reimpose fees in regard to second degrees.

He said that there has never been and there will not be a reimposition of fees. There certainly has been. Senator Lajovic thought in 1979-two years later-that he had better update his information; so he asked a similar question. He asked:
Can the Minister for Education inform the Senate about the current speculation that fees for tertiary education courses might be reintroduced in 1980?
Senator Carrick, amongst other things, said:

. . . on Tuesday night I informed the media-and through them the people of Australia-that the Government had decided that its policy which it had stated in the past would be continued, that is, that there would be no reintroduction of fees at any level of tertiary education. I repeat that.
Later he said:
. . . our policies have been stated and are clear. . . There will be no reintroduction of tertiary fees.

Granted, that was in 1979. But it is only two years ago that Senator Carrick gave a firm undertaking that fees would not be reintroduced. If we do not want to take those undertakings of Senator Carrick, let us go to the last election campaign. I have a document which is the most telling of all in relation to this Government saying that there would not be any tertiary tuition fees imposed for higher education. I can remember well what happened on 8 October last year. I was campaigning in central western Queensland. Many other honourable senators would have been campaigning and I suppose all the members of the House of Representatives were doing so. The Minister for Education, Mr Fife-he is still the Minister for Education-said:

There continues to be speculation about Government plans to re-introduce fees for tertiary education. I have given an assurance publicly and I repeat that assurance, that no proposals are being considered by the Government for the possible re-introduction of tertiary fees.

We can twist that around all we like, I suppose, by saying that no proposals were being considered then but that the proposals were considered after the Government was re-elected. Any government with any decency, if it wanted to reintroduce fees, would have said so then. One would have expected that if the Government had any decency it would have given an indication that it was going to reintroduce fees less than 12 months after that statement was made. One would have thought that the Government would have waited until the next election campaign, told the people that it was going to reintroduce fees at the tertiary level and let the people give it a mandate or otherwise. The Government does not have a mandate to re-introduce those fees. Because it does not have a mandate, there is no reason at all why we on this side of the chamber should not oppose the reintroduction of tertiary education fees. It is a clear breaking of an election promise. How else can one accept Mr Fife's statement?

How much does this Government expect to raise by reintroducing fees at the tertiary level? To be honest, I am not too sure. Firstly we were told that it might be $8m a year and then we were told that it might be $4m this financial year. Let us suppose the fees will raise $4m this financial year. How does this stand up against the total appropriation for colleges, TAFE institutions and universities throughout Australia? When the Appropriation Bills are passed, over $1,800m will be appropriated for this area of education throughout Australia. In fact, it is a little more than $1,800m but I have rounded the figure. Yet, the Government seeks to get $4m from the reintroduction of certain fees. It is not a word that I use but it is a word that Senator Macklin used about half an hour ago; he said it is a piddling amount. It certainly is but it is not a piddling amount for those students who will be required to pay the fees.

Before the Senate rose in June, we were under all sorts of pressures because the Prime Minister was trying to get as much legislation passed as he could before the composition of the Senate changed. I was amazed then when I heard Senator Baume say-I have not checked his statement because it is so indelibly imprinted on my mind-something to the effect that there would not be any reduction in the number of people going forward for second degrees or higher degrees because, if they do not have a scholarship or some other means of paying their fees, they will be able to get a loan. What a nice state of affairs that would be. How heavy would loans of that amount weigh on post-graduate students. We are going to give them all that worry about the loans hanging over their heads, as Senator Baume suggested might happen, all for $4m a year. Perhaps, as was suggested by way of interjection during Senator Macklin's speech, it could be $20m in three years' time. If it is $20m, how does that compare with a total outlay for education of $1,800m?

Why would the Government bother to break an election promise for $4m or perhaps for $20m in three years' time? I suggest that clearly this Government has in mind the reintroduction of fees at lower levels. This seems to me to be the thin end of the wedge. If we introduce fees for higher degrees and second degrees, it is probably the thin end of the wedge so we can have fees at the lower levels. One might say that the Government has not said anything about that; it has given us undertakings that it will not bring in fees at those levels. But, previously, we have had undertakings that there would not be fees for overseas students and we have had undertakings that there would not be fees for second and higher degrees. What good is an undertaking at this stage that we will not have fees for primary degrees? It seems to me that this is just laying the groundwork for getting fees and getting much more return from that greater body of students who are doing their primary degree.

There are many reasons for opposing tertiary fees. I want to raise just one other issue in the time I have left. If fees are charged for second and higher degrees, we will discourage people in Australia from retraining and updating their skills. In a rapidly changing society, it is imperative that we allow people to have the opportunity to update their skills but some will not be able to do this if there are tuition fees for second or higher degrees. Amongst these, in particular, would be married women who have been out of the work force for perhaps 10 or 20 years. If those women once more wish to take their place in the Australian work force and want to update their skills by going to a university or college of advanced education to upgrade or retrain in the course in which 10 or 20 years ago they obtained a primary degree-the fees would be a barrier to them. These people in particular will be disadvantaged if fees are charged for second and higher degrees.

This evening, members of the Opposition will be outlining their clear objection to the reintroduction of tuition fees at the tertiary level. The Opposition has a non-negotiable stance on this issue. We have made it clear that we will use all the forms of the Parliament that we can to protect students in Australia from a misleading, promise-breaking government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The five Bills before the Senate, which have been debated throughout the afternoon and now during the evening, include two major Bills that come up at this time of the year to distribute money for tertiary and secondary education from the Commonwealth to the States. There are three other Bills, two of which give power to the Australian National University and the Canberra College of Advanced Education to raise tuition fees. The other Bill, the Loan Guarantee Bill, affects secondary education. From what I have heard of the debate so far, there has been a concentration upon what are seen to be cuts in the Commonwealth's provision for education generally in Australia. This emphasis upon cuts has grossly distorted the real facts of the Commonwealth's provision for education and I believe that it has distorted this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the facts of the matter in regard to these Bills? With regard to tertiary education in Australia, there is for this year a real increase in the amount of money the Commonwealth is distributing in respect of the total of moneys going to universities, colleges of advanced education and the technical and further education area. There is a real increase in this year's provision for tertiary education in Australia. This is set out very clearly on the first page of the expert report on which these Bills are based. The increase, adjusted for real terms, is from $1,865.3m to a figure for this year of $1,867.55m. It is an increase of only $2m in that vast amount. I prefer to call it a plateauing, that is, the same level of increase. It is certainly not a cut and certainly is not a drastic cut which has been the premise on which most of the speeches we have heard in the Senate today have been based.

Following the vast increase in public resources for education through the 1970s, the Commonwealth Government now continues to maintain that high level and there is not the same call for further increases given the vast turnaround in recent years. This has been directly referred to by Professor Karmel, the Chairman of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, in a speech he gave-the first Archer Memorial Lecture-in June of this year. I wish to refer to a number of tables in that speech. In due course I will seek to incorporate in Hansard three of the tables from Professor Karmel's speech. One of them sets out the proportion of gross domestic product which has been committed to education in Australia. Back in the mid-1950s, 2.35 per cent of GDP went towards education in Australia. That grew to 2.98 per cent buy the late 1950s and it is now double that. The present figure is 6 per cent of GDP. The table sets out a steady progression in the proportion of gross domestic product expended on education in this country. In the last four years, that figure has been steady at about 6 per cent. That is not only Government spending; it is a fair estimate of all resources devoted to education in Australia. The table, as it will appear in Hansard, clearly sets this out. The sources for Professor Karmel's figures are Melbourne Studies in Education, the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission.

We have heard people lamenting the so-called cuts in education funding. The speech today from the Australian Democrats' spokesman, which was more appropriate to the situation 15 years ago, referred to the urgent need to increase our national investment in education. As honourable senators know, I have constantly urged the Government parties to allocate a high and increasing proportion of our resources to education. The level of expenditure has been maintained for the last four years at about 6 per cent, which is about three times what it was at the beginning of the 1950s.

The second table of Professor Karmel sets out the proportion of 15 to 19-year olds engaged in full time study. In the mid-1950s that proportion was 18.2 per cent. Five years later it had grown by another 10 per cent. By the mid-1960s it was 33 per cent. Today it is more than 47 per cent. There has been a steady progression over those 25 years from 18 per cent to 28 per cent, 33 per cent, 42 per cent and 47 per cent in the census of 1976.

The third table, which has been talked about in a number of speeches tonight, contains a comparison of involvement rates for tertiary students in Australia with other countries. In the list, which is taken directly from the 1981 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development figures, Australia is mid-way in the ranking. It is true that the United States of America, Japan and Canada have much larger proportions of students involved in tertiary studies. However, Australia is a middle ranking country. We outrank Norway, Sweden, New Zealand and the United Kingdom. The figures that have been cited from the Australian Union of Students may be partly comparable with these figures. TALK.START.PARA: —Why has there been a 0.4 per cent decrease in funds for universities and colleges of advanced education and a 6 per cent increase in real terms in funds for the tertiary and further education sector? Overall, that balances out the $2m increase I spoke of earlier. Why is there such restraint or, as I put it, plateauing? Why is there the same level of commitment to tertiary education? I believe that it is because in 1975, 1977 and 1980 the Liberal and National Country parties were elected on the basis of economic responsibility and a program of spending restraint. This led directly, after the 1980 elections, to the Review of Commonwealth Functions, which in turn led to the famous razor gang conclusions. That report led to an overall 1.5 per cent decrease in Government spending. I know that a lot of newspaper editorials regarded that as too small a decrease or cutback in the level of Government funding. However, what was the cut or the decrease in respect of universities and CAEs? It was just 0.4 per cent.
—Was your committee consulted?

—No, the back bench committee concerned with these matters was not consulted. The Cabinet sub-committee made Cabinet decisions. I am referring to the basic policy, endorsed by the people of Australia in three elections, that the Liberal and National Country parties would exercise economic restraint. I happen to be a strong spokesman for the education provisions of the Government. But am I, as one Government member, to say that all the other 26 portfolios of Government can be touched in this review but not education? I happen to be interested also in social security. Should I say: 'Do not touch that'? As it happened, social security was not touched by that review. I believe, as one member of the Government team in this Parliament, it is being responsible to have a small decrease in the provision of education moneys.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to the area in which the decrease is to occur. Clearly that can be seen in the partial re-introduction of tertiary fees. The first issue that I have tried to canvass is the level of resources that the Australian Government is making available. I believe that this continues to be at a high level. Nearly $2 billion has been made available for tertiary education. That does not represent the kind of massive decline that some honourable senators have argued in this debate. In fact, I have a pile of letters from the students and staff of some universities, not least from a large group from Sydney. The letters are all in the same terms and they all ask: Why has the Government reduced in real terms spending this year on universities and CAEs by 5 per cent? That is a load of nonsense. There has not been that decrease.

The second political issue discussed this month has been the autonomy of academic bodies. Some small crowds of students and staff have gathered in universities and some colleges this month. The loudest cry and the first plank on their agendas has concerned the question of autonomy. Reference was made to Deakin University. The proposition here was that the Commonwealth was providing funds for 11 engineering schools in Victoria. The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission had recommended that there be some reduction in that number so that it can concentrate on education resources for engineering students and provide better training for engineers. The Deakin University was among those being considered in that context. When the Government made a decision on the ground that the taxpayers' money has to be used wisely and responsibly there was an outcry from some academics in Australia about autonomy. For the life of me, I cannot see how that decision was other than a responsible decision in the resources area. Did the Commonwealth Government purport to interfere or even interfere in any factual way with the way engineering was to be taught in Victoria or with the appointment of the staff which would be doing the teaching? Academic freedom in these respects was entirely preserved. Indeed, academic freedom is preserved direcely by statute by the parliaments of the States. This is not a question of autonomy. It is not a question of academic freedom. It is purely a question of political opposition to the Government's proper decisions about resource levels.

Similarly, there has been some criticism of the Government's decision to amalgamate within the whole body of tertiary education institutions some 30 colleges of advanced education. Twenty-three of those amalgamations are proceeding and three more are just about to be finalised. Only in four cases is there some real difficulty that may involve a proposal in this Bill whereby the Government will put money into an unallocated fund for availability to those colleges when amalgamation takes place. I believe that these amalgamations, based upon resource decisions about the taxpayers' money, are appropriate ways of ensuring that we are providing in the best way for students in each of the States in the areas in which these colleges are providing courses.

The third political issue to which I referred earlier is the implemtation of fees. Senator Colston, who spoke before me, and some other honourable senators have referred to this as a broken promise. Indeed, some reference was made to this by the Opposition spokesman on Education in another place, the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins). He referred to some statements of mine at university campuses. He said: 'Senator Teague is really an irresponsible senator because he has been going around saying that you can say anything in a election context. Of course it does not matter that there is some inconsistency between a statement that he may allege was made by the responsible Minister at election time and then the decision of the Government to see a partial reintroduction of fees.' I want to assure the honourable member, as I have done personally, that I seek the highest credibility and honesty in statements that are made in an election context or that are made at any time by politicians. What riled me was that at some of these university meetings at which I spoke this year, students and others were saying: 'Your Minister is a liar. He promised that there would be no fees. Lo and behold, there now is a partial reintroduction of fees'. That is not true. In fact what was said in answer to questions during the election campaign by Minister Fife was that the Government was not at that time contemplating the reintroduction of fees.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just not true.
—I am quick to agree that that is not a promise that there will not be a reintroduction of fees. Nor is it a-
—You are splitting hairs.
—It may be that there is some degree of splitting hairs. I do not seek to split hairs. I want to react to the interpretation that some have made that the Minister is a liar. I reject it utterly.
—Of course he is.

—It is not true. It is in that respect that I want to clarify and repeat now what I have said on some university campuses. I believe that the Minister stated what he believed to be true at that time, and that was that the Government was not contemplating the reintroduction of fees. It is a limited reintroduction of fees. Some have said that this is a very small, miniscule amount. All I can say is that for this calendar year the amount of money involved is estimated to be $8m, and in a full year-when in three years time the full process has been taken-the estimate is $20m. If $1,000 is the maximum per capita amount of any one student's fee, that leads to an estimate of about 20,000 students involved. That is about 10 per cent of the higher education students in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: To gain some contribution towards the cost of the tuition of that 10 per cent of university and CAE students is not a miniscule nor an insignificant amount. It compares, for example, with $163m expended last year on the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme with respect to 90,000 students and compares with about 330,000 students altogether in universities and CAES. This Bill introduces an amount of about $8m in revenue to be gained from fees, which is about 10 per cent of all students eventually making some contribution to the cost of their own tuition. But that amounts to less than 18 per cent of the cost of the tuition of a student who is paying the fee. It is now a fact that an average undergraduate course in a year costs the taxpayer about $6,000. The maximum amount that is required in any one year by a fee-paying student-that is the small minority of students-is $1,000. The cost of that tuition is considerably higher for post-graduate students and their proportion will be less than 18 per cent.

I also note that the reintroduction of fees does not relate to all post-graduate students but rather to what I term the fourth category of post-graduate students. The first category competes, in an open way, for Commonwealth post-graduate awards and students in that category will be exempt from the fee. The second group receives university research grants. The third group receives private, industry and other benefactions. As long as those benefactions amount to at least $3,500 a year, those students also are exempt from fees. I believe it is undeniable that the first three categories of post-graduate students are those who are most capable and best placed to take on post-graduate awards, university research grants or other benefactions. It is the fourth category, the group that has never had the support from those three types of student finance, which will have to contemplate paying up to 18 per cent of the cost of their tuition. Senator Colston says that it is a light matter or it is somehow trivial for the Commonwealth to say that that $1,000 may be available by way of a loan. The important question is that students in that fourth category have already competed for one or other of the awards and the universities themselves determine the priority of those awards. Those who have, as it were, missed out on the scholarships are able to continue with their studies. They are not denied studies, but they will have to make a small contribution. It is estimated that even that amount will be able to be gained by way of loans.

The fourth question that arises in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill is that of the level of research in Australia. A number of honourable senators have referred to this and, in very scathing terms, have condemned the Government for its small allocations to research. There has been a significant increase in the amount of money committed to research in the Budget this year. The Australian Atomic Energy Commission, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, research grants and university grants, the Australian Institute of Marine Science, the Anglo-Australian Telescope Board, the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies and other miscellaneous research bodies last year received $314m, which has been increased by $66m to $380.9m. This is an increase far in excess of the inflation level and it shows, consistent with considerable increases last year and the year before, that the Fraser Government ismaking considerable contributions and increases towards research funding in Australia.

With regard to the impact of some fee-paying students in this fourth category of post-graduate students in Australia, there may be a small and, I believe, not significant impact on research levels in universities and colleges of advanced education. But if I am wrong in that, given the massive amounts that are available by way of direct research grants and provisions, or by way of direct funding of tertiary staff or by funding of the first three categories of post-graduate students, if there is by some chance some significant estimate, then the Commonwealth Government has already made the commitment that it will look again at the number of Commonwealth post-graduate awards that are available in Australia. I identify myself with that and urge the Government to monitor carefully the level of post-graduate students in Australia to make sure that we do not see the kind of misery or decline that the Australian Democrats and some Opposition speakers have so woefully included in their speeches here today. I do not believe there will be that kind of decline and I for one will seek an increase in Commonwealth post-graduate awards if it happens that there is even a small decline. I believe the Fraser Government can hold its head high in regard to the very adequate and responsible provision for research in Australia.

The fifth question, and final question it seems to me involved in this debate, is that of access to education for tertiary students. For the benefit of those honourable senators who looked about the chamber with a little interest, I regarded the first question as one of resources, the second as one of autonomy, the third one of funding, the fourth one of research and the final question being one of access, which was almost entirely the substance of Senator Ryan's speech today and of the Opposition's contribution generally. Senator Button referred to it and he asked me to refer to it when I made my speech. It seems to me there are four questions in this area. The first question is: Did fee abolition in the early 1970s result in a significant change in student composition? The answer from a number of reviews is resoundingly no. The great proportion of students attending tertiary education institutions in the 1940s, 1950s, 1960s, 1970s and even in the 1980s is composed of children of professional and higher income families in Australia, and I lament that fact. I had hoped that the abolition of fees might have led to a much larger proportion of children of lower income families coming on to study at the universities. But the Anderson report concerning the social composition of tertiary standards, the Australian Vice Chancellors' Committee and various other reviews have not found a significant change.

The second question is: Are talented students denied access to tertiary education now? Senator Ryan thinks they are. We had some dialogue, as it were, on that in the Senate earlier today. I do not believe they are. Indeed, any matriculating student in Australia can freely go to any tertiary education institution and enrol for a course. Also, those of lowest means-I talk of the financial means of the family-have full access to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. Whilst I happen to believe that the allowance at the full rate of $49 a week is too low, nevertheless that $49 a week is available to someone whose family income is low. In comparison, some students have zero financial provision because their family income is higher, even though they do not ask their parents for support or their parents may deny them support. I used to advise students for some six years at the University of Adelaide in these matters and try to help students in need. I used to run the University's loan scheme, amongst other things, at the University. Those who had grave difficulties and who, as the saying was, bombed out of university, as often as not were those who had wealthy parents but for whom there was no provision. In addition, there were students who were repeating subjects because they had failed. They are the kind of students who have a very real need. I also am entirely committed to TEAS which gives direct encouragement to those students from low income families to come to tertiary education. But let it not just be glibly said that because there is a partial reintroduction of fees for post-graduate students, somehow or other by some mixed up logic this relates to first degree students and in particular to children of low income families or, as Senator Ryan said, to women. No one has been able to maintain that those groups are being denied access to tertiary education.

My time in this debate is almost up; I conclude by saying that a lot of nonsense and a lot of misinformation has been brought into this debate by the Australian Democrats and from some of the Opposition senators who spoke today. I believe the Government has made responsible decisions and those of us who seek a continuing high commitment towards education in Australia can still glory in the fact that we have at least 6 per cent of our gross national product committed to education.

This Bill embodies the Government's main Budget proposals for improvements in the field of social service pensions and benefits. The Bill reflects the priority given by the Government to ensuring assistance is provided to high need groups. It provides additional assistance for the children of large families and refugee children, pensioners who are paying high private rents and for certain unemployment beneficiaries. The major provisions of the Bill will:

increase the maximum rate of supplementary assistance and supplementary allowances for pensioners and supporting parents and sickness beneficiaries who pay private rent, and vary the method of calculating entitlement;
extend to wife's pension the same general requirements as to physical presence and residence in Australia that apply for age and invalid pensions;
increase the rates of family allowances for third and subsequent children and for children in institutions;
extend the circumstances in which double orphan's pension is payable in respect of refugee children;
