increase the rate of unemployment benefit for those aged 18 and over without dependants.

These measures and those announced in the Budget but not requiring amendment of the Social Services Act demonstrate the Government's continuing commitment to assisting those in the community in greatest need. In this Budget alone the Government has allocated $9,865 million to pensions, benefits and other welfare payments and services provided through the Department of Social Security. Notwithstanding overall restraints on Government expenditure, this represents an increase of $1,265 million more than was spent in 1980-81.

The main reason for this rise, apart from increases in the numbers of pensioners and beneficiaries, is the automatic indexation of the major pensions and benefits, introduced by the Government in 1976, to maintain the base rates of these payments. The full year costs of pension indexation are estimated to be $716 million for increases that will be payable from November 1981 and May 1982 and the Budget allocation includes a sum of $281 million to provide for these rises during the remainder of the 1981-82 financial year.

These figures illustrate not only the cost, but also the degree, of the Government's commitment to its policy of protecting basic pensions against inflation. The Government regards automatic rises in the basic rate of pensions and benefits in line with Consumer Price Index increases as a crucial element in ensuring social justice for people whose major or only source of income support is their pension.

Since coming into office in 1975 the Government's application of its indexation policy has meant that the standard rate of pension has risen by $27.90, or over 70%, in line with Consumer Price Index movements. Sickness benefits for single people aged 18 and over, and unemployment benefits for those single people aged 18 and over with dependants, have been adjusted in the same way. Pension and benefit rates for married persons have also been indexed.

I turn now to the area of supplementary assistance and allowance. As honourable senators are aware, a pensioner, including a supporting parent's beneficiary, who has little or no income apart from the pension, and who pays rent or for lodgings, may presently receive supplementary assistance to a maximum of $5 a week:
$1 of assistance is payable for each $1 of rent with a maximum payment of $5 a week; but
$1 of assistance is withdrawn for every $1 of income in excess of a $1 ''free area'' for single pensioners and $1 for every $2 above the first $2 for pensioner couples.
Supplementary allowance is payable on a similar basis to a sickness beneficiary who has been in receipt of benefit for a continuous period of six weeks.
The Government is conscious that low income pensioners paying unsubsidised market rents are among the most needy groups in the community.

Accordingly, the Government has decided to act to increase the maximum level of assistance available from $5 to $8 per week and to change the income test. It will also remove the overlap created by the independent development of supplementary assistance and rent rebates (or equivalent subsidies) as dual forms of assistance to pensioners renting public housing.

As I have indicated we have decided to increase the maximum rate of assistance from $5 to $8 a week and to liberalise the income test on it. Under the existing income test arrangements a single pensioner or a sickness beneficiary eligible for supplementary assistance/allowance loses all of any income between $1 and $6 a week. To provide some incentive for pensioners to obtain small amounts of private income this provision will be replaced by a tapered income test-the maximum amount of supplementary assistance/allowance otherwise payable will be reduced by one-half of income.

In future, supplementary assistance/allowance will be payable at the rate of one-half of rent above $10 a week to the maximum of $8. For example, a person paying $14 per week rent will be entitled to maximum assistance of $2, at $20 he will receive $5 and the maximum of $8 when rent is $26 or more.
Having established the maximum rate at which the assistance may be payable the income test will then operate to reduce this maximum rate by half the amount of any income.

The rent rebate formulae used by State and Territory Housing Authorities mean that such pensioners are required to pay only some 17-20 per cent of their incomes as rent. The average value of rent rebates for State public housing at June 1980 has been estimated at over $16 a week.

Since pensioners renting from State Housing Authorities receive rebates in excess of supplementary assistance on rents which are often, before rebate, less than private rentals it is proposed to concentrate assistance on pensioners paying high private rentals.

Consistent with this, it was also decided to take action to direct suplementary assistance away from pensioners and beneficiaries who pay only nominal rents. Pensioners paying rents of $10 a week or less would not generally be any worse off than home owners and could be expected to pay rents of this level from their basic pension. Those paying rents of between $10 to $20 a week would receive assistance under the new arrangements although less than the current rates. Rents in this range are still below market rates. In addition, because a subsidy rate of $1 for each $1 of rent paid may encourage landlords to increase rents in line with any increase in supplementary assistance, the rate of subsidy has been changed to one-half of rent above $10 a week. This is intended to reduce incentives to increase rent while increasing assistance to pensioners paying higher rents.
Even with the re-direction of available assistance, the increased rate and liberalised income test will mean an increase in expenditure of some $50 million in the first full year.

This cost also reflects the Government's decision that the changes will not operate to the disadvantage of those already receiving supplementary assistance/allowance. All current recipients, when the new provisions commence, will be able to continue to receive payments according to present rates and conditions until such time as they cease to qualify under these conditions or would benefit from the new arrangements. The estimated cost of protecting the current entitlements of recipients of assistance who would otherwise have been made worse off is of the order of $30 million.

Over 300,000 pensioners and beneficiaries paying rents in the private sector are estimated to benefit from the new arrangements. Approximately 130,000 current recipents are expected to continue to receive their current rate of supplementary assistance due to the savings provision.
The new provisions will take effect from February 1982.

The Government has also decided to increase the rate of the incentive allowance which is payable in lieu of supplementary assistance/allowance to everyone receiving a sheltered employment allowance. The rate of this income test free allowance will also be increased in February 1982 from $5 to $8 a week. Some 8,300 handicapped people in sheltered workshops will benefit.

Mr President, the Bill contains provisions to overcome certain deficiencies in the existing legislation relating to wife's pension; this is a pension payable to the wife of an age or invalid pensioner who is not qualified for an age or invalid pension in her own right.

To qualify for all other pensions a person must both reside in Australia and be physically present in Australia at the time of lodging a claim. Prior to 1973, pensions generally could not be paid to people outside Australia. With the introduction of portability provisions this situation changed and, as it was not necessary to lodge a claim for wife's pension, it became possible for a wife's pension to be granted to a woman living in another country. This consequence, which was unintended, became apparent upon the receipt of legal advice. Thus, as presently drafted, the legislation permits the automatic grant of a wife's pension without the need to make a claim and regardless of the wife's place of residence.

Thus, we have the rather anomalous situation whereby a wife's pension can be granted to a woman who has never been to Australia and has no intention of coming here. To overcome this anomaly the Bill proposes to extend to a wife's pension the same general requirement as to physical presence and residence in Australia for the grant and commencement of pension that apply for age and invalid pensioners. As a result, wife's pension will not be payable overseas unless pension is granted prior to departure from Australia.

There is one exception to the rule that an applicant for an age or invalid pension must be residing in and physically present in Australia on the date the claim is lodged. This exception applies where a person who is in special need of financial assistance ceased to reside in Australia before 8 May 1973, the date the general portability provisions were introduced. Where a pension is granted to such a man, the Bill proposes that wife's pension will be payable to his wife.
The changes in relation to wife's pension will come into operation on 1 November 1981. Women overseas in receipt of wife's pension at that date will continue to receive the pension.

Mr President, the Government's commitment to the welfare of Australian families is reflected in the Bill, which provides real and very substantial increases in the rates of family allowances payable in the case of larger families, as from January 1982.

The rate of family allowances payable in respect of the third and fourth children of a family has been increased from $26 to $39 per month, an increase of 50%. The amount of $39 per month will also be payable in respect of children in institutions. In respect of the fifth and subsequent children of a family, the increase is from $30.35 to $45.55 per month.

Additional family allowance will be paid in respect of some 780,000 children in 540,000 families-containing almost half of Australia's children. The cost of this initiative will be $62 million in the current financial year, representing $124 million in a full year.

To meet a particular problem with respect to refugee children who are not technically orphans but whose contact with their parents is effectively broken the conditions governing double orphan's pension will be altered to extend the provisions to them.

As Honourable Senators will be aware, a person who has the care of a child both of whose parents are dead, or where one parent is dead and the whereabouts of the other is unknown, is entitled to a double orphan's pension of $55.70 a month. In the case of a refugee child, it is often a question of not knowing whether the parents are alive or dead or not knowing where they are. In some cases the parents are known to be overseas, but the parent and the child cannot be reunited and the parent cannot provide economic support. The circumstances of these children are similar to those of a 'double orphan' and so the Government proposes to pay a double orphan's pension to people who are caring for refugee children whose parents are not in Australia or whose whereabouts are unknown.

The rate of the pension is $55.70 a month and, like family allowances, is not subject to an income test or to income tax. Payment is made in respect of children under 16 years of age and dependant full-time students aged 16 and over and under 25 years of age.
Mr President, I would now like to deal with the provisions of the Bill relating to unemployment and special benefits.

Honourable Senators will be aware that, prior to October 1979, the Social Services Act precluded payment of unemployment benefit to a person who was a direct participant in a strike. However, it enabled unemployment benefit to be paid at the ''married rate'' to the spouse of a person ineligible for unemployment benefit on those grounds. The Act was subsequently amended to provide that unemployment benefit payable to the spouse of a person engaged in industrial action was to be at the single rate. A further amendment precluded payment of special benefit to a person not qualified to receive unemployment benefit because of industrial action.

The present legislation permits a situation where trade unions can choose to strike knowing that through the operation of the social security system their members will be largely insulated from the effect of their actions. The Australian public for its part is attacked from two directions. First, it has to bear the personal disruptions, inconveniences and associated costs brought about by the strike. In addition, it is then called upon to meet the cost of providing income support for the families of those involved in that industrial action.

Similarly, there is no good reason why the community should automatically and immediately be expected to assume the normal financial responsibilities of those who are not willing to work, who voluntarily and without good reason give up their job or who are dismissed through misconduct. This is happening at present where the spouses of such persons register for employment in their own right and, if unable to obtain employment, attract unemployment benefit both for themselves and for their ''dependent'' spouses.

There have been numerous cases where wives of strikers who have appeared to have no genuine intention of joining the workforce have registered for work in places such as mining and construction towns where there is no real possibility of employment for them. This has enabled them under the present legislation to obtain unemployment benefit thus transferring to the taxpayer some of the real cost of the industrial action taken by their husbands.

Accordingly, the Bill proposes that a person will be ineligible for unemployment benefit for so long as the person's spouse is disqualified from receiving unemployment benefit because of the spouse being involved in industrial action or being unwilling to undertake suitable work or not taking reasonable steps to obtain such work. Additionally, a person will be ineligible for unemployment benefit for so long as payment of that benefit to the person's spouse is postponed due to misconduct as a worker, becoming voluntarily unemployed or failing to accept an offer of suitable employment.

Consistent with this approach concerning payment of unemployment benefit, special benefit will be withheld from persons not eligible for unemployment benefit in these circumstances, although the Government had decided that the spouse of a person precluded from unemployment benefit and special benefit may be eligible for special benefit at the single rate, with additional benefit for any children of a couple.

The basic rates of unemployment benefit for those aged 18 and over with dependants, and those under 18 who are married, are subject to automatic increases twice yearly as a result of the indexation provsions introduced into the Social Services Act by this Government. However, the maximum rate of unemployment benefit for persons aged 18 years and over without dependants is not indexed. The Government has decided to increase this rate by $4.65 per week from $53.45 to $58.10 per week. The Bill makes provision for this increase, which will apply from the first payment period after 1 November 1981.
I now turn to the matter of people disposing of income or arranging their affairs in such a manner that they avoid the receipt of income in order to qualify for a pension or for fringe benefits.

Pensions are paid subject to an income test and the Government is determined to ensure that the income test operates as it was intended to operate. In other words, it is committed to see that the income test remains an effective mechanism for directing taxpayers' funds to those in greatest need. The Social Services Act already contains provisions which are designed to counter attempts to circumvent the income test. However, due to the proliferation and active marketing of sophisticated and contrived schemes in recent times, these provisions have been found to be inadequate in certain respects and accordingly the Government intends to strengthen these provisions.

I have already announced that it has been found necessary to delay the introduction of these amendments. This delay has been necessitated because of the Government's commitment that the proposed measures will work equitably in practice, will not affect the normal everyday financial transactions of bona fide pensioners and will not impose undue restraints upon the way in which such pensioners manage their normal financial affairs.

Given these policy parameters and the extremely wide range of financial arrangements which are available to individuals in a free market economy, the preparation of legislation which achieves these ends, yet prevents abuse of the system, proved more complicated than was anticipated.
As I have already indicated, work is continuing on this matter and I am confident that the legislation will be introduced during the next session of parliament.

The Government is aware, however, that there is a deal of concern as to the likely structure and impact of the proposed legislation. In my earlier statement of 18 August. I indicated the the proposed provisions would not penalise people who liquidate income-producing assets for such reasonable purposes as the purchase of a home or a car, or to finance a holiday. Similiarly, I said that there would not be any restriction on people keeping reasonable amounts of money in non-interest bearing forms, such as cheque accounts.

The Director-General, with whom the discretion in this matter resides, has indicated that he would not regard it as unreasonable to retain in a form such as a current cheque account amounts of less than $2000 for a single person and $3000 for a married couple. He still has under consideration whether higher amounts would be regarded as reasonable. Some flexibility would, of course, be necessary to cover situations where amounts held in a cheque account could be higher than the levels indicated for reasons not related to pension entitlement, for example, between the sale of one home and the purchase of another.

I would also like to point out to Honourable Senators that it is not proposed that the legislation should penalise people who chose to hold their investments in savings accounts, even though higher rates of interest might be obtainable elsewhere.

While it is necessary to postpone the anouncement of the details of other operational aspects of the proposed legislation, I would hope that the outline I have given will prove to be valuable in setting to rest the minds of many of our elderly citiens.

Mr President, this Bill reflects the Government's concern to assist those in greatest need in the community, at a time when the Government is conscious of the need for overall expenditure restraint. Our approach has been to maintain a steady course, while introducing worthwhile improvements for those whose circumstances are such as to justify a special focus of assistance.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a number of education Bills which have aroused considerable interest in the Australian community. Twelve honourable senators are listed to take part in this debate; four from the Government side and eight from the Opposition side-that is, the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party. I think it is interesting that in the debate so far today, of the three Government senators who have spoken, we have had three different approaches to the problems of education particularly as they relate to tertiary education. Senator MacGibbon's contribution can only be said to be one from a nineteenth century Tory. Senator Missen's contribution was perhaps a little more enlightened. He expressed a great deal of criticism of the Government's approach to this matter although he indicated that he would not vote against the legislation. For the last half an hour we have had the defensive speech of Senator Teague in which he led us to believe that all is good in the Garden of Eden. But, of course, that is not the view of the Opposition. It is not the view of academia. It is not the view of the community at large. The Opposition makes no bones about its criticism of the legislation and the upshot of the passage of the legislation as it relates to the training of a very important section of the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill and related Bills. Principally the Bill that I want to speak about provides funds to post-secondary institutions in Australia for the 1982-84 triennium. Overall it can be said that the funds provided are totally inadequate for the carrying on of paper post-secondary teaching in this country and the allocation will ensure that Australia stays at the lower rungs of the expenditure on education by the member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. We are often regaled by Senator Carrick about Australia's comparative position in many sectors as far as the performances of OECD countries are concerned. I have examined the statement put out by the Australian Union of Students which shows that of the 12 countries that have full time enrolment rates, Australia is at the bottom of the list, surpassed as we are by all of the main industrialised countries of Europe. It shows that only Ireland, New Zealand, Spain and Portugal spend a smaller percentage of their gross national product on research and development, and of course that is exactly what this Bill is about.

It has been adequately stated in the debate to date that Australia needs people who are skilled in up-to-the-minute methods, and fees for secondary degrees will only deter people from retraining, leaving their skills stagnating in an ever-changing world. That is the essential difference that we have with the Government. We are living in a period of advanced technology. We are living in a period in which change is taking place very rapidly. We must have an education system which provides for the right of students to be adequately trained, both in the area of technical education as well as in tertiary and other forms of education. It is pretty clear that, quite contrary to what Senator Teague suggests, in the whole area of the academic field, from the vice-chancellors down-the administrative, and student levels-there is a unanimity that we have not seen for a great number of years about the defects that are apparent in this Government's approach to education.

I do not intend to concentrate at any great length on the dire consequences of the general cuts in education funding. I wish to look at the new measure introduced in the Bill; the reintroduction of tuition fees for second and higher degree students. Clause 6 of this Bill, whole of the Australian National University Amendment (No. 2) Bill and the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill are relevant sections of legislation which it is the Opposition's role and obligation to oppose.

This piece of legislation will undoubtedly have an effect on Australian post-secondary education standards. It will force many students into further hardship and will force many students out of the education system altogether. That is a fact which is ignored by Senator Teague in his contribution to the debate. The decision to impose fees is a blatantly ideological decision that pays more regard to establishing the Government's own Tory credentials, its own discredited economic policies and in the current jargon its dryness. Of course, Senator MacGibbon was referring to the drys in his contribution to this debate, the drys that are making such a mess of the United States economy. This decision flows from the creation of the Review of Commonwealth functions, that notorious band of two titled accountants, two half-smart lawyers and a farmer, as one of my colleagues in the other place described them. The teachers, the administrators, the students, the community, the employers, even the Tertiary Education Commission, have not had any say in this matter. It is not their decision. It is a decision made by a government hell-bent on altering the whole structure of our education system.

I should like to address myself to some of the main points arising from this decision. Firstly, contrary to what Senator Teague said, it is a dishonest decision. I suppose we should not be surprised about that any more, because this Government is notorious for its habit of breaking election undertakings. It deliberately misleads the people; and here in this instance it is happening again. On 8 October 1980, the Minister for Education (Mr Fife), in a letter to the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations, said:
I have given an assurance publicly and I repeat that assurance that no proposals are being considered by the Government for the possible reintroduction of tertiary fees.

There was no ambiguity or qualification about that. There was no saying 'at this time'; that was a clear-cut understanding given to the organisation, and obviously understood and accepted by the organisation. Students have been reminding Senator Teague in his roundabout on the campuses that the Minister has lied. I say that their assumptions are correct.

Only a few months after that statement was made the razor gang came out with proposals. Less than one year after the Government's term of office has started, this legislation for which the Government has no mandate is before us. This Government just cannot be trusted. It is no wonder, then, that the Australian Democrats, when they coined the slogan 'keep the bastards honest' swept the pool and in fact increased their representation in this place, and they did so at the Government's expense. Is it any wonder that students and potential students consider this introduction of fees on a so-called limited basis or limited scale to be the start of a wider reintroduction of fees? There is no doubt in my mind that this is the thin end of a very nasty wedge, and that is the way the student movement sees it.

Honourable senators should cast their minds back a short while. In 1976 the then Minister for Education, Senator Carrick, announced that fees would be introduced along the lines we are discussing today. His Government backed down after huge protests from all over the country. Senator Carrick assured us, both outside and inside the Parliament, that the Government had changed its mind and fees would not be introduced. These assurances have proved to be worth absolutely nothing. In 1979 fees were introduced for overseas students studying in Australia. Again we were told not to worry, that there would be no extension of the scheme to Australian students. Yet less than two years later we have this contemptuous piece of legislation doing exactly what we were told the Government was not going to do. Senator Carrick's promises were useless. He may have opposed fee introductions in the Cabinet and in the party room, but all he got for his trouble was to be shifted sideways from the education portfolio. Mr Lynch, the Treasurer and architect of the 1976 scheme, finally got his way as the razor gang chief in 1981. Mr Fife's pathetic bleatings that this fee introduction is limited cannot be believed. The Government's transparency is laughable. If the consequences of fee introduction were not so severe, we could all pass it off as a good joke. But it is not a joke. The explanation of the Minister for Education for fee introduction, contained in a Press release on 2 July this year, reads:
The financial demands placed on the Australian taxpayer by the education sector will be kept down.

But, as Senator Colston has shown, the estimate for the revenue to be raised by this measure, when the Government finally made up its mind, is a paltry $4m in 1982 and $20m by 1984. Even these excessively inflated estimates show the revenue raising potential of this measure to be a mere pittance when compared to the $1,865m to be spent in 1981-82 on post-secondary institutions.

The point I am stressing here is that this measure will do nothing to ease the tax burden for the Australian people whom the Government so opportunisticly claims to support. They will still be taxed at the same inequitable rates. The working people of this country will still be forced to shell out a disproportionate amount to the tax man while the Liberal and National Country Party Government does nothing to assist them in getting access to the vast range of educational facilities we could offer. To that extent I can share the philosophy expressed by Senator Teague, but this has not been provided for in this legislation.

To the average working taxpayers in Australia, this measure will mean, firstly, that they will still have to pay higher taxes and, secondly, that if they or their sons or daughters struggle through the education system, stacked against them as it is, the final barrier will be a $1,000 university fee. Not many will get over that barrier. If there is any credence at all in Senator Teague's contribution he must surely admit that the lower income groups are not getting into the education race, that they need further financial incentive and assistance if their sons and daughters are to be encouraged into the tertiary education system. Why does not the Government address itself to this problem? Why does it not seek to go about levelling the education system so as to ensure that willingness, knowledge and ability are the criteria for further education, instead of the ability to pay as it currently is now. Of course, we have a government of two different postures-a Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde type of government. I will read what Mr Hyde, the honourable member for Moore in other place, had to say in today's Australian. Of course, he is the leader of the 'dry' in this Government. We are seeing an increasing influence from that school of thought-hard line Toryism which seems to be taking over the Liberal Party.
What does Mr Hyde want to do:
He wants to see a 'user-pays system' replacing the present Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme.
That is quite contrary to and differs from the contribution made by Senator Teague and also that made by Senator Missen. The article continued:
In fact, he makes no secret of the fact that electors he meets are increasingly indicating opposition to free tertiary education.

I do not know what circles Mr Hyde moves in but certainly that is not the view that I have. It is certainly not the views contained in the hundreds of letters and protests coming to members of the Senate and members of the Parliament generally about what is proposed in this legislation.
Mr Hyde talks about a taxation system that should be neutral. He stated:
Under present arrangements we have a situation where the less wealthy and less articulate in Australia are providing money to people from a generally wealthier group-our student population.
What this means is that this privileged group obtains a private commodity for nothing, which guarantees students an expectation of higher life-long incomes.

Of course, the taxation system in this country has a class basis; of course it taxes lower income groups too highly. Of course, it is a taxing system that places an undue burden on the average wage and salary earner in our community. If that is the problem, Mr Hyde ought to be addressing himself to a more equitable taxing system so that we are not in a position where those at the lower end of the scale are contributing to the education of a group of people who may be said to be coming from the wealthier group. We ought to be working out a system whereby the tertiary assistance schemes are providing the necessary financial incentive to children of the lower income groups to come into the tertiary institutions. We should not set about establishing a whole new system. Mr Hyde said:
Universities which constantly call and argue for their autonomy would truly have it. Government would no longer be involved. There would be no need to look at the education vote.

He wants the whole education system to be drastically altered and changed. What sort of government have we when so many different points of view can be expressed in looking at this problem of education?

Government members defend their decision by pointing to the predominance of students from the upper and middle socio-economic background in tertiary institutions. They say that the revolution of access, hoped for by the last Labor Government, has not occurred. No one denies that. Does the Government know why? Has it considered the effects of a world economy depressed since 1974? Has it considered the effects of poor student finances and the decline in recent years of assistance under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme? Has it considered the fact that participation by women students, mature age students and country students has multiplied rapidly, a fact directly attributable to fee abolition? The Government has not considered that. It prefers to go on its own ideological blinkered way and carry out policies which address none of the key problems of access to post-secondary education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true, not true.

—Is the Government even aware of the consequences of introducing fees? Senator Teague, this is what the Minister for Education had to say about this matter just last week. In answer to a question on notice from Senator Watson, the Minister provided this information:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not known to what extent enrolments in 1982 will be affected by fees.
He also stated:
It remains to be seen whether the limited reintroduction of tertiary tuition fees in 1982 will have any disincentive effect.

That was contained in the Senate Hansard of 21 October. How dare the Minister play with the careers of thousands of post-graduate and second degree students with phrases such as 'it remains to be seen'. Perhaps the Minister for Education does not care. Perhaps he does not know of some of the examples from overseas that can be looked at. I will take just two examples. For example, in 1977 in Canada, Ontario and Manitoba shared the dubious distinction of levying the largest fee increases in the country. The result was that enrolment in each province fell by 3.2 per cent. At the University of Wisconsin in the United States, the reverse happened when fees were reduced. What will happen here? The Minister does not know. But he is quite happy to press on with the legislation because he has been told to do so by a Government intent on reducing public sector expenditure, whatever the consequences. I suppose that ignorance is bliss. It will hardly make a convincing slogan for Mr Fife when next he has to walk on to a university campus.

I have no doubt that the effect of these fee charges will be to deter post-graduate and second degree study in Australia. Studies by the Council of Australian Postgraduate Associations and associate bodies show that most post-graduate students are living at levels several thousand dollars below the poverty line and receive financial assistance for earnings well below their needs. A burden of an extra $1,000 a student will tip the balance and tip them out of study and research altogether. I do not believe that we can afford to lose our post-graduate scholars as we have been doing for the past few years. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. We are moving in a direction absolutely opposite to that supported by such conservative figures as Sir Robert Menzies. Unlike his Tory successors, Sir Robert understood that Australia's research capacity would not be subjected to pure financial constraints. In a 1968 lecture, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Any decision made by those in financial authority which limits or reduced the body of postgraduate students is a wrong decision, because by implication, it gives priority to elements other than that one element which is of supreme importance if great universities are to survive and grow.
That statement was made on 12 March 1968 in the second Dunrossil Memorial Lecture.
Of course, the Tertiary Education Commission concurs with this view. In its report for the 1982-84 triennium, it stated:
Participation in higher education in Australia is not high by the standards of many OECD countries, and the increasing pace of technological change will require more rather than less education.
So, ignoring the advice of both its founding father, its own present-day advisory body, international experience and the community at large, this Government ploughs on.

About 20 per cent of all research in Australia takes place at universities. Nearly 60 per cent of basic research-that is, research of an original kind which seeks to map out a complete knowledge or understanding of topics of concern-is carried out in Australian universities. These are the figures supplied to us by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. This is the kind of research that the Government seeks to jeopardise for the sake of its own petty financial and economic gains. Rather than take up the time of the Senate, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard three brief descriptions of the type of research that actions of this Government will threaten. They are examples drawn from the survey conducted by the Council of Australian Postgraduate Associations and are contained in a May 1981 submission from that body to the Federal Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we see those?
—Senator Gietzelt, would you allow the Minister to check those please?

—Yes. This then is the sort of situation that faces us. This is the kind of legislation that the Government has before it in the Senate today. This legislation threatens our basic research effort and places higher education out of the reach of an ever greater number of people. If this sort of thing is extended to all courses of tertiary study, as is the Government's long term intention, I am sure that the consequences will be tremendous. Tertiary education will be a pursuit for the elite, and always for the elite.

SPEECH.PARA: For these reasons, the Opposition is firmly opposed to clause 6 of this Bill. Of course, we have had some instances given of the Governments backfilling on the whole question of tertiary education. I have to agree with what Senator Carrick said in the Senate on 3 April 1979. In reply to a question by Senator Puplick he stated:

One would have to agree that the future development of this country, including its capacity to trade and the living standards of its people, must depend upon a properly based program of research and development. If Australia is to keep competitive with the world outside it must have such a program and with the growing field of technology this becomes more important.

Senator Colston reminded us that Senator Carrick, in reply to a question by Senator Lajovic, said that there would be no recommendation for the reintroduction of fees at any level of tertiary education. Indeed, he criticised the Minister for Education in New South Wales for suggesting that fees were going to be introduced. Finally, the Minister for Education said in the House of Representatives just a week ago:

I want to make it abundantly clear that the Government has no intention of reintroducing fees for students undertaking their first degrees. I repeat that: The Government has no intention of reintroducing fees for students undertaking their first degrees.

MINISTER FOR EDUCATIONParliament House, Canberra A.C.T 27 October 1981 Dear Senator Martin,
I refer to your representations regarding the Government's decision to introduce fees for second and higher tertiary qualifications.

As you are aware, the legislation presently before the Parliament provides for the limited reintroduction of tuition fees from 1982 and specifically excludes the charging of tuition fees for students undertaking courses leading to first awards. It also exempts students who commenced second degree or diploma courses before 1982 from paying fees for these courses.

It is, of course, only reasonable that the Australian taxpayer bear the full cost of the education of students up to and including a first tertiary qualification. It is also reasonable that those who wish to continue their studies beyond the first qualification stage should be required to make a contribution to their education. Under the Government's proposal this contribution represents less than 20% of the average overall cost of educating a person in a tertiary course.

Insofar as the particular question of retention rates at the postgraduate level is concerned, the Government will keep this matter under review. At the same time it will keep under review the level and rate of postgraduate awards which, of course, are examined annually in the Budget context.

You are, of course, aware that our Government has no desire to see a reduction in the number of students undertaking postgraduate studies. It believes that the revised arrangements together with additional research measures such as the Research Centres of Excellence initiatives, make adequate provision for the maintenance and, indeed, the extension of research in Australia.
Yours sincerely, WAL. FIFE Senator K. J. Martin,
Senator for Queensland,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600

Funding for maintenance in the state school sector in Victoria has declined year after year in region by region to the point where no funds at all are being made available for maintenance, for furniture or for general upkeep. There are no cyclic funds. No cyclic work is being done on the maintenance of hundreds of schools across Victoria. I repeat that this Government is pouring funds into elitist grammar schools. Three or four people who have a bit of a bitch about the state education system or who believe they are entitled to something better than the common herd can get together under the guise of perhaps some holy roller organisation and get funds at the drop of a hat to build new schools for a handful of kids while for the multitude of kids the Victorian education system is in total decline.

On 25 September my leader, Senator Button, the honourable member for Ballarat, Mr John Mildren, and I attended in the city of Ballarat a conference sponsored by the Ballarat regional office of the Department of Education. Out of desperation, that Ballarat regional office called together every member of parliament, both State and Federal, whose electorate in any way touched on the region, every shadow Minister, and Ministers for Education from both Victoria and the Federal sphere. The paper we received stated that:
Special problems affecting the Buildings Operations Program will be considered-in particular:
(a) the continual decline in funds available for school building since 1975.
(b) the alarming inadequacy of funding for essential maintenance and upgrade of school buildings.
(c) the apparent withdrawal of some critically necessary Federal funding from Government Primary and Post Primary School programs in order to service other programs.
(d) recommendations for future programs.
The Regional Director of Education of the Ballarat region, Mr Dobell, raised various points in the summation of his report. In paragraph 4.2, headed 'Enrolment declines', he had this to say:
These need to be kept in perspective. In Victoria, net enrolments in the State School System were:
Year 1976-624,107 pupils

The small decline evident in those four years does not justify massive cuts in school building budgets. Maintenance costs for example remain almost unchanged. Likewise, in Victoria, in those years, annually many new classrooms, and schools had to be built to provide for population mobility.

In paragraph 4.4 of that report headed 'Sharing of Education Resources'-the suggestion to share these resources was put forward in an endeavour to try to overcome the paucity of classrooms, the paucity of equipment and the paucity of furniture within the Government system-he had this to say:

Possibly, as government funds are increasingly allocated to private schools, much more positive consideration will need to be given to the sharing of these latter resources with government school communities.

So here is the Regional Director of the Ballarat region so concerned about the way in which the education system has been stood on its head in Victoria that he is now almost pleading for the government system students to be allowed to share the resources, the far better resources, that are being funded within the non-government sector of education. In his conclusion, paragraph 5, he had this to say:

The decision to invite to today's meeting Federal members of Parliament whose electorates include portions of the Central Highlands Region was reached after much thought and wide consultation with, e.g. P.R.C. members; local State members of Parliament, school councillors from primary, secondary, special and technical schools; many parents of pupils in government schools.

The Federal Minister for Education, Hon. Wal Fife, M.H.R., and the Shadow Minister, Mr John Dawkins, M.H.R. were also invited when it became clear that the consensus of opinion, amongst those consulted, was that the currently alarming inadequacy of funding for government school building programs and site extensions was primarily due to the apparent diversion of funding, by the Federal Government, away from the State primary and post primary schools to other programs.

The purpose of today's meeting of parliamentarians and P.R.C. members is not in any way aligned with party politics. However, one of the R.D.E.'s key responsibilities is in the area of school buildings maintenance and upgrade. The continual decline in the funds available over the past five or six years for government school buildings, especially for maintenance works, can only be described as positively alarming. My purpose is to try to find ways of correcting this worrying situation. I am not in the least interested in political point scoring. But I am concerned about the welfare of our school system. It is essential that parliamentarians of all parties in both State and Federal spheres are shown unmistakably why government school building programs-and especially cyclic maintenance programs-have been virtually at a standstill in the Central Highlands Region, and elsewhere in Victoria, over the past twelve months. During most of that time regions have been largely constrained to initiate only critically urgent minor works necessitated by possible dangers to the health or safety of pupils and Staff.

At that very same meeting those of us who attended were shown films and slides of some 17 schools in the Ballarat region which could be described as being in exactly the same situation as the South Warrnambool State School I spoke of earlier-peeling paint, cracked boards, broken windows, leaking spouts, downpipes, rotting boards and filthy urinals because there was no way that people could keep them clean due to lack of maintenance over the year. There was a general state of decay in that region, as in other regions throughout Victoria so far as the State education system is concerned.

In my view this situation will not be alleviated while this Government continues to pour funds into elitist grammar schools which, as I said earlier, seem to be able to be obtained by elitist groups at the drop of a hat, particularly if they belong to some latter-day Christian minority group-holy rollers of some sort or other. I guess that most honourable senators today received in their mail an epistle from some gentleman from King River or Myrtleford or somewhere, who proposes capital punishment for every man and his dog. Is this sort of person going to be able to obtain funding from this Government to poke his brand of religion or Christianity, or whatever he likes to call it, down the throats of good Australians kids? God forbid that this can happen in a country that has been proud of its egalitarianism over the years and its secular approach to education. Shame on the day that a person such as that or any person like him, can get funds. In my view, it would be like funding Adolf Hitler or Joseph Stalin to fund people like this who want to poke some religious dogma down the throats of innocent kids and have them all marching off to war or whatever, clamouring for capital punishment, for the hanging of some poor innocent citizen who, through some misdemeanour, commits some crime against their ancient Judaean law of an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth. No, I have spoken long enough. I can only say that I am thoroughly ashamed. It is a great disgrace that that Government is prepared to pour out taxpayers' funds, as I have said so many times in the last half hour, for elitist groups in our community while all around us, certainly in my State, the education system is almost dead for the want of maintenance funding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the hour I direct my remarks only to the Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Amendment Bill. This Bill will allow for a far more diversified education system but it really has very little relevance to the large non-government school system. It really provides loans to schools that cannot initially come up with the collateral to get a bank or other loan to build. The problem that governments face with this sort of funding is where to draw the line and the sort of criteria that they should be using when they allocate funds. Should there be no restriction to the variety of schools? If there is to be that sort of restriction, where does a government set the line of demarcation? In many other areas of policy governments have to come up with demarcation lines. When it comes to funding hospitals, many private hospitals would not get government funds. I daresay that the Government would take the attitude that not all hospitals that people would like to be set up would be allowed to be set up. In other words, if any of my colleagues here were to set up a naturopath hospital with herbal cures and everything else there would be very little chance of government funding. Similarly, if someone wanted to set up a private army in Australia I am sure that the Government would not say: 'It is part of the freedom of Australian citizens to set up their own private army and have government funding for it'. Unless they get funds from the Australian Film Commission I really cannot see how anyone could do it.

SPEECH.PARA: One disturbing trend that could relate to this Bill is the development of the various fundamentalist schools around Australia. It is not just sectarianism to say that many people in the community are concerned about the development of the fundamentalist schools. The Uniting Church in Australia, the Catholic Church and, in particular, many of the State school teachers have serious doubts about whether the Commonwealth Government or the State governments should be funding these types of schools. I really share their doubts. The Uniting Church has attacked the teaching methods used in many of these new fundamentalist Christian schools. In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 15 October a Uniting Church report made the following points:
The report singles out the Accelerated Christian Education schools for its strongest comments. The group has 80 schools in Australia, 15 in New South Wales.
The children in these schools spend up to four hours a day working in small cubicles on self-instructional material, which weave biblical texts into the lesson.
If a child working in a cubicle wants help the child must hoist one of two flags-the 'Christian flag' brings the help of a qualified teacher, the Australian flag brings the help of a teachers' aide.
The article then deals with Accelerated Christian Education. It states:
ACE operates almost like a franchised American takeaway food chain. A slick audio-visual display sells the 'product'.

So we have Kentucky-fried education in parts of Australia. Mr Michael Norman, who led an investigation into the dramatic increase in small alternative schools since the mid-1970s, made the following point:
. . . the teaching system is designed to fight the liberalism, modernism and secular humanism of the education systems in Western society.
It is done by feeding graded students, isolated in closed carrels, teaching material infused with fundamentalist religious ideas.
There has been some criticism from the various education departments throughout Australia about the methods being employed. For instance, the National Times states:

Registrar of the Victorian Council of Public Education, Mal Wilkinson, pointed out that Canaan College's curriculum was not considered broad enough, and that other factors about the running of the school had influenced the Council.

This related to registration or deregistration. I wish now to make some general comments on these schools and to state why I am rather disturbed by them. The first thing is that there is no interaction at all between teachers and students. There is not much point really, I believe, in having a teacher in the room if the teacher is there only to be called on for assistance occasionally. We have these large corrals, quite often with some sort of audio system. The students put on headphones and develop under these sorts of American-based programs. There is no interaction at all between the child and the teacher. I think that is a very disturbing trend in education.

But an even greater problem as far as I am concerned is that there is no social interaction in the classroom. One child is isolated from another child. Anyone who has taught in schools would realise that the teaching process and the education process are far more than just the teacher giving students work and that sort of interaction. It is most vital in the development of any child to learn how to relate to other children in the school. That is where in the main they develop their social skills. If that is taken away and children are put in isolation doing what is called self-development courses-perhaps of a biblical nature-we will get very isolated children growing up. This will cause great social problems in the future.

The other aspect that disturbs me is that we have an Australian culture of which we should be proud. We talk about broadening it and including other matters. These courses are American designed wholly and solely. As with television and anything else, the children develop a sort of Americanised mentality. Whilst these schools are very popular, parent disillusionment tends to set in after two, three or four years. Many of the students are taken out of these fundamentalist Christian schools and put back into the State school system. This is where I have heard the most criticism. Many of the teachers who actually have to take over the teaching of these children find that their development is retarded by two or three year levels. They find that if they get 16-year-old students who have been in these schools for three, four or five years in actual fact they are equal to about second form or first form level in regard to education.

The final aspect that worries me is that I think many of the schools adopt methods very close to brain washing. For instance, at the Hare Krishna school in southern Queensland we have the following remark:
The Headmaster, Mr Pariksit Das, admits that the sole reason for the existence of the school is to 'brainwash' the 18 students aged from five to 12.
'Of course we brainwash them', he said. 'We take their brains and wash them clean with the love of God.'

I will not comment on that last part but I am wondering where the Government is going to draw a line in funding these sorts of schools. The Non-government Schools (Loan Guarantee) Amendment Bill makes it much easier for these types of schools to start. It is true that State inspectors in each of the education systems have the right to deregister these types of schools or to put some sort of controls on them. But it must be understood that it is very difficult for these school inspectors to make a judgment about these schools. There is a good deal of social and other pressure on them not to take any action. There is a good deal of pressure on State education departments not to close any of the schools because of the likely voter backlash that eventually may effect the government in power, be it Labor or Liberal.

I am wondering what attitude the Government has and how far it is willing to take this funding. If the Communist Party of Australia decided to set up a school, would the Government fund that school? If the anarchists set up a school would the Government really want to fund that sort of school? The difficulty is-I do not pretend that a Labor government could confront it a lot better than a Liberal government-where one draws the line on these schools. I am not really trying to argue today just in favour of established religion. I am trying to cut out any of the minority religious groups. But I think the Government should try to confront the problem. The legislation before the Senate at the moment will only encourage proliferation of what I call these ratbag schools for their abysmal educational methods. I think we should have a look at that. It is not just a State responsibility to assess whether these schools are competent because Commonwealth funds are involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has been debating by way of cognate debate five education Bills. One of those Bill seeks to provide as a response to the triennial report of the Tertiary Education Commission funds for universities, colleges and technical colleges. Another, in response to the Schools Commission, provides funds for schools. Two other Bills relate to fees in respect of the Australian National University and the Canberra College of Advanced Education. One other Bill relates to funds by way of loan guarantee to new schools.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has taken a general line. It has said, in effect-I do not think I am being uncharitable-that there has been a shrinking of funds to the institutions, that access to the institutions has shrunk and fewer people can get into them. In fact, Opposition members have repeated that only the affluent can now get into these institutions, that there is a fall-off in the numbers in these institutions and that elitism is setting in. They have gone on to criticise the loan guarantees. They have criticised the funding of non-government schools, claiming that that funding is for elitist schools. They have singled out the Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Amendment Bill and they have singled out the proposed rationalisation.

First of all I will deal with the concept that there has been a contraction in funding of education because that is the first plank. In the 1981 calendar year, $2,827m was allocated for educational purposes. In constant money terms, with adjustments for inflation, $2,876m will be allocated for educational purposes in the 1982 calendar year. That is a significant gain of some $49m in real terms. So, in fact, the total money being spent on education has increased. But, lest one feel that the amount we are talking about is miserly, I point out, that this Government is allocating, in these five Bills, about $500 for each taxpayer in Australia. I do not think that any one taxpayer would think that miserly. That is the first dolly over. Rather than there being a shrinking of money, in real terms there has been an expansion.

Next I deal with the number of student enrolments. The situation is very interesting because the fact is that between 1980 and 1981 the number of students in universities and colleges of advanced education increased by 7,000. Where is the contraction in that figure? Seven thousand is a significant increase when one is looking at a movement towards a static and useful population. One has only to look at the enrolment projections of the Tertiary Education Commission to see whether there will be contractions or not. In 1979, 160,000 students, in round numbers, were enrolled at universities. In 1980, 162,500 were enrolled. The 1981 preliminary figures showed that 165,900 were enrolled. For the period 1982 to 1984 up to 166,000 students will be enrolled. So the Tertiary Education Commission says, in fact, that there will be an expansion. In fact, in 1979, 160,126 students were enrolled at colleges of advanced education. It is envisaged that in the period 1980 to 1984 between 168,000 and 172,000 students will be enrolled at colleges of advanced education. That is a very significant increase. Of course, in 1978, 620,514 students were enrolled at colleges of technical and further education. In 1980, 701,820 students were enrolled at TAFE colleges. So the second concept disappears completely. Rather than there being a shrinking either in the money spent on education or in the students enrolled, there has been an expansion.

A quaint argument being put tonight is that the so-called shrinking is due to the fact that there is an application of fees. There has been an attempt to compare Australia with overseas countries. First of all, that attempt is not a good one. For example, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development figures for full time students aged 16 to 18 years show Australian figures are higher than those of the United Kingdom and West Germany. So that is another dolly over. More real money is spent on education and there has been a gain in student numbers. In fact in comparison with the rest of the world we have quite a respectable situation.

I look now at the comments that have been made that we are dealing only for the affluent. They are obviously wrong. There have been comments that we are denying access. They are obviously wrong. I open the papers each day and see universities and colleges advertising places for students. Invitations are being advertised for non-fee bearing courses day after day for people, including mature aged people. So, obviously, access is being invited in a much wider way.

One of the situations that has been a most unhappy one tonight, I think the most misrepresented and the unhappiest of the lot, has been the attempt to misrepresent entirely the state of affairs in state schools and in non-state schools, and an insinuation that non-government schools are elitist schools while state schools are poor schools. The important thing for us to remember is that we do have a Schools Commission-a body that makes the classifications as to which are the affluent schools and which are not. Let us examine the Schools Commission. First of all the Schools Commission says that although all government schools in the Australian system have well passed the targets set by Professor Karmel-I invite honourable senators to listen to this statement-eighty per cent of non-government schools continue to operate with resources some 30 per cent below the average resources of government schools. Of those schools that the Opposition senators are attacking, 80 per cent of them are 30 per cent below the resources of government schools, and those figures are cited by the Schools Commission.

Again for those who are saying there ought not to be money for those schools, let us see what the Schools Commission says. It says, for example, that in 1979-80 money spent by State and Commonwealth governments to educate a student in a government school averaged $1790 a student and in a non-government school $770. The parents are equal taxpayers, and the parents and the children equal Australians. Where now is the justice that the Opposition is talking about? We must bear in mind that the classifications of these schools are made by an objective Schools Commission; the whole basis for the money being passed out is made by such a group.

Now we come to an interesting situation, an attack upon freedom of choice in the development of new schools. First of all, let me make this clear. No school can attract Commonwealth money until it passes the registration provisions of the State Government. In other words, the State Government, with its education standards set up, has first of all to certify that a school will carry out the curricula and the standards of education that it expects.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't do it before they are built!

—If the honourable senator wants to attack the individual States, let him do so. The second situation is this: No money can be passed by way of funds for building new schools unless the planning and finance committees of the various States look at the application and its validity and make a recommendation. Those committees comprise ordinary people drawn from the States and the communities. Ordinary people look at these things. They are not affluent people; they are not wealthy people at all. The Opposition attacks these planning and finance people by saying that they are making prejudiced judgments. Before money can go to one of these schools the State has to say: 'This school is a proper school within our concept of a school'. The planning and finance committee has to look at a school and say: 'This school is eligible for assistance'. It is a sad day in Australia when the Opposition seeks to deny the right of freedom of choice. It is not for any honourable senator here to sneer at any religion. That any honourable senator should sneer at any sect or religion because he or she does not like it is in fact a denial of the very principle for which this chamber stands. That is the very reason that it is repugnant to me to hear honourable senators saying such a thing. Voltaire said:

SPEECH.PARA: I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it.

That is the reason for the existence of the Senate. The situation is that we have established that there is more real money for education, more students coming into the education stream and a widening of the system altogether. It has been established that the Schools Commission has said that the state school system is making improvements much faster than non-government schools, that a body of people, not the Government, makes the recommendations as to the amount of money that shall go to individual schools, and that the States and the planning and finance committees make the recommendations in these things. These are the things that the Opposition has sneered at tonight.

I make it perfectly clear that, although the Government recognises the basic right of all parents to freedom of choice in education, it has no desire to encourage the growth of small alternative schools without the consideration of their educational philosophies and practices. At the request of the Australian Education Council, the Commonwealth has initiated a study of school registration procedures and issues for discussion with State officials and with non-government school authorities. I suppose the Opposition will widen its criticism to attack the Australian Education Council which sets the standards.

As to the criticism of the proposal to rationalise colleges, the fact is that it has been conveniently overlooked that the recommendation for rationalisation came from the Tertiary Education Commission. The recommendation that some 30 colleges be brought together came from the Tertiary Education Commission which saw the desirability that single purpose teaching institutions should not persist and that there should be an improvement not only in the administration but also in the general education of these colleges by their rationalisation and co-ordination. Those who sneer at this might well remember that the report of the Murray committee said very strongly in this regard that there was an irrefutable need for the development of a national policy for Australian universities. It said that there must be collaboration, co-operation and co-ordination between universities, the Commonwealth Government and the State governments if unnecessary duplication and wastage of scarce resources are to be avoided. The report continued in that vein. In other words, the Murray committee has laid down these principles.

That, in a nutshell, is the case. Senator Button referred to Queensland. He said that the Queensland Government had not agreed to the amalgamation of the James Cook University and the Townsville College of Advanced Education. I am advised that the Queensland Government has agreed to that amalgamation and that only seven of the 30 colleges of advanced education are outstanding at the moment.

The Government will not accept the proposed amendments. The amendment proposed to the States Grants (Tertiary Assistance) Bill 1981 is in defiance of the concept of the Tertiary Education Commission. For example, I cannot believe that anyone would come forward with a straight face, having attacked the independent schools, and argue that the advancement of one sector of the Australian school system should not be at the disadvantage of another sector, whether public or private, as this would revive tensions. That came after a large part of tonight was spent attacking the private sector of education and the money spent on that. The disadvantaged side of education is the private sector. It does nobody any good to extend the propaganda that the independent schools are the elite and the Government schools are not. An amount of $1,790 of taxpayers money is spent a head on students at government schools and $770 a head is spent on non-government school students. That amount of money is decided on by an objective body, the Schools Commission, which was set up by the Whitlam Government. In the face of this and in the knowledge that we are bringing forward Bills expending enormous sums of money on education in Australia-an amount larger than the year before and widening the number of students coming into the system-I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take a little of the time of the Senate, even at this stage of the night, to raise on the adjournment the matter of compensation for some Australians who were held in concentration camps during world War II. The Senate may be aware that some prisoners of war were held not in prisoner of war camps, as apparently was the legal requirement in war, but actually in concentration camps. This matter has not been finally settled. The Australians concerned have not been compensated for that action.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer in particular to Walter Wise, an Australian Army private who was among a number of Australian, New Zealand and British servicemen who found themselves in Theresienstadt concentration camp in Czechoslovakia during the latter part of the Second World War. When he and others were taken there by the Gestapo in late 1944 they were taken underground to a cell which had just been vacated. The occupants had been shot to make room for the new prisoners. Walter wise was one of 88 prisoners held in a cell where the blood was still wet on the walls and floor. Apparently they took turns in standing and sleeping on the floor. There was no toilet and only one tap. During the day they were put to work moving earth with their bare hands. They were also made to clean out the cells of the dead Jews, collecting bodies on what was known as the morgue cart. They were punished for moving too slowly, grinning, failing to bow their heads when being spoken to and being caught asleep or unwashed. For those 'sins' they were placed on a low bench head down with someone sitting on the neck and another on the legs, and their bare buttocks were beaten with a stick with a metal spike on the end. This punishment was inflicted until the flesh was pulp and the prisoner passed out. It was in those conditions that Walter Wise and his mates spent seven months until 1 May 1945.

Walter Wise is now 65 and lives comfortably in Hobart, but those days in Theresienstadt have left their mark. They have had a dreadful psychological impact on him and others like him. Yet neither Walter Wise nor the other Australians who were held in German concentration camps have ever received one cent in compensation. They had to battle to get the Australian Government even to recognise that they spent time in those camps. Now any action seems to have stopped there. I do not like raising matters from so long ago or from war time, but the compensation should be provided. There is also the danger that the Federal Republic of Germany will call an end to compensating the victims of war crimes, but the Australian Government does not seem in the least concerned about that. It is only in recent years that this--

TALK.START.PARA: —What nationality are they?
—Australians.
—What were they during the war?

—Australians; this matter has been raised only in recent years and a lot of work was done by a journalist, Paul Rea, of the Newcastle Herald. Since then some action has slowly started to be taken. There has been lots of correspondence involving the Ombudsman and the Department of Foreign Affairs. The British victims of this illegal action were recognised by the Federal Republic of Germany in the 1960s when an Anglo-German agreement set up a fund. That is 20 years ago and the Australian vicitims of this breach of international law are still waiting, still hoping and still suffering from the emotional scars inflicted by the regime of Nazi Germany. What do they have to do to draw attention to the shabby treatment they have received? Is it not enough to make direct approaches to the relevant government departments and Opposition shadow Ministers and tell their stories of horror and terror through the news media? How can they make their cries heard?

SPEECH.PARA: The most recent event was in May 1980. The Department of Foreign Affairs informed Mr Wise that discussions were taking place with New Zealand about a joint approach to the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany. New Zealand indicated its willingness to make this approach. I want to know whether a final agreement was ever reached.

The present honourable member for Denison said at the time that he supported this joint approach, but did he ever take this up? Was he only grandstanding, seeking publicity? In June last year the then Minister for Foreign Affairs advised our former colleague, Ken Wriedt, that the Australian Government would definitely seek compensation for these ex-servicemen, but there the matter ended. Perhaps the only way to solve this problem is for an inquiry to be held into all Australian prisoners of war who, I believe, received only pitiful compensation soon after the War. If the Government cannot take action without some strong recommendations from such an inquiry, we had better have one fast because time is running out. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister for Primary Industry confirm that the Bureau of Agricultural Economics has reported a decline of almost 29 per cent in the number of beef properties in Australia since 1975.
(2) Have thousands of cattlemen with fewer than 200 head of cattle left the industry.
(3) What effect has the drought which devastated south-western Queensland and New South Wales had on the availability of slaughter cattle.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Associated with ongoing research into structural change in rural industry, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics published in the May 1981 issue of the Quarterly Review of the Rural Economy an article dealing with the beef industry in the 1970s. In that particular article, the observation was made that there was a decline of almost 29 per cent in the number of beef-producing properties over the five years 1974-75 to 1978-79. The source of data for this particular study was the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

(2) In that same period, there was a reduction of around 34,000 in the number of beef holdings with fewer than 200 head. The degree to which the operators of these properties were dependent on beef cattle, and the activities, rural or otherwise, to which they turned after leaving the industry, will only become apparent as further rural industry statistics become available.

(3) In November and December 1980 the BAE conducted a telephone survey of producers in parts of Queensland and New South Wales considered to be drought-affected. The results of this survey were also published in the May issue of the BAE's Quarterly Review of the Rural Economy. In New South Wales, 34 per cent of beef producers contacted were reported as experiencing drought conditions sufficiently severe to make them contemplate the sale of above average numbers of cattle from their properties before June 1981. In Queensland, 25 per cent of producers contacted anticipated selling extra cattle because of drought. Seasonal conditions improved from May 1981.

In 1980-81 total cattle slaughter in Australia was approximately 8.5 million head. Although this is around 4 per cent below the 1979-80 level it is likely that the decrease would have been substantially larger without the forced turn-off of cattle as a result of the drought.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1093) Senator Jones asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. The honourable senator's question was as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Does the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry recall that on 15 September in the other place during discussion on Estimates Committee D the Minister for Primary Industry, in reply to a question from the honourable member for Moore about the cost to taxpayers, consumers and exporters of maintaining a dual State-Commonwealth meat inspection system, quoted a figure of $5m.

How does the Minister reconcile the fact that on the following day, as recorded in the Senate Hansard, in reply to the same question as put in a question upon notice by me, he claimed that the estimated cost was only $1.25m.
The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The best estimate of the direct additional cost to the meat industry of the present dual State-Commonwealth meat inspection system is $1.25m.

This estimate was provided by the High Level Working Group on Meat Inspection in its report to the Standing Committee on Agriculture at the Darwin meeting on 29 July 1981. It represents the calculated savings that adoption of either of the two proposed options under discussion at that time may have produced had they been agreed to.

Upper estimates of costs to the Australian community have been put at $5m but would include all the components of meat inspection, charges and related animal health administration in Commonwealth and State governments. Many of these costs are inextricable from government administrations in the federal system but represent costs that could be attributed in some way to the dual system.
